WT01-B08-1IA062-000351-B044-6http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni6.html 207.32.88.17 19970115195710 text/html 3293HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 19:50:07 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 3122Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:25:19 GMT Falklands-Malvinas News 6 Falklands - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 1/1/97 POSSIBLE OIL BONANZA LEADSTO FRICTIONS WITH BRITISH PRESS STANLEY. (MP).- Oil has yet to befound and in commercially sustainable volumes, but controversyhas already taken off. First it was Tony Lloyd, LabourMP and shadow spokesman for the area who after a short visitsuggested that the islands would have to pass on to the BritishTreasury some of the enormous revenue expected from the comingoil bonanza. This was followed by reports from Britishjournalists, guests of the islands' government, who indicated thepossibility of a 1,1 billion pounds oil revenue in twenty yearstime, and wondered what could this mean for the personality andunique life style of the Falklanders. The Times went further andin an editorial reminded the islanders that "citizenshave as many obligations as rights, the main of which is to paytaxes according to their means". Although a colonyislanders are full British citizens. The Falklands-Malvinasgovernment, in spite of the recent optimism about oil, has triedto down play the controversy by arguing that it's not possible topretend a fixed rate, "when we still don't know how muchwe will be receiving". Councillors on the other handconfirmed in a release that "it was on their owninitiative that they wrote a letter two years ago to the Britishgovernment offering to defray the cost of the defence of theFalkland Islands should a sufficient quantity of oil be found". WT01-B08-2IA062-000351-B044-45http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni121296.html 207.32.88.17 19970115195730 text/html 9094HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 19:50:29 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 8923Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:23:47 GMT Falklands - Malvinas News Full version FalklandS - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 12/12/96 "POLAR PRINCESS" BEGUINS SEISMIC SURVEYING OFF THE FALKLANDS - MALVINAS STANLEY. (MP).- The oil industry has began its search for hydrocarbons off the Falklands - Malvinas well in advance of the most optimistic forecasts. The Norwegian flag "Polar Princess" started surveying on December 3rd and it's expected that by the beginning of January three vessels will be involved in seismic related activities, the first stage in the exploration for oil. OIL COMPANIES COOPERATE TO CUT COSTS AND RISKS STANLEY. (MP).- Although it's still unofficial, all the consortiums licensed to search for hydrocarbons in the Falklands - Malvinas, with the exception of Shell, are progressing in finding ways to cooperate and cut costs and risks in the mostly unexplored South Atlantic oil territory. AEROVIAS DAP NEEDS A PARTNER, BUT "WILL CONTINUE TO FLY TO THE ISLANDS" PUNTA ARENAS. (PM).- Aerov�as DAP categorically assured that it will continue the air link to the Falklands - Malvinas, is spite of the fact that the Piscevic brothers from Punta Arenas, who own the company, confirmed that they are looking for partners with fresh funds. FALKLANDS - MALVINAS CULTURE CROSSES OVER TO THE CONTINENT STANLEY. (MP).- Believe it or not, expressions of the Falklands - Malvinas culture have crossed to the continent and are making a splash in Santiago and in Buenos Aires. "NORMALIZATION" OF RELATIONS WITH ARGENTINA IS FAVOURED BY LABOUR STANLEY. (MP).- "I do believe there should be a normalization of relations, and most certainly a Labor government will talk to Argentina about the Falkland - Malvinas, but not on the sovereignty issue unless the islanders request it", remarked Tony Lloyd, Labour MP and "Shadow Minister" responsible for the South Atlantic. SCIENTISTS RECOMMEND CLOSER MONITORING OF SQUID AND "POLACA" BUENOS AIRES. (MP).- In spite of the "friendly and constructive" atmosphere during the last session of the Fisheries Commission of the South Atlantic, no advances on a long term fishing agreement were reported in the joint Argentine-British release after the meeting held in Buenos Aires. SECOND ROUND FOR THE "INDEPENDENCE" PROPOSAL LONDON. (MP).- Following on the recent British Argentine Conference held during October in Salta, Argentina, academics, politicians and diplomats met again but this time in Longford Castle, Salisbury, to talk about the future of the Falklands - Malvinas and how to break the deadlocked 160 years old dispute. OVERNIGHT VISIT TO THE ISLANDS BY ARGENTINE NEXT OF KIN RELATIVES STANLEY. (MP).- Next of kin relatives of Argentines buried in the Falklands - Malvinas will be visiting the islands overnight in small groups of sixteen, on January 22nd. and February 20th. YPF MIGHT FINALLY MAKE IT TO FALKLANDS MALVINAS OIL LONDON. (MP).- According to press reports in London and Milan, YPF is discussing the possibility of participating with the Shell-Agip consortium in the exploration of oil off-shore the Falklands - Malvinas. HIGH SEAS RESCUE FROM LEAD BOAT IN YATCH RACE STANLEY. (MP).- A crew member suffering from a suspected duodenal ulcer, was evacuated in the high seas from the lead boat in the BT Global Challenge yatch race, a hundred miles to the north of the islands. WT01-B08-4IA062-000351-B044-98http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/snif.html 207.32.88.17 19970115195805 text/html 10052HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 19:51:07 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 9881Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:31:34 GMT Mercosur News Full Version Mercosur News Mercopress Agency 1/1/97 THE SOUTHERN CROSS, SEAL OF MERCOSUR FORTALEZA. (MP).- After longdiscussions, a blue southern cross with a green under stroke on aclear background was finally chosen as the seal of the Mercosurtrade block and officially inaugurated during the presidentialsummit held in the north of Brazil on December 17th. Argentinedelegates objected the seal because the southern cross hasbasically four stars and could be interpreted as a closedorganisation with only its four original members (Argentina,Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay), leaving aside new associatemembers such as Chile and from next May, Bolivia. Uruguayan andBrazilian delegates on the other hand argued that the southerncross is a constellation of stars with the four brightestrepresenting the original country members. Finally it was agreedthat the seal, "if necessary could be modernised in thefuture", as more stars (countries) are definitivelyincorporated to the group. The seal was chosen by a jury of eight(two for each member country) among 1.412 presentations with a10.000 US dollars prize for the winner, an Argentine artist. BOLIVIA BECOMES AN ASSOCIATE MEMBER FORTALEZA.(MP).- Bolivia became an associate member of Mercosurand the official integration will take place as of next May oncethe different parliaments ratify the agreements reached in thepresidential summit held in the Brazilian city of Fortaleza. Lastminute negotiations opened the doors to an understanding which inthe previous days seemed hard to reach because of the differenceswith Argentina over a long list of products the Bolivians wantedto privilege with a long term reduction of tariffs such astextiles and agricultural commodities. "We're happy withwhat was agreed, otherwise we wouldn't have signed",said Bolivian president Gonzalo S�nchez de Lozada, in spite ofhaving to step back in many of his country's original demands.After Chile last October, and Bolivia in May, the next candidatefor an association with Mercosur is oil rich Venezuela, which hasalready requested to become a member and is quiet advanced in thenegotiations. Brasilia is particularly interested in Venezuelasince Mercosur so far has only benefited the southern states ofBrazil next to Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. With Venezuela,(in the north of South America), many of the poor states ofnorth-east Brazil could have direct access to an important marketfor industrial goods. Brazil is aggressively promoting industrialinvestments in the area to combat poverty and also wants todiversify its oil dependency by increasing imports fromVenezuela. OPEN SKIES, A DEVELOPMENT BANK AND THESECRETARIAT IN MONTEVIDEO FORTALEZA. (MP).- Thecreation of a development bank for Mercosur countries, a policyof open skies for small and medium cities of the area and thelocation of the Secretariat in Montevideo, were some of the veryimportant decisions taken in the Fortaleza summit. A specialgroup of experts was given five months to elaborate a report onhow to set up a non bureaucratic financial institution, whichmust help in structural development investments such as theimprovement of land and fluvial communications systems tofacilitate trade and cut costs. Aid for the new bank has beenpromised by the World Bank, the Interamerican Development Bankand the Japanese government. Deregulation of regional flights wasdecided to promote direct links between medium and small citiesof the six countries which at present can only be reached by stepflying through the main international airports of the area innever ending trips. Direct scheduling between regional airportswill not interfere the main bilateral agreements. FinallyMontevideo was confirmed as the permanent location for theMercosur Secretariat, which will have an initial budget of 1,2million US dollars and will be headed until 1999 by UruguayanAmbassador Jorge Fern�ndez Reyes. TRADE UNIONS COORDINATE FIRST EVERSTOPPAGE IN THE REGION BRASILIA. (MP).-Integration spirit is not only limited to government and businessdecisions: trade unions of the six Mercosur countries have asupranational co-ordinating committee and coinciding with theFortaleza presidential summit they organised a relativelysuccessful general stoppage of several hours. Besides the 17th ofDecember was declared the "International Day for thestruggle of the human rights of the Mercosur Workers",and will be celebrated annually. During the presidential summit,representatives of the main eight Mercosur workers unions, plusan American representative for the American Workers Federationand the Congress of Industrial Organisations, held a meeting inFortaleza and released a document with a list of common demands.Top of the list was the creation of mechanisms for collectivenegotiations on working conditions and salaries at Mercosurlevel, plus more legal space in the block's decision makingprocess, for social organisations including non governmentorganisations (NGO). Secondly a Bill of Rights, based onregulations and agreements of the International LabourOrganisation (ILT); thirdly a policy for promoting jobs,productive reconversion and retraining in new trades. In spite ofgrowing economies, unemployment has become one of the worst fearsand threats for workers in Mercosur countries: the official ratesare as follows: Argentina 17%, Brazil 14%, Uruguay 12%, Chile 8%. THE MAGNIFICENT "OMBU",SYMBOL OF MERCOSUR CULTURE MONTEVIDEO. (MP).- The"omb�", the magnificent tree which grows andoutstands solitarily in the pampas and Southamerican grasslands,has been selected as the symbol of cultural integration forMercosur. The Education and Culture Ministers of the fourfounding countries agreed on the omb� sketch during a meeting inUruguay and decided it will be used to identify all culturalassets, facilitating their circulation through Customs and PostOffices of the different country members. The cultural logotypeincludes two "omb�" outlines, one blue andred, another green and yellow, which overlap, on a whitebackground and with the inscription Mercosur Cultural in black.The novelty of the symbol is that when the two outlines areoverlapped into a single figure the inscription can becomeMercosul, which is the Portuguese translation of Mercosur. So thenew cultural symbol includes several integration factors such asthe colour of the banners and the two languages, Spanish andPortuguese. Ministers also decided on an agenda of activities forthe next semester which will begin with a show of pictures fromthe world famous Jesuit Missions and the first of a series ofstamp editions dedicated to outstanding artists of Mercosur. WT01-B08-10IA062-000351-B044-295http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni121296.html 207.32.88.17 19970115200034 text/html 6780HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 19:53:37 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 6609Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:30:11 GMT Mercosur News Full version Mercosur News Mercopress Agency 12/12/96 CLOSED BRIDGE AFFECTS 56% OF LAND TRADE BETWEEN ARGENTINA AND BRAZIL URUGUAYANA. (MP).- The momentary closing down of a bridge over the Paran� river, one of the main waterways of South America, has had a negative impact on Mercosur trade because of the delays and increase in the cost of freight. MERCOSUR IS STILL HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON FARM EXPORTS BRASILIA. (MP).- "Mercosur countries overall must reduce their dependence on agrobusiness exports and try to increase their supply of manufactured goods". The recommendation was made by Professor Mauro Borges, a Brazilian economist and international trade expert. A SOUTHAMERICAN PARLIAMENT TO SUSTAIN ECONOMIC PROGRESS? SAO PAULO. (MP).- The prospects of an expanding Mercosur which could include the whole of the South American continent, is one of the main papers of discussion considered by an American-Brazilian think tank in Sao Paulo. NEGATIVE EFFECTS OF ECONOMIC INTEGRATION SAO PAULO. (MP).- A question which keeps cropping up in Brazil is how does the Mercosur integration process influence the regional misbalances in a large country, and how does this impact in the rest of the economy. SAO PAULO WILL BE THE DOOR OF ACCESS FOR BRITISH INVESTMENTS SAO PAULO. (MP).- "Relations between Brazil and the United Kingdom are growing, and Sao Paulo will be the door of access for British investments in the Mercosur block". The remarks were made by Anthony Nelson, British Trade Minister Anthony Nelson, who visited Argentina and Brazil to promote the "Link into Latinamerica" conference to be held next February in London. EUROPE COUNSELS MERCOSUR ON ITS OWN EXPERIENCE MONTEVIDEO. (MP).- European personalities counselled Mercosur countries to take notice not only of the achievements, but also of the mistakes committed by the Common Market in its long process to become the European Union. 1980 a 1996 los datos del Censo excluyen aquellas personas abordo de barcos; los datos del censo de 1986 y 1991 tambi�n excluyen aquellas personas en servicio en las Falklands/Malvinas en relaci�n con la base militar. Los datos de 1991 y 1996 no incluyen las personas que est�n presentes en forma temporal (1991 = 90; 1996=38), o el n�mero estimados de personas que est�n ausentes en forma temporal (1991 = 119; 1996= 140).</font></p> <p><font face="Arial">++ Los datos de 1996 incluyen 483 personas presentes en FalKlands/Malvinas en relaci�n con la base militar , pero excluyen todo personal militar.</font></p> <hr> align="center" width="25%" height="16"><font color="#000000" size="2" face="Arial">3</font></td> <td align="center" width="25%" height="16"><font color="#000000" size="2" face="Arial">5</font></td> <td align="center" width="25%" bgcolor="#FFFF00" height="16"><font color="#000000" size="2" face="Arial"><strong>8</strong></font></td> </tr> </table> </center></div><p><font face="Arial">* To date of Census (24 April 1996)</font></p> <p><font face="Arial"><strong>Notes</strong> :</font></p> <ol> <li><font face="Arial">These figures are extracted from Register of Births, but the births are apportioned to the year in which they occurred and not the year in which they were registered.</font></li> <li><font face="Arial">Because of the method used (note 1) the figures do not correspond in all instance with those shown in Table 5 of the 1986 Census Report. For example, a birth on 21/02/82 was not registered until 13/02/84, and in the 1986 Census Report, stillbirths appear to have been included.</font></li> <li><font face="Arial">It should be noted that these figures will not included births to women whose confinement took place overseas for medical reasons.</font></li> </ol> <hr> <p><a href="census.html" target="_top"><img src="images/atras.gif" align="middle" border="0" width="50" height="50">Back</a></p> <!--webbot bot="Include" endspan i-checksum="25843" --> </body> Round Fares To The Uk For All Falklanders PORT STANLEY.(MP).- Every man, woman and child in the Falkland Islands will be entitled to a free round fare to Britain to enjoy holidays abroad. The announcement was made by Andrew Gurr, CEO of the islands, who said the decision followed a recommendation by a team of British experts who made a special report on the terms and employment conditions of the Civil Service. Brothers Reunite But Remain Distant On Falklands' Issues BUENOS AIRES. (MP).- Terrance and Alexander Betts are brothers and islanders of very humble background. Since early age Alexander had to make a living carrying peat to help his parents, but not Terry who suffered constant health problems. Oil Licencing For The "Special Cooperation Area" During 1997 LONDON. (MP).- Great Britain and Argentina will be launching the oil exploration licensing round in the special joint cooperation area in the South Atlantic during 1997. Seismic surveying licenses will be extended to all those companies interested before the end of 1996. A Proposal For The Future Of The Islands LONDON. (MP).- A future of independence, or leading to some form of autonomy to be decided by the islanders, having both Great Britain and Argentina as guarantors, is the essence of the paper which is being informally circulated in Argentina, Great Britain and the Falklands. (MP).- A 30 pages paper titled "Future of agriculture in the Falklands", which is a summary on the many reports on farming, a most controversial issue in the islands, was finally released by the Legislative Council. 16.000 Miles Medical Rescue Mission In The South Atlantic PORT STANLEY. (MP).- What is believed to be the longest ever medical rescue mission took place in the South Atlantic. (MP).- British investments in Argentina will reach 2,2 billion US dollars by the end of the century according to a report by the British Chamber of Commerce (BCC), in Buenos Aires and the private Foundation "Invertir". Joint Command For Brazilian And Argentine Troops In A Near Future BRASILIA. (MP).- In not a too distant future Argentine and Brazilian troops could be operating under an only joint command since both countries do not consider each other "conflict hypothesis" and now have common strategic targets. Brazil Under Pressure From Investors And Local Exporters SAO PAULO. (MP).- Strong lobbying from Sao Paulo's exporters and equally strong demands for a quicker opening of the Brazilian market from foreign investors and bankers, have forced the government of Mercosur's main member into a defensive situation. Businessmen Against Bolivian Membership Of Mercosur LA PAZ. (MP).- Businessmen from Argentina and Bolivia are complaining about Mercosur in spite of the fact that Argentine President Carlos Menem in his official visit to Bolivia, signed 18 agreements to increase trade between both countries and ensure Bolivia'a integration next January to Mercosur. Negotiations With Andean Block To Continue In Lima MONTEVIDEO. (MP).- The second round of negotiations of Mercosur with the Andean countries, (Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Per� and Venezuela) to create a free trade zone between the two blocks, ended with no progress reported. Mexico, After A Closer Relation With Mercosur BUENOS AIRES. (MP).- Mexico wishes to have a closer bilateral economic relation with Argentina and in the near future a possible "four plus one" association agreement with Mercosur, leading to block to block links with NAFTA (North American Free Trade Association). Theannouncement was made by Andrew Gurr, CEO of the islands, whosaid the decision followed a recommendation by a team of Britishexperts who made a special report on the terms and employmentconditions of the Civil Service. The program already has the support fromall the elected members of the Legislative Council, and consistsof three consecutive annual vouchers of � 315 which will then beexchanged for a round fare, equivalent to � 940, which is thecost of traveling to Britain via Ascension Island on the RAF TriStar. To fly through Punta Arenas/Santiago on DAP/British Airwayscosts an additional � 25, but islanders will be able to choose. The Hay report describes the vacationsinitiative as a necessary "cultural opening",while Andrew Gurr considered it the best way to distribute wealthamong islanders. "We can't enforce a negativeincome tax system, but we can make a fair distribution of thegrowing income from fishing, both among those who work for thegovernment and those who don't", said Gurr. Since the enforcement of the fishingexclusion zone round the islands in 1985, the Falklands have hadannual budget surplus and reserves invested in Britain exceed 180million US dollars for a population of just 2.300 islanders. But both Mr. Gurr and several Councilors,as well as the Hay report, do not deny a political motive alsobehind the decision: to increase and perpetuate the strong linkswith Britain. Nor surprisingly the decision was takenwhen the islands are in the threshold of a possible oil bonanzaand when the Foreign Office is pressing the islands for a gradual"normalization" of links with Argentina. WT01-B08-31IA062-000352-B044-94http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni2211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201409 text/html 3474HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:07:11 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 3303Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:33:12 GMT Falklands - Malvinas 2 Falklands - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 Brothers Reunite ButRemain Distant On Falklands' Issues BUENOSAIRES. (MP).- Terrance and Alexander Betts are brothersand islanders of very humble background. Since early ageAlexander had to make a living carrying peat to help his parents,but not Terry who suffered constant health problems. In 1982 Alexander was working for theArgentine air link and left the islands with the defeated troops.He established in C�rdoba and married a local girl. Terryremained in the Falklands, took advantage of the fishing boom andnow is a very prosperous businessman. They never met again until 1987 in theUnited Nations, in New York but in opposite sides: Terry as aCouncillor and member of the British delegation before theDecolonization Committee, Alexander attacking British colonialismand exploitation of the Falklands. Nine years later Terry was present inArgentina for the annual Argentine British Conference held inSalta, and both brothers were able to meet again, this time inBuenos Aires. The motive: their father's recent death andAlexander's birthday. Alexander still has a similar job andcomplained bitterly about the hard living conditions now a daysin Argentina. But he remains as convinced as ever of Argentina'smore legitimate rights over the islands, while Terry insists thatrights belong to those living in the Falklands for the last 163years. What was the final score? Both shareddrinks to celebrate Alexander's birthday, but also agreed topolitely disagree on the Falklands issue. WT01-B08-32IA062-000352-B044-117http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni3211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201424 text/html 3421HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:07:24 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 3250Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:33:28 GMT Falklands - Malvinas 3 Falklands - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 Oil Licencing For The"Special Cooperation Area" During 1997 LONDON. (MP).- Great Britainand Argentina will be launching the oil exploration licensinground in the special joint cooperation area in the South Atlanticduring 1997. Seismic surveying licenses will be extended to allthose companies interested before the end of 1996. The agreement was reached during anunscheduled meeting of Argentine Foreign Affairs Minister, GuidoDi Tella with Foreign Secretary Malcolm Rifkind in London, duringthe second week of November. According to a spokesperson from theForeign Office a coming meeting of the Hydrocarbons JointCommittee of the South Atlantic to be held in early December inLondon, will "be crucial for the discussions over thelicensing terms which are making great progress". Thespecial cooperation refers to the area where waters of theFalklands and Argentina overlap. But contrary to oil, in fisheries there wasno advance. Nevertheless both sides agreed to continue addressingthe issue: Britain insisting on a long term agreement, Argentinaon including South Georgia to the Falklands conservation andmonitoring discussions. And even if the Foreign Office spokespersonunderlined that the "moment is not right for apresidential visit", in reference to the long announcedvisit of the Argentine President to Britain, both ForeignSecretaries did agree on two visits of next of kin relatives tothe Argentine cemetery in Darwin, before next February. WT01-B08-33IA062-000352-B044-140http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni4211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201436 text/html 3741HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:07:38 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 3570Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:33:44 GMT Falklands Malvinas News 4 Falklands - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 A Proposal For The FutureOf The Islands LONDON. (MP).- A future ofindependence, or leading to some form of autonomy to be decidedby the islanders, having both Great Britain and Argentina asguarantors, is the essence of the paper which is being informallycirculated in Argentina, Great Britain and the Falklands. The man responsible for the draft proposalis Alistair Forsyth, a merchant banker, member of the ArgentineBritish Conference, who has taken to heart the South Atlanticdispute. One of the basic arguments of the paper isthat the 163 years old conflict won't be solved to completesatisfaction of any of the sides involved. Another the growingsense of identity and confidence developed by the noweconomically autonomous islanders which could convince them tobreak away from the motherly protection of Britain. "A strong, brave politicalleadership from both Argentina and Britain could help find a wayto overcome with honour for all parts, the ever present potentialfor crisis", says Forsyth. During a transition period of ten to twentyyears both Argentina and Britain would have a presence in theislands helping to preserve a very unique way of life andcollaborating with the preparations for independence. At a pre-established date both guarantorswould leave the islands, meaning the end of the colony, and thelocal population can then decide and strongly develop their ownfuture. Forsyth believes links and trade with thecontinent would be normalized and the islands would benefit fromall that the Argentines have to offer them. "Argentina during these last yearshas shown pragmatism, political maturity and unequal boldness toreform the society and change long established beliefs; whyshould they not accept the Forsyth paper for discussion?". WT01-B08-34IA062-000352-B044-159http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni5211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201455 text/html 3014HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:07:53 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 2843Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:34:03 GMT Falklands Malvinas 5 Falklands - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 Future Of Agriculture PORT STANLEY. (MP).- A 30 pagespaper titled "Future of agriculture in the Falklands",which is a summary on the many reports on farming, a mostcontroversial issue in the islands, was finally released by theLegislative Council. The paper written by CEO Andrew Gurrunderlines the idea that agriculture is the "long termprize for the islands" since once fishing and oil areover, farming will be the only resource available. From this basic idea the report describes asignificant list of recommendations to develop an alternativeagriculture, taking advantage of new technologies, such asimprovement of pastures, crops, trees, legumes, cattle breeding,wool classification, fertilizers, genetic engineering, etc.. But also taking into account livingconditions in the Camp to ensure a balanced development in allthe islands, and that consumer prices, for example, are nothigher than in Port Stanley like at present. Falklands Landholdings is another importantissue included in the report with all its impact on landsubdivision and community farming. WT01-B08-35IA062-000352-B044-186http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni6211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201507 text/html 2596HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:08:09 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 2425Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:34:18 GMT Falklands - Malvinas News 6 Falklands - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 16.000 Miles MedicalRescue Mission In The South Atlantic PORT STANLEY. (MP).- Whatis believed to be the longest ever medical rescue mission tookplace in the South Atlantic. An American nine seats, twin engined LearJet made a 36 hours flight from Jacksonville, Florida to theFalklands and back to pick up an 82 years old American who brokehis hip on a cruise ship. The "Society Explorer"sailing for the South Georgia islands was surprised by a stormand fierce seas in the middle of the South Atlantic leavingseveral people injured and forced to divert to the Falklands. The Lear Jet refueled in Rio do Janeirobefore landing at RAF's military base in Falklands and thefollowing morning made the 18 hours return trip to Jacksonville:a total of 16.000 miles. WT01-B08-36IA062-000352-B044-216http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni031196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201525 text/html 25414HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:08:23 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 25242Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:23:03 GMT Falklands - Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 3/11/96 SURPRISE IN THE ISLANDDS OVER YPF/BRITISH GAS'S ABSENCE In spite of the public rejoice in the islands with the successfull oil bidding, the major surprise and comments from the three sides involved in the complicated South Atlantic scenario, was the apparent failure of the application for a licence by the Argentine/British consortium YPF/British Gas. Rumours had been anticipating what was considered incredible but it so happened, and officials in the islands, Britain and from YPF (the Argentine oil company which is now private) were quick in disactivating any wrong interpretation of the event. "We're a private company and we make our own decisions on the basis of efficiency and commercial criteria, certainly not politicial. Under no way can this be interpreted as a discriminatory action against Argentina", emphasized Nells Le�n YPF's president, as well as Roberto Monti who will be succeding him next April. Anyhow YPF made it quiet clear that if there's a new licencing round to the north of the islands, the company will bid again and obviously will also partipate when the joint bidding of the so called Special Area is convened. The special cooperation area is to the west of the islands where border lines with Argentina overlap, and is the result of last year's September Oil Understanding agreed in the United Nations between Prime Minister John Major and President Carlos Menem. The area will be jointly explored and exploited between both countries. Both Governor Ralph and CEO Andrew Gurr pointed out that the Argentine-British consortium lost because they didn't meet the requirements and concentrated their interest in the two most popular tranches, but added that they expect an Argentine participation in future rounds. A similar message came from the British Ambassador in Buenos Aires Peter Hall who said that: "our policy and the islands policy is of open doors to Argentine companies, but that will depend on the commercial and technical level of the bids". The Argentine Foreign Office also received the consortium's exclusion calmly, in spite of the setback that this could mean for the present approachment policy towards the islands and islanders. "The British government gave us assurances that commercial reasons exclusively were decisive and that no political circumstances influenced the non allocation of a licence". Nevertheless the Argentine press revealed that in two occasions British diplomacy warned the Argentines that the YPF/British Gas was not sufficient. There was a first attempt to improve it, but on the second time, YPF allegedly simply replied, "this is as far as we'll go". According to the Argentine press reports, "frustration" over YPF/British Gas exclusion was shared by both Foreign Offices. ECONOMIC BONANZA AND DRILLING IN EARLY '98 The population of the Falklands/Malvinas is preparing for what they consider unexpected years of economic bonanza following the very successfull first ever allocation of off shore hydrocarbons exploration licences with the involvement of the some main oil companies of the world. It is estimated that towards the end of the '97 austral summer the first groups of oil industry experts and officials will begin arriving in the islands, and possibly in early '98, the first exploratory drilling could be starting. In this first five years exploratory stage, the licenced companies have promised to invest several hundred millions of dollars which although mostly will be in sophisticated equipment and services, and in the high seas, there will be ample margin for the business talent and capacities of the 2.300 islanders. Several local industries such as construction, hotel and lodging, and supply services are already anticipating a boom while in the camp farmers are offering land on lease next to deep shores for the oil companies to set up their operational bases. Richard Ralph, Governor of the islands said that with the successfull allocation of licences a "potentially momentous day" and far-reaching time begins for the future of the Falklands. The CEO of the islands, Andrew Gurr underlined that the 28th October will become the second most important date in the recent history of the Falklands after the liberation of the islands by British troops on June 14th. 1982. John Martin, former British Petroleum official and one of the main oil experts on contract for the local government indicated that "the enthusiastic response to the Falklands Islands government offer has been most satisfactory, and ensures a vigorous entry of the islands into the oil exploration industry". Phyllis Rendell who was making her official international d�but as Director of the Oil Department explained that at this stage licence revenue will produce very little since companies will be paying an annual fee of 30 US dollars per square kilometer. "But even if hydrocarbons are found, and in interesting volumes, it would take several years before commercial production actually gets rolling, we're looking at the year 2003", said Mrs. Rendell. The Oil Department Director also remembered that between 50 to 60 wells were drilled in the North Sea before oil was discovered. Mrs. Rendell underlined that the islands government will be closely monitoring activity in the licenced tranches with particular emphasis on the protection of the unique natural environment. "Some areas of the blocks will have restricted access at times in order to preserve and protect the marine resources". COMPANIES AWARDED LICENCES TO EXPLORE FOR OIL OFF SHORE On October 28th., early morning, first from Stanley and a few hours later from London, the Falklands/Malvinas government announced the list of companies awarded licences to explore for hydrocarbons off shore the islands. Of the 19 tranches offered, consortiums concentrated their interest in twelve of them, all to the north of the islands, while no bids were made for the other seven to the south. All the company consortiums which participated in the original July 1996 oil round were allocated tranches with the only exception of YPF/British Gas. In the first five years stage of the oil industry development in the islands activity will be concentrated in compiling further and improved information on the allocated basins and the drilling of at least one exploratory well. What follows is how the licences were awarded and their tranches which add upto 12.800 square kilometres, the equivalent of approximately 58 North Sea blocks. TRANCHE A AMERADA HESS Ltd. (Operator). United Kingdom company who own 25% of the consortium. FINA Exploration Atlantic BV. Italian company formed in the 1920's as Petro Fina. Own another 25% of the consortium. MURPHY SOUTH ATLANTIC OIL CO. Canadian company. With experience in Venezuela.Another 25% interest in the consortium. TEIKOKU OIL Co. Japanese, 50% funded by the Japanese government. Have a 20% interest in the consortium. ARGOS/EVERGREEN. Falklands/USA consortium which have a 5% in the consortium. Evergreen work mosly in the Gulf of Mexico. Argos has 20 Falklands/Malvinas shareholders, most of which have invested � 1.000 and are members of the Butler/King families as Argos is a local fishing company with Laurie Butler and Desmond King as the Directors. It is believed the Argos company has a � 300.000 participation in the Argos/Evergreen consortium. TRANCHE B SHELL EXPLORATION BV (Operator). Royal Dutch/British company. Could operate with the Argentine Shell subsidiary. AGIP EXPLORATION BV. Italian company which has undertaken considerable onshore work in noted difficult areas. TRANCHE C & D LASMO INTERNATIONAL EXPLORATION Co. (Operator). British company which owns 50% of the consortium. CLYDE EXPRO PLC. British compay which holds 25% interest in the consortium. (Lasmo stands for London & Scottish Marine Oil and was founded in 1971) DESIRE PRETROLEUM Ltd. U.K. registered company with a 25% interest in the consortium. Desire has 100 shareholders from the islands with an approximate investment of � 200.000, and Sir Rex Hunt, a former Governor as the President of the company. TRANCHE F IPC SANDS ERITREA Ltd. (Operator). Registered in Canada, Chairman is Swedish and has offices in Dubai, UAE. (International Petroleum Corporation). SATELLITE EXPLORATION AKTIEBOLAG.- Satellite company of IPC and registered in London. TRANCHES I & L DESIRE PETROLEUM Ltd. (Operator). Registered in the United Kingdom. CONFERENCE IN SALTA RECOMMENDS LIFTING TRAVELL BAN TO ARGENTINES With a consensus recommendation for the normalisation of links between Falklands/Malvinas and Argentina, and an end to the ban on Argentine passports, which the islands' government strongly upholds, concluded the VI Argentine-British Conference, (ABC), which took place in Salta, in the north of Argentina during the last week of October. The ABC meeting, a non government organization created for the improvement of understanding between both countries, had a numerous and distinguished participation. The Argentine delegation was headed by Senator Eduardo Menem while the British included several members of Parliament and influential personalities of politics, business and finance, and academics. With the British delegation came three islanders which were in constant demand and became the central figures of the meeting: Lewis Clifton and Terry Betts, both former Councillors and now in the fishing and oil business, and journalist Graham Bound, founder of the Penguin News and actually Director of the BBC "Calling the Falklands" program. "It's only natural that discussions should turn on to the Falklands/Malvinas issue since this is the one remaining problem in the framework of exellent relations British-Argentine relations", said Barney Miller member of the committee responsible for the organisation of the events. Surprisingly, considering his "hard line" approach contrary to the present "seduction" policy of Foreign Secretary Guido Di Tella, Senator Eduardo Menem admitted feeling he has friends in the islands and in gentle terms said that "it is most important that contacts are made at a cultural, academic and even sporting level, because that is the only way people can really get to know each other". DIFFERENCES OVER LOCATION FOR THE ANTARTIC TREATY SECRETARIAT Britain and Argentina have differences over the location for the new headquarters or permanent Secretariat for the Antartic Treaty Organisation. Member states, which include Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Britain among others have agreed that a central Secretariat is necessary if the organisation is to continue to be effectively managed as well as to coordinate the enriching multilateral scientific research. Saying that they have the support of the majority of the other signatory nations, Argentina has moved quickly to claim such honour for Buenos Aires. But Britain does not agree with Argentina. According to a senior British Foreign Office source, the British believe that the Secretariat should not be located in any of three nations that have disputed claims on the icy continent. These countries with overlapping interests are Argentina, Chile and Britain, but all have agreed to suspend the claims as long as the treaty survives. Unofficially the British believe that Argentina wants to host the Treaty headquarters because this would add prestige to the country's "Antartic condition". Montevideo has been suggested as an appropiate and suitable compromise home for the organisation, but it is believed Buenos Aires would not back the idea if formally proposed. But it was a British delegate Professor from the University of London, Victor Bulmer-Thomas who was really critical of the islanders and said that " British/Argentine relations are being held hostage by 2.000 islanders". British Labour MP Ton Dalyell anticipated that if his party wins the coming elections the next Labour government: "will be less tolerant and will bring pressure on islanders to commence normal relations with Argentina". But the islanders even outnumbered, and moderate compared to the hard-liners back in the islands, reminded the delegations that Argentines with passports of other countries can now visit the islands and visits by families of Argentines killed in the war are welcomed. Furthermore, islanders are regularly meeting to discuss issues of mutual interest such as oil and fisheries with their Argentine counterparts. Reactions from the islands didn't have to wait. Councillors Bill Luxton and Eric Goss said that so long as Argentina does not drop its sovereignty claims over the islands, "we've nothing to talk about". "These are the only sanctions we can apply on them and we know it hurts them"... insisted Luxton. The ABC also decided to leave for further discussions a private non-official paper by businessman Alastair Forsyth which proposes that Britain and Argentina work together to establish and mantain an eventual independence and special role for the islands in Mercosur. Some concrete plans which emerged from the conference include linking schools in Britain, the islands and Patagonia through Internet; seeking funds for joint scientific projects and introducing in Argentina a British scheme for funding businesses owned and run by unemployed and deprived young people which has beeen very successfull in Britain. MIKE SUMMERS ELECTED LEGISLATIVE COUNCILLOR Mike Summers formally joined the Legislative Council of the islands after winning by a clear majority in the Stanley by election held on October 17th. The election was convened to replace the unexpected death of Conuncillor John Cheek, who was considered one of the outstanding political leaders of the islands. Michael Summers, 44, has a BA degree in Business Studies, a long experience in the private and public sectors where until a few months ago he held the post of General Manager of the Falkland Islands Development Corporation. He was decisive in helping to establish the air jet link with Chile and presently works as a private consultant. He is a supporter of the present Council's policy regarding Argentine nationals visiting the islands, accepting they come under passports of alternative countries. He favours allowing a limited number of Argentine journalists to help in communicating the real facts about the islands. In his political manifesto Summers emphasized in the need for government long term planning concerning capital investments and targets, so "that the oil industry does not end dictating terms to us". Summers also proposed new legislation which makes it compulsory for elected members and high officials of government to declare their interests, in closed envelopes and only for the Governor's eyes, as a way of avoiding possible clash of interests. Concerning the recent allocation of oil licences and the absence of YPF/British Gas, Summers said the "concerns of expression are misplaced. I think people who are entitled to be concerned about their failure to get a licence are their shareholders. If I was a shareholder of either of those companies I think I would be very cross with the failure to properly approach the issue. It serves them right for relying on a nod and a wink fro their ministers". Summers also thanked the citizens who participated in the Salta conference and expressed he is a supporter of taking every possible advantage in strongly explaining the islands position to others, "who otherwise will make up their own minds". Finally concerning fisheries, Summers underlined the need to abide by the international regulations recently agreed in the UN for high seas fishing and conservation beyond the 200 miles zone. However the new Councillor also pointed out that "we must be careful that we don't disadvantage those vessels that are flagged in the Falklands and stop them from fishing when every other vessel in the world are fishing stocks that otherwise would have been taken, had they not chosen to transfer to our flag and connect their futures to our fishery". (MP).- Britishinvestments in Argentina will reach 2,2 billion US dollars by theend of the century according to a report by the British Chamberof Commerce (BCC), in Buenos Aires and the private Foundation"Invertir". The announcement was made public a few daysbefore the arrival of an important British business delegation, headedby Anthony Nelson Minister of Industry and with representativesof fourteen top line companies such as British Gas, BritishAerospace, Lloyds Bank, BZW and National Power. Nelson in London said trade betweenArgentina and UK "was in good shape, our exports havegrown 19% so far this year", and added that investmentprospects in Argentina for British industry are excellentparticularly in "waterworks, gas, electricity andinfrastructure". The areas which have most attracted Britishinvestments according to the BCC report are energy, with the announcedone billion dollars operation of Shell Oil; another 231 millionUS dollars invested by British Gas in the acquisition of 41% ofMetrogas, 100% of an oil field in lindero de Piedra and 45% ofthe Dock Sud power plant. Another important area is the food industrywhere Cadbury, Unilever and British Tobacco have invested almost 200million US dollars. Other investments include Lloyd's Bank, 17million US dollars; Glaxo 27 million in a new antibioticslaboratory, British Tire & Rubber 20 million. The delegation with Anthony Nelson isscheduled for November 26the and will be arriving just a few daysafter another numerous delegation from the Commerce and IndustryChamber of Birmingham left Argentina. (MP).- Innot a too distant future Argentine and Brazilian troops could beoperating under an only joint command since both countries do notconsider each other "conflict hypothesis" andnow have common strategic targets. "Economic integration willnecessarily lead to a defence integration and the first steps areself evident", said Argentine Foreign UnderSecretaryAndr�s Cisneros, following Brazil's official announcement of anew defence policy which will be geared to the protection of theAmazon, and to combat the drug trade. For the first time since the end of theTriple Alliance war against Paraguay, in the second half of lastcentury, Argentine and Brazilian troops participated duringOctober in the "Southern Cross" joint militaryexercises in the province of Corrientes to the north ofArgentina. For years now Argentine Navy jets take offand land from the Brazilian aircraft carrier "MinasGerais", since the "25 de Mayo" hasbeen practically out of action since 1982. "After a century and a half ofindependence, our identity is not based on underliningdifferences but common grounds; regional integration is abovenationalism", said Andr�s Cisneros. "There are practically nodifferences between the Brazilian and Argentine defence policies". WT01-B08-39IA062-000352-B045-57http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni3211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201648 text/html 3091HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:09:35 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 2920Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:39:05 GMT Mercosur News 3 Mercosur News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 Brazil Under Pressure FromInvestors And Local Exporters SAO PAULO. (MP).- Stronglobbying from Sao Paulo's exporters and equally strong demandsfor a quicker opening of the Brazilian market from foreigninvestors and bankers, have forced the government of Mercosur's mainmember into a defensive situation. The recent municipal elections where therewas a clear advance of the opposition parties particularly in Sao Paulo,Rio do Janeiro, Belo Horizonte and Porto Alegre, the mainBrazilian cities, surprised President Henrique Cardoso who wasconvinced his successful stabilisation economic program wouldensure a swift approval in Congress of his reelection plans. The fact is that the mayor of Sao PauloPablo Maluf managed to retain control over the most importantcity of Brazil turning him at the same time into a formidablepresidential candidate for 1998. Maluf has the support of localindustry and exporters, who are demanding a more flexibleexchange rate and tariff protection. The industrialists' demand has beensupported by recent statistics which indicate Brazil will have arecord trade deficit in 1996 which could increase next year. Atrade deficit which nevertheless has helped Mercosur tradepartners to overcome recession: 30% and 45% of Argentine andUruguayan exports are absorbed by the Brazilian market. WT01-B08-40IA062-000352-B045-85http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni4211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201719 text/html 3715HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:10:14 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 3544Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:39:20 GMT Mercosur News 4 Mercosur News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 Businessmen AgainstBolivian Membership Of Mercosur LA PAZ. (MP).-Businessmen from Argentina and Bolivia are complaining aboutMercosur in spite of the fact that Argentine President CarlosMenem in his official visit to Bolivia, signed 18 agreements toincrease trade between both countries and ensure Bolivia'aintegration next January to Mercosur. Argentine businessmen argue that Boliviawill become a disloyal competitor if the country joins Mercosurwith a list of 1.200 protected goods. Bolivians on the other hand complain thatMercosur negotiators treat them "as if we were Asiantigers when we're only the poorest country of the area". The Bolivian list of exceptions protects1.200 sensible and ultra sensible products, "but thatumbrella could also become the gateway for many industrial goodsmanufactured in third countries", warns the Argentine IndustryUnion. Bolivian insist they have a right to beconsidered a "less developed country" andwould rather postpone until next April integration to Mercosur. Bolivia is expected to join Mercosur nextJanuary on a similar "4 plus 1" Chileanassociation, but still has to convince Brazil of the long list ofexceptions which will have a special tariff protection. Menem promised his Bolivian counterpart,S�nchez de Losada strong lobbying in the Mercosur coming discussionswith Brazil, and in exchange Bolivia will include Argentina inits mega project to sell natural gas to Brazil. Another thorny issue of theArgentin-Bolivian discussions was the illegal presence of over amillion Bolivians in Argentina, many of whom are discriminatedand exploited because they have no legal documents, while Argentinacomplains they distort the local employment market. (MP).- Thesecond round of negotiations of Mercosur with the Andeancountries, (Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Per� and Venezuela) tocreate a free trade zone between the two blocks, ended with no progressreported. This means that the original idea ofsigning a framework agreement next December in Brazil, during the Mercosurpresidential summit will have to wait. The delegations did agreeto continue discussions in Lima next February. During the first round of negotiations alsoheld in Montevideo, the Andean countries were discussing on an individual"four plus one" basis, but this last time iswas agreed it should be on a block to block basis. Bolivia was left out of the new approachsince negotiations, as those with Chile, had been going on for along time and were close to an agreement. Differences arose when both sides presentedtheir own draft of a framework agreement, and the Andean groupinsisted on a considerable list of products to be exempted, aswell as a timetable for cutting tariffs considered too slow byMercosur. "They came with high expectationsand not enough reality", said a member of the Mercosurdelegation. In spite of the no progress situation,trade between the two blocks is growing: Andean countries exportsto Mercosur reached 2,5 billion US dollars in 1995; 1,27 billionin 1994; 930 million in 1993 and 861 million in 1992. Mercosurcountries on the other hand exported 3,34 billion US dollars in1995; 2,7 billion in '94; 2,5 billion in '93 and 2,28 billion in1992. WT01-B08-42IA062-000352-B045-138http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni6211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201809 text/html 4081HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:11:07 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 3910Last-modified: Wed, 11 Dec 1996 04:39:52 GMT Mercosur News 6 Mercosur News Mercopress Agency 21/11/96 Mexico, After A Closer Relation With Mercosur BUENOS AIRES. (MP).-Mexico wishes to have a closer bilateral economic relation withArgentina and in the near future a possible "four plusone" association agreement with Mercosur, leading toblock to block links with NAFTA (North American Free TradeAssociation). Ernesto Zedillo the Mexican President, madethese remarks during his three days visit to Argentina following hisparticipation in the Iberoamerican summit held in Santiago deChile. "We favour an approximation ofMexico to Mercosur since this would help to open markets andincrease trade which is to the benefit of all countries involved",said Zedillo during the signing with Argentine President CarlosMenem of a bilateral Investments Protection and GuarantyAgreement. President Menem said Argentina would commitits support for a closer relation of Mexico with Mercosur and a possiblefuture association similar to that of Chile, who recentlyincorporated to the South American block. But in spite of Menem's optimism, UruguayanPresident Julio Mar�a Sanguinetti said it would be "difficult"to liberalise trade between Mexico and Mercosur. "It's a difficult issue sinceMercosur already has a complex trade structure, Mexico has itscommitment with NAFTA (United States and Canada), and it will behard to make progress", indicated Sanguinetti. Chile's Mercosur incorporation which becameeffective last October took well over two years of endless negotiationsand in spite of a gradual drop in tariffs, Chilean farmers havealready successfully appealed in Court against the import ofagricultural commodities, mainly beef. Mexico has bilateral agreements with allMercosur countries and would like to turn them into an only 4plus 1 agreement. Mexico which has invested almost a billionUS dollars in Argentina, (cement, steel, banking, textiles), istrying since the "tequila" crisis two yearsago, to increase trade and diminish its dependency of the UnitedStates which absorbs 75% of its exports. WT01-B08-43IA062-000352-B045-168http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni031196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115201830 text/html 12543HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:11:30 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 12371Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:29:31 GMT Mercosur news Mercopress Agency 3/11/96 CHILEAN CATTLE BREEDERS BLOCK BEEF IMPORTS SANTIAGO. The Chilean Appeals Court ruled favourably a demand from local cattle farmers virtually blocking the import of beef from Mercosur countries mainly Argentina. Chilean cattle breeders have openly opposed Chile's association with Mercosur arguing that imports of agricultural commodities from these countries would ruin farmers. The judicial decision, only once month after Chile's association to Mercosur, came as a shock to Argentine exporters who so far this year have sold 75 million US dollars of beef to Chile and were rapidly becoming a dominant force in the local market. Chilean farmers claim that the Argentine beef does not comply with local typification regulations and is below quality standards. Argentina described the decision as "inadmissable" in commercial terms, and said Chilean cattle farmers were complaining simply because they can't compete with Argentine beef, which has lower costs and higher quality. "Chilean supermarkets and consumers only have praise for Argentine beef which so far has captured 30% of the top market", said Felipe Sol�, the Argentine Agriculture Minister. The appeal was filed against the Chilean government by the ultraconservative National Agricultural Society (SNA), which has a strong backing in the Chilean Congressional opposition. Although President Frei's administration can appeal to the Chilean Supreme Court, the ruling can block beef trade for weeks upsetting Mercosur partners. In spite of the fact that the Frei administration has promised farmers 500 millions US dollars in compensation funds over several years, which was part of the deal for the Chilean Senate to vote the association agreement, the SNA has consistently rejected Mercosur and has also self excluded itself from all the main agricultural shows. According to SNA officials Mercosur beef imports so far this year have caused losses of over 100 US million dollars because of the drop in cattle and land prices. CONTROVERSY OVER THE "EFFICIENCY" OF MERCOSUR WASHINGTON. A continental controversy literally exploded when a report by one of the main economists of the World Bank described Mercosur as "an artificial world of growth, where inefficient industries prosper behind a wall of trade barriers". The first critical report was followed by a second praising Mercosur as a "positive and important initiative similar to the first steps given by the Common Market", and letters of apologies to officials of the 4 plus one block. But far from discrediting Mercosur, the reports revealed a strong struggle inside the World Bank where experts and economists seem to be divided concerning trade block policies. On the one side are the fundamentalists who preach complete free market and private enterprise, and elimination of trade tariffs to all commercial partners, while on the other are those who believe that economic block associations can be moderately inefficient but compensate as the market consolidates, gains in credibility and reduces risks to foreign investments. Besides the first report was leaked when the World Bank officially recommended foreign investors to consider "Mercosur a serious option", and also revealed that in the last five years the multirateral institution has loaned 32 billion US dollars to Latinamerica. To make things worse the World Bank as part of a decentralization program has moved its Mexican Department to Mexico City and is planning something similar with Brazil, one of the main clients of the bank. Nevertheless the fundamentalists received some help since their critical report was almost simultaneous with an official claim before the World Trade Organization from the United States and Japan, against Brazil and Argentina for their closed automovile industry regimes. The controversy which happened to take the Mercosur block as an example is expected to be one of the main issues of the December meeting of the World Trade Organization to be held in Singapur. Meantime for the World Bank, "in the context of growing regional globalization, Mercosur promises with time, to improve competitivity and therefore is still considered a positive and important initiative". BRAZIL DEPENDENCY FLORIANOPOLIS. The lack of an "active industrial policy" and the risks of the "Brazil dependency" have become the main topics of debate between the Argentine government and certain industries who feel they are rapidly loosing ground to a more aggresive and pragmatic Brazilian trade partner. The first shots were fired by one of the main industrial tycoons of Argentina with important interests in automovile manufacturing. "We are running the risk of becoming a Brazilian province, not necessarily because that is the aim of our northern neighbours but because we lack an active industrial policy", said Francisco Macri who assembles Fiat and Peugeot in Argentina. The Argentine administration immediately replied with statistics of industrial exports which have more than doubled during the last twelve months. But in spite of the controversy trade between Argentina and Brazil in the framework of Mercosur, is booming with record Argentine oil and agrobusiness exports, while Brazilians are effectively taking the upper hand of the market in several industries. Analysts also point towards the vulnerable political moments the two main Mercosur partners are going through: Argentina is still suffering the consequences of a severe recession and unemployment, and the Brazilian government is under pressure from strong local industrial protectionist groups which are showing their muscle just when President Henrique Cardoso is discussing with Congress a constitutional reform which should open the door for his reelection and the continuity of the present economic development program. MEXICO AND MERCOSUR DRAFTING AN ASSOCIATION AGREEMENT MEXICO. Mexico in the mid term will be discussing a block association agreement which will substitute the bilateral treaties with the four full members of Mercosur. Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo made the announcement during the official dinner to host Uruguayan president Julio Mar�a Sanguinetti who is visiting Mexico with a numerous business delegation. "Even if we have our main frame agreement which is Nafta, we are also determined to have a flexible trade relation with the Mercosur block which has made an impressive progress in recent years", remarked Zedillo. Both Mexico and the Mercosur countries are limited in their possibilities of further regional understandings unless all members agree. So far Mercosur has a main block of countries with a basic common external tariff, Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay; a 4 to 1 association with Chile and next December in Fortaleza during the regular biannual presidential summit, Boliva and Venezuela are expected to sign association agreements. EUROPEAN UNION SURPRISED AT "MERCOSUR'S SUCCESS" BUENOS AIRES. Mercosur's rapid success has surprised the European Union and the South American integration process reminds us of "our own continental genesis", according to the president of the Latinamerican Committee of the European Parliament. Spanish representative Gerardo Galeote, on a short visit to Argentina and Brazil, remarked that Europe was most interested in the political aspects of the Mercosur association and in promoting trade in certain areas such as fisheries. "Our European experience indicates that in an integration process unless you have a common political background, a joint foreign affaris expression, and a direct link with the citizenship, progress will be limited", said Galeote. The European representative also indicated that Mercosur has better prospects than Nafta (North American Trade Agreement) since Mexico is suffering serious financial and political difficulties. Finally Galeote underlined that in spite of the fact that Europe has become the main economic block of the world and is working towards a common currency and Central Bank, "we're advancing according to our interests and not as rivals of the United States". width="100"><font face="Arial">1957</font></td> <td align="right" valign="bottom" width="20">&nbsp;</td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">1980</font></td> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">1813</font></td> <td valign="bottom" width="20"><font face="Arial">�+</font></td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">1986</font></td> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">1916</font></td> <td valign="bottom" width="20"><font face="Arial">�+</font></td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">1991</font></td> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">2091</font></td> <td valign="bottom" width="20"><font face="Arial">�+</font></td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">1996</font></td> <td align="center" valign="bottom" width="100"><font face="Arial">2564</font></td> <td valign="bottom" width="20"><font face="Arial">�++</font></td> </tr> </table> </center></div><p><font face="Arial">* Estimado</font></p> <p><font face="Arial">+ Desde 1980 a 1996 los datos del Censo excluyen aquellas personas abordo de barcos; los datos del censo de 1986 y 1991 tambi�n excluyen aquellas personas en servicio en las Falklands/Malvinas en relaci�n con la base militar. Los datos de 1991 y 1996 no incluyen las personas que est�n presentes en forma temporal (1991 = 90; 1996=38), o el n�mero estimados de personas que est�n ausentes en forma temporal (1991 = 119; 1996= 140).</font></p> <p><font face="Arial">++ Los datos de 1996 incluyen 483 personas presentes en FalKlands/Malvinas en relaci�n con la base militar , pero excluyen todo personal militar.</font></p> <hr> Censo (24 Abril 1996)</font></p> <p><font face="Arial"><strong>Notas</strong> :</font></p> <ol> <li><font face="Arial">Estos datos fueron extraidos del Registro de Nacimiento, pero los nacimientos fueron contabilizados el a�o de nacimiento y no el a�o en el cual se registr�.</font></li> <li><font face="Arial">Debido al m�todo empleado (nota 1) los datos no se correlacionan en todos los casos con los datos mostrados en la tabla 5 del censo de 1986. Por ejemplo, un nacimiento del 21/02/82 no fue registrado hasta el 13/02/84.</font></li> <li><font face="Arial">Debe notarse que los datos no incluyen los nacimientos cuyas madres fueron hospitalizadas en el continente por razones m�dicas.</font></li> </ol> <hr> <p><a href="censo.html" target="_top"><img src="images/atras.gif" align="middle" border="0" width="50" columna de &quot;No-Locales&quot; incluyen las muertes del personal de servicio, marinos, y contratistas en las islas Falklands/Malvinas. El alto n�mero de &quot;No-Locales&quot; en el a�o 1993 incluye a 16 marinos que fallecieron en el hundimiento del &quot;SeraKunda III&quot;, y dos mujeres del personal del servicio.</font></li> : </strong>Dos personas omitieron su edad, por lo tanto no fueron incluidos en la tablas.</font></p> <hr> <p><a href="censo.html" target="_top"><img src="images/atras.gif" align="middle" border="0" width="12%" height="16"><font color="#000000" size="2" face="Arial">0</font></td> <td align="center" width="12%" bgcolor="#FFFF00" height="16"><font color="#000000" size="2"
