20:18:48 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 18642Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 15:37:55 GMT Falklands / Malvinas News Mercopress Agency 14/10/96 FALKLANDS / MALVINAS POPULATION GROWING IN NUMBER AND PROSPERITY Census 1996 Population in the Falkland / Malvinas Islands stands at its highest ever: 2.564 residents, and so does prosperity: 1.364 registered vehicles, 1,5 for each household, 779 televisions; 751 video cassette recorders; 257 computers and 734 washing machines. But the recently published figures of the April '96 census also show imbalances between the population living in Port Stanley and the Camp, as well as significant social changes. While the number of residents in the capital has jumped 63% since 1982, and is now 1,638, the Camp in just ten years lost 208 inhabitants and stands in 445 people. The collapse of wool farming, the strong fishing industry and civil service, plus lately the prospects of oil have attracted many camp residents to Port Stanley looking for better payed jobs and causing at the same time a housing shortage. Since the declaration of a 200 miles exclusive fishing zone round the islands in 1985, the economy of the Falkland / malvinas has not ceased to grow, and the shortage of manpower to keep up with government development contracts has become more evident. The previous record-high population was in 1931, with 2,392 inhabitants, while the lowest statistics correspond to the late seventies and 1980 with a century low record of just 1.813. Another interesting fact is that the Falklands / Malvinas have lately received a steady inflow of inmigrants reversing the tendency previous to the war, when local girls would marry Britsh Royal Marines deployed in the islands and emigrate to Great Britain. This also caused a serious imbalance between the male and female population (2-1), which is now almost normal (1-1). The 1996 census does not include the British military garrison in Mount Pleasant estimated in 2.000 strong, but does include 253 natives from the island of St. Helena generally employed in the base. ARGENTINA'S NEW POSITION ON FISHERIES CONCERNS ISLANDERS To the concern of Falkland / Malvinas islanders and British officials, Argentine Foreign Secretary Di Tella delivered in the United Nations Assembly a hardline message on fishing in the South Atlantic which raised the stakes dramatically. Argentina's new position on a long term fishing agreement ruined any hopes of an early solution by insisting that any understanding must cover the maritime zones, not only of the Falklands / Malvinas, but of South Georgia as well. The issues are "indivisible", and "if we do not reach an agreement over fishing in the Falkland / malvinas and the Georgias, then there is no agreement", remarked Di Tella. Britain controversially controls the South Georgia fishery also, but sees no connection between the two groups of islands and rejects the new Argentine stance. Since the Falklands / Malvinas economy depends almost totally on fishing, mainly squid, which migrates in the South Atlantic between waters of the two countries, the new Argentine policy entails risks for the islands annual income from licences. Both countries recognise that they need a long-term agreement if the stock is not to be over-exploited, but an agreement now seems further away than ever. Di Tella has also said he intends to raise the issue of fishing in South Georgia at the next meeting of CAMELAR (Convention on Antartic Maritime Resources) in Australia. Both Argentina and Chile have protested Britain's decision to licence fishing in South Georgia waters. MERCOSUR MAP INCLUDES FALKLANDS / MALVINAS The first regional map of the Mercosur block chartered and printed by the Uruguayan Military Geographical Service (MGS) and which was just made official includes the Falkland / Malvinas Islands. Following instructions from the Foreign Affairs Offices of the four country members, the islands figure as Argentine territory. "The map reflects the international policy of Uruguay and of the regional block, that is, the four member countries of Mercosur are convinced the islands are Argentine", explained Cnel. Daniel de los Santos head of the Uruguayan MGS. The map is part of a cartographic project contracted by Latinamerican countries which also includes Mercosur. The presentation of the official Mercosur map was done during a ceremony attended by Uruguayan President Julio Maria Sanguinetti. OZONE RED ALERT The full impact of the thining of the ozone layer this year anticipated a month its appearance in the South Atlantic with very dangerous consequences for human beings exposed to the burning sun rays. The readings in Dobson units, which is the Ultra Violet index, reached a record-low in Punta Arenas and the Falklands / Malvinas, where the government immediately put on a red alert. But for some yet unknown reason the Argentines, who had also anticipated the phenomenom from the Marambio base in the Antarctic, firstly reacted by not releasing the information. A normal Dobson reading is 300, but anything below 220 is considered dangerous, sun exposure must be minimum and special protection for skin and eyes is needed. Readings in Punta Arenas in mid September were below the 220 Dobson units mark. See the full size map THREE CANDIDATES CONTEST VACANT SEAT ON LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL Finally three candidates from Stanley will contest on October 17th., the vacant seat on the Falklands / Malvinas Legislative Council following the death in early September of Councillor John Cheek, possibly the most prominent of local politicians. The candidates include a young Islander, who has a Chilean father and is back in the islands after seven years in the British Army; a female ex-patriate clerical worker in the Post Office and the former General Manager of the Falklands / Malvinas Islands Development Corporation. In their manifesto the three candidates reject any sovereignty talks with Argentina, claim the right to self determination of the islanders but admit "realistic" discussions concerning oil and fish. Elvio Miguel Cofre, 29, who emigrated to the United Kingdom in 1978 and now is a Government Housing Officer is possibly the most bold of all candidates. Cofre believes Councillors must seize every possible opportunity to impress upon Argentines their political views and the right to self determination, but also favours a relaxing of regulations concerning visits from Argentine born citizens. "This needs to be solved in my lifetime and not left to our children; we need a more inter-generation balanced judgement", insists Cofre. June Beasley-Clarke, 50, is married to a former Royal Marine who runs a photo shop in the islands. Mother of five, June is a fervent defender of the islands' life style, (where she's now back for a second time), and feels she could make a contribution to the community and the Council. "I don't want the islands turned into a miniature Great Britain, we have our own way of life and traditions", says June. The candidate with the highest profile in Michael Summers, 44, a sixth generation islander, presently a private consultant with a long experience abroad and in government. Summers besides backing the official Council policy concerning links with Argentina favours rural development, promotion of the private sector and above all long term planning to make sure the islands keep their economic and political initiative in the coming years, and are not surprised by events. The great absentee of the by-election will be Jane, widow of the late John Cheek, favoured to complete her husband's mandate but barred from participating because of a "technicallity" in her nomination form. AGENDA FOR ARGENTINE-BRITISH CONFERENCE IN SALTA CONFIRMED An influential group of British and Argentine politicians, academics and businessmen, plus several Islanders, will meet later this month in Salta, Argentina, for a conference which is expected to concentrate mostly on the disputed Falklands / Malvinas Islands. The Argentine-British Conference's regular meetings have helped improve diplomatic and trade relations between both countries following the South Atlantic conflict. However on this occasion the Falklands / Malvinas' dispute will figure prominently in the agenda, not because of an incoming incident, but because the excellent trade and diplomatic relations, have left the islands as the one remaining problem issue. Among the British personalities figure Jacques Arnold MP, Sir Kenneth Carlisle MP, Alastair Forsyth, Baroness Hooper, Andrew Graham Yooll, Viscount Montgomery of Alamein, John Bueno of British Gas. The Argentine delegation includes Senator Eduardo Menem, Ambassador Carlos Manuel Muniz, former Minister of Foreign Affairs Juan R. Aguirre Linari, Julio Macchi, president of the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange, businessman Santiago Soldati, Carlos Bulgheroni president of Bridas Oil Co. and the Argentine-Europe Club. The three islanders delegation includes Terry Betts, a local businessman, Lewis Clifton, Director of Desire Petroleum, and Graham Bound, who will be replacing Robin Lee. Another big absence will be Tony Lloyd, MP, Labour spokesman for Latinamerican affairs. LABOUR MP APPEALS FOR SOVEREIGNTY TALKS A Labour government should immediately resume talks with Argentina over sovereignty in the Falklands /Malvinas with the purpose of achieving a long term agreement according to one of the socialist MP back benches. Tom Dalyell who has been a member of Parliament since 1962 and will be running for office once again in Linlithgow, Scotland insisted that the sooner an agreement on sovereignty is reached, "the better for all sides". Dalyell remarks have a special impact since it is almost certain that in 1997 Great Britain will be ruled by the Labour Party. Nevertheless in the last Labour Party Conference held in Blackpool members of Labour including Tony Blair, who will probably be the next Prime Minister, personally promised a delegation of islanders headed by two Councillors, that the wishes of the Falklander / Malvinases will be respected based on the right to self determination. Anyhow Dalyell who shared lunch with Argentine Ambassador Rogelio Pfirter in London, believes that for several reasons it is essential for the islanders to have a constructive attitude towards an approachment with Argentine officials. It is most difficult that the 1982 circumstances will repeat themselves when Mrs. Thatcher and Mr. Reagan had such a close and common relation, nor will British public opinion respond with the same enthusiasm. On the other hand if oil is found off-shore the islands the only way to extract it is with Argentine assistance. Finally Argentina's commitment to respect the rights, traditions and way of life of the islanders, is probably the most which can be expected in any future sovereignty agreement Issue 06/09/96 Back WT01-B08-62IA062-000352-B048-37http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni141096.html 207.32.88.17 19970115202619 text/html 5129HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:19:16 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 4958Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:30:20 GMT Mercosur News Mercopress Agency 14/10/96 BRAZIL AND ARGENTINA AT ODDS OVER OIL AND EXPORT INCENTIVES The ongoing trade disputes between Mercosur's two main members have erupted again, this time over oil deregulation and export and investment incentives. Argentina forced by its business community is complaining that the Brazilian oil market, contrary to what has happened in Argentina where the market has been completelly deregulated, continues restricted and dominated by Petrobras, and is still waiting for Congress to consider a "flexibilisation" bill. The other area of dispute is the package of incentives to promote exports, (almost a billion dollars in soft loans and reimboursment of taxes) which the Brazilian federal government recently decided in an attempt to diminish the balance of trade deficit. Similarly many of the Brazilian states have their own fiscal incentives to attract foreign investments in the steel, cheminal and paper industries, which offset Argentina's hopes for industrial development. The Brazilian press has been quiet caustic about the whole situation saying that "Argentina wants Brazil to solve its self made economic problems. Our endemic trade deficit with Argentina only helps to finance Argentine purchases in the US", said a leading Brazilian industrialist in the main business publication of Sao Paulo. A SPECIAL MERCOSUR COURT FOR TRADE AND CUSTOMS DISPUTES Members of the Supreme Courts of Argentina, Uruguay, Chile and Paraguay have decided the creation of a supranational Court for Mercosur trade, commercial, customs and diplomatic disputes. The resolution was taken in spite of the opposition of the Brazilian judicial delegation which considers the special Court "costly and unnecessary". The special Court will have its seat in Asuncion, Paraguay and will be the first step towards the unification of the regional community legal systems. "It's still too early to think about a special supra-national Court, at least until we have considered and passed an appropiate and efficient community legislation, which should benefit all country members and associates", said Nelson Jobim, the Brazilian Minister of Justice. Before the Special Court comes into existance, the legislative branch of the five countries involved must render its approval. Issue 06/09/96 back WT01-B08-63IA062-000352-B048-56http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sne.html 207.32.88.17 19970115202634 text/html 6085HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:19:35 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 5914Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:26:46 GMT Noticias de Mercosur Texto Completo Noticias del Mercosur Agencia Mercopress 1/1/97 LA CRUZ DEL SUR, SIMBOLO DEL MERCOSUR FORTALEZA. (MP).- El esp�ritu de integraci�n no solo se limita a la esfera gubernamental o empresarial: los sindicatos de los seis pa�ses del Mercosur tiene una comisi�n de coordinaci�n supranacional y coincidentemente con la cumbre de Fortaleza organizaron un paro regional de varios horas relativamente exitoso. Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 11607Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:23:27 GMT mni0609 SIX MILLION POUNDS TO EXPAND STANLEY The Falkland / Malvinas Islands government will be investing six million pounds in the expansion of the capital Port Stanley. A Scottish company was appointed for the project which includes the building of eighty new homes and the development to the east of Stanley of a network of roads, drainage and sewer systems plus the installation of water and electricity supply. The engineering project is the second most important in the history of the islands. Since the end of the 1982 conflict and the fishing boom, Stanley has suffered a severe shortage of housing which is believed has inhibited the growth of the population. With the prospects of oil the demand for new homes and building plots has increased. Port Stanley at present has approximately 300 houses. A recent population and housing census taken early this year and whose results will be released in the coming weeks, should help to have a more exact picture of the situation THREE ISLANDERS TO VISIT ARGENTINA Three prominent members of the Falklands / Malvinas Islands community will be participating in the coming Argentine-British Conference (ABC) to be held next October in the northern Argentine city of Salta. The three businessmen who anticipated to the Falklands / Malvinas press that they would be participating are Lewis Clifton, a Director of Byron Holdings Ltd. and of Desire Petroleum; Terry Betts of JBG Falklands Ltd. a fishing company and Robin Lee one of the strongest farmers of the islands and co-owner of White Rock Ltd. an important local public works contractor. Although the three of them at one time held office as elected members of the Falklands' Legislative Council, no present Councillors accepted the invitation from ABC, a non government organization which was created to discuss political relations and cultural links between Argentina and Great Britain. The three businessmen from the islands will be going as part of the British delegation which includes several outstanding and influential personalities from London circles with very close links and interests in Argentina. The meeting is officially scheduled for October 25-27 and ABC's host this time will be the Argentine Foreign Relations Council, a non government organisation which sponsors international visits and conferences. This will be the sixth meeting of ABC, the last was held last year in Oxford, England. AIR LINK WITH CHILE DAP the Chilean carrier which has been flying to the Falklands / Malvinas from Punta Arenas since 1991 has been promised additional financial help from the islands' government until March 1997. The sum which has a limit of � 75.000, was decided by the Executive Council to ensure DAP's Boeing 727 connection with Punta Arenas and then onto Santiago to catch regular British Airways flights to London. The Chilean company covers most of the southern tip of South America including Ushuaia in Argentina, with small aircraft such as the Twin Otter (ten seats) which use to fly weekly to Port Stanley. Since January this year DAP began flying twice a week to Mount Pleasant Airport with a Boeing 727 which has a 125 seat capacity, but has had greater than expected difficulties in booking the aircraft in spite of the tempting and attractive fares of the British Airways connection in Santiago. To begin the Boeing 727 shuttle, DAP received an initial financial assistance from the Falklands' government of almost 180.000 US dollars. The Falkland / Malvinas Islands Development Corporation and the Chilean company estimate that the summer tourist turnover, when cruise ships sailing to Antartica change passengers and crews, will prove the project a success. At present DAP has cut the link to a weekly flight and many times is covered by a Twin Otter. The Falklands also has a two times a week connection with Britain, with an only stop in Ascension Island, in the RAF'S Tristars military transport which have a limited capacity for civilians. REX HUNT OPTIMISTIC Desire Petroleum, an oil company based in Britain and with an important participation of Falklands' shareholders has very good chances of obtaining a licence to explore in some of the best off-shore trenches round the islands, according to Rex Hunt who was governor of the Falklands during the 1982 conflict. Rex Hunt who is vicepresident of Desire Petroleum made these comments after it was announced that two important oil companies, from Texas and Norway, would not be joining Desire in the exploration consortium as had been anticipated. Both companies were expected to become the second most important partners in Desire, of which Lasmo International from Scotland holds 50% of the shares. Falklands shareholders have contributed to Desire with over half a million pounds. The Norwegians walked out because they disagreed with Lasmo's plans to drill two wells during the first (five years) stage of the exploration licence. GREENPEACE WARNING ON OIL The environmental group Greenpeace is following closely the off shore oil exploration process round the Falklands and has anticipated it could actively oppose the industry. "We are keeping a close look at the development of the oil industry particularly in frontier areas such as the Falklands which are marginal and involve new sophisticated technologies", remarked Paul Horseman. Horseman heads the British chapter of Greenpeace and was responsible for the successful campaign against the sinking by Shell of the Brent Star oil rig in the north Atlantic. "The Falklands ecosystem has a very rich wild life and the South Atlantic is exposed to some of the strongest winds in the world which makes the risks of oil spills very dangerous", added Horseman. Horseman refused to say if Greenpeace was planning any protests in the Falklands area, but "our merd0ers are ready to jump aboard any moment". In October the government of the Falklands / Malvinas is expected to announce the consortiums which will be licensed to explore for oil and the trenches where operations will begin. COUNCILLOR'S DEATH FORCES BY-ELECTION The death of one of the leading politicians and Councillors of the Falklands / Malvinas, John Cheek, (57), has caused grief and sadness in the islands and will force a by-election in the coming weeks, just one year before the eight members of the Council face a general election. John Cheek a successfull islander who was one of the first to grasp the opportunities of the fishing industry in the Falklands / Malvinas following the 1982 conflict, was first elected to office in 1981 and had become the most influential of all Councillors. Pragmatic in his understanding of relations with Argentina, (he favoured discussions on fisheries and oil), Councillor Cheek nevertheless was decisive in ensuring the publication of a Councillors' document on the future of the Falklands / Malvinas based on the concept of a "secure independence". In 1982 when the Argentine invasion of the islands Cheek, was in Britain and spent the ten weeks of the war broadcasting daily to the Falklands / Malvinas and acting with the then Governor Rex Hunt as a Falklands / Malvinas government in exile. With "Fortuna", the islands' first wholly owned fishing company, John Cheek was also able to show his talent as a businessman which turned him into a wealthy man and leading member of the community. The Governor of islands Richard Ralph described Cheek as "an exceptional Councillor, a Falklands patriot and a worthy son of the islands". Cheek was elected three times as a Councillor and resigned after chairing a government committee in late August, just a few hours before his death caused by a long battle against leukemia. 06/09/96 Issue 06/08/96 Back WT01-B08-70IA062-000352-B049-20http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni0609.html 207.32.88.17 19970115202929 text/html 11971HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:22:20 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 11799Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:29:54 GMT sni0609 IT'S AGRICULTURAL SHOW SEASON August, September are clue months for farming in Mercosur countries. During those two months the most important agricultural and connected industries shows are held in Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, giving a clear idea of the prospects and state of mind of the farming industry. This year the Palermo Show in Argentina could not escape the general recession and concern about the future which lingers over the Argentine economy in spite of the very strong international grain market with direct benefits for local agriculture. Cattle and sheep breeders on the other hand have been conditioned to the negative consequences of the international beef market because of the "mad cow" disease which has plagued Europe, and because of the depression in wool prices. Equally disturbing has been the instability of the weather with extreme peaks out of season, which have caused great losses in the four countries: droughts have been followed by floods and below zero temperatures harming the nutrition capacity of the grasslands. In Paraguay official announcements to help cattle breeders managed to neutralise those consequences, and in Brazil the Show of Esteio in Porto Alegre, the biggest in the country with a turnout of over 4.200 animals, in spite of a government package to promote exports of agricultural commodities, protests and complaints were more spontaneous than applauses. In Palermo, Paraguay and Esteio total sales and prices for the best animals of the show dropped compared to last year's edition. Still missing are the results of the Prado Show in Uruguay, the country which most depends on international prices for agricultural commodities since it exports most of its farming production. Anyhow farmers in Uruguay have been complaining bitterly for the last few years over taxes and interest rates. go to expoprado CHILE INVESTS STRONGLY IN MERCOSUR In spite of the fact that the Mercosur-Chile agreement will not become effective until next October, Chilean foreign investments during the last six years have been directed mainly to Mercosur countries. With a total of 8,634 billion US dollars invested by Chile overseas since 1990, almost five billion, that is 57%, have found their way to Mercosur, according to figures released by the Committee of Foreign Investments which depends from the Chilean Ministry of Economy. Of those five billion, 90% have been invested in Argentina, 7% in Brazil and the rest split among Uruguay and Paraguay. Even if most of Chilean foreign investments so far have ended in neighbouring Argentina, taking advantage of the massive privatisation programme of President Menem, it is no secret that one of Chile's main purposes behind the Mercosur agreement is penetration of the Brazilian market with 150 million consumers. Chile has already invested 340 US million dollars in Brazil and has a participation in projects involving over 1,3 billion US dollars. "A MOST INTERESTING PHENOMENON" Mercosur is one of the most significative phenomenon of the continent and it's interesting to see that decisions concerning this common market are taken with out the influence of Washington said Henry Kissinger, former Secretary of State of the Nixon administration. Asked to comment on the present relations between the United States and Latinamerica, Kissinger indicated that unfortunately President Clinton does not show much interest for the continent. "In four years he hasn't even visited Mexico, but what really concerns me is that no proper attention is given to the Mercosur phenomenon", said Kissinger. For the first time in history according to the international consultant, there is a group of allied countries of which the United States has been excluded. "Presidents of Brazil and Argentina are good friends, but decisions over the future of a region so important for the Western world, are being taken in Buenos Aires and Brasilia, while Washington remains indifferent", insisted Kissinger. Finally Kissinger said it was essential the United States recovered the initiative in the continent and attempted a confluence in an only market of NAFTA (North America Free Trade Association) and Mercosur. OBSTACLES TO TEXTILE TRADE IN BRAZIL Brazil has once again set up obstacles to the import of textiles by unilaterally deciding to reduce the terms of payment for foreign merchandise from 180 to 30 days. When the measure was first enforced last May, Uruguay and Paraguay immediately protested and were joined by Argentina. A month later during the presidential summit of the Mercosur countries held in San Luis, Argentina, Brazil announced it was returning to the 180 days term for textiles from Mercosur partners. In this occasion apparently the Brazilian Central Bank August resolution also includes minimum import prices which violate regulations of the WT0. In Brazil political sources said that the purpose of the measure enforced by the Cardoso administration is to "cool" imports and appease manufacturers from Sao Paulo as well as to help combat the growing trade deficit. DISCUSSIONS WITH THE ANDES BLOCK Mercosur accepted the invitation to discuss on a block to block basis with the Andes Group the possibility of establishing a common market area. The proposal was sent to the four Mercosur countries by the Andes Group office in Cartagena. Special committees from both groups have been commended to prepare the negotiation documents although no dates have yet been arranged for the meetings. "We don't want to precipitate the talks and we will begin by assessing mechanisms and criteria for the negotiation", said Morris Harf, Colombia's Minister of Foreign Trade. Anyhow a first formal meeting has been scheduled to take place in Lima. The country members of the Andes Group are Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Venezuela. CHILE WANTS TO RENEGOTIATE When there are only a few days left for the enforcement of the Mercosur-Chile agreement which was subscribed by the presidents of the five countries involved, but still awaits consideration by the Chilean Senate, officials anticipated the Chilean government will request an extension of the list of goods which can be traded with Mercosur. According to Carlos Mladinic, Director of the International Trade Relations Committee of the Chilean Foreign Office, the request is based on the recent increase of tariffs for 17 goods decided by Brazil and which directly involve Chile.The announcement was made just when the Chilean Senate is beginning to debate the Mercosur agreement which passed with an overwhelming majority in Deputies, but is very much resisted by traditional farmers who have began a public opinion campaign on the issue. Some Chilean businessmen are also concerned that the tariff preferences extended to the Mercosur countries could bring retaliation from other more traditional trade partners of Chile. MERCOSUR WILL REVIEW TARIFFS A delegation of Mercosur will be discussing this month with the World Trade Organisation (WT0) in Geneve the region's trade policies to adapt them to international regulations. This means that some aspects of the Common External Tariff of Mercosur will have to be changed. During one of the last meetings of the Trade Commission of Mercosur held in Brasilia, delegates agreed to a list of products which will have their foreign tariffs reduced to adapt them to the demands of WT0. Another issue which was considered by the Commission was the harmonisation of rules regarding the origin components clause for goods from the four member countries. To abide by the origin clause, goods must have at least 61% of components from the home country. After the WTO sessions in Gerteve, Mercosur officials will be meeting with representatives from India, Japan and the European Union for further trade talks. 06/09/96 Issue 06/08/96 Back WT01-B08-71IA062-000352-B049-53http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/snef.html 207.32.88.17 19970115203020 text/html 10658HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:22:59 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 10486Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:29:03 GMT Noticias del Mercosur Texto Completo Noticias del Mercosur Agencia Mercopress 1/1/97 LACRUZ DEL SUR, SIMBOLO DEL MERCOSUR FORTALEZA. (MP).- Finalmentedespu�s de largas discusiones, una cruz del sur en azul sobreuna l�nea curva verde que representa el horizonte y fondoblanco, fue seleccionada como el s�mbolo oficial del bloqueMercosur y oficialmente inaugurada durante la cumbre presidencialcelebrada en el norte de Brasil el pasado 17 de diciembre. Losdelegados argentinos objetaron el escudo pues sostuvieron que lacruz del sur b�sicamente tiene cuatro estrellas y podr�ainterpretarse como una organizaci�n cerrada a sus cuatromiembros originales (Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay y Uruguay),dejando fuera los nuevos asociados como Chile, y desde mayopr�ximo Bolivia. BOLIVIASE CONVIRTIO EN MIEMBRO ASOCIADO FORTALEZA. (MP).- Bolivia seconvirti� en miembro asociado de Mercosur y la integraci�noficial tendr� lugar el primero de mayo pr�ximo, una vez quelos distintos parlamentos ratifiquen los acuerdos alcanzados enla cumbre presidencial celebrada en la ciudad de Fortaleza.Negociaciones de �ltimo momento abrieron las puertas para unentendimiento que en los d�as previos parec�a dif�cil dealcanzar por las diferencias existentes con Argentina respecto auna larga lista de productos que los bolivianos quer�anprivilegiar con una reducci�n de tarifas a muy largo plazo,entre los cuales los textiles y productos agr�colas. Edici�n 21/11/96 Volver WT01-B08-86IA062-000353-B002-143http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/mni0608.html 207.32.88.17 19970115203811 text/html 6445HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:31:12 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 6274Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:23:13 GMT Falkland - Malvinas news Oil licences in the Falklands/Malvinas The special panel named by the government of the Falklands /Malvinas has began in London the round of interviews with the six consortia who applied for oil licences in the Falklands/Malvinas. The six consortia represent a total of fourteen companies from ten different countries. The panel of five members and their advisers will closely examine details of the bids for ten tranches in the prospective off shore oil fields mostly to the north of the islands. A final report is expected to be drafted by mid September when it will be considered by the Legislative Council in Stanley. Once the Governor adds his signature the report will be sent back to London for final approval by the Foreign Office. The consortia will have to show a sustainable work programme, financial stability, a reliable record and the best commercial package for the islands. Oil companies are expected to begin operating in the Falklands waters by next summer. Paul Newman The actor Paul Newman has donated u$s 40,000 to a charity set up by British Falkland / Malvinas war veteran Simon Weston, Weston, Weston, who was badly burned during an Argentine air attack in 1982, established The Weston Spirit, to perpetuate the spirit of determination that enable him to recover from injuries that left him permanently scarred. Teh charity operates a network of centres where young people from poverty stricken urban areas are helped to pursue studies and careers away from crime. Paul Newman's gift comes from the profits of the star's successful food company. The funds will be used to set up a new youth centre in London's East End. Mewman was not able to be present at the ceremony where his cheque was handed over, but a representative had this message from the star ; "Simon's dedication and commitment to youth provides a very neccesary programme". Newman's own charitable programme has set up the Hole In the Wall Gang Camps in the USA, Ireland and France, where in, disabled and disadvantaged children enjoy activity holidays. Air link Further talks on the improvement of the Falklands/Malvinas - Chile/Britain link are been held in Santiago de Chile . These include the possibility of medical evacuations to Santiago and an increased air freight capacity with the removal of some passenger seats in the Chilean Boeing 727. The air link presently includes a weekly flight PuntaArenas/Stanley/Punta Arenas by the Chilean carrier DAP, in time to meet British Airways in Santiago for the London runs. Chilean vessel The Chilean company owner of the vessel “Antonio Lorenzo” which was fined a total of � 367.000 on July 9th. for illegal fishing in South Georgia waters, has refused to pay and has reported the incident to the Chilean diplomatic authorities. The refusal to pay comes as a result of the Pesquero Concar's S.A. non-recognition of South Georgia's jurisdiction in the 200 mile limit imposed around the islands and the fact that Chile is a member of CAMELAR, an international Conference for the Conservation of Marine Antartic Resources which covers. The case attracted international attention because of the presence as counsel for the prosecution of a Senior Barrister QC, fuelling speculation that the case would derive into a challenge of British sovereignty over South Georgia. This was the second time the “Antonio Lorenzo” faced Court proceedings in Stanley since in 1994 they were fined � 74.000. 7/8/96 Back WT01-B08-87IA062-000353-B002-168http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sni0608.html 207.32.88.17 19970115203822 text/html 5334HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:31:23 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 5163Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:29:41 GMT Mercosur News M. Fernandez Amun�tegui visited Uruguay. Democracy, an open economy and our future tightly knit to Latinamerica are the main elements of Chile's foreign policy", said the Chilean UnderSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs who recently visited Montevideo. Mariano Fern�ndez Amun�tegui said Chile's relations with Latinamerican countries are going through an excellent moment. Chile and The Mercosur. Half of the Chilean population (49%) believes Chile's Mercosur membership will be benefitial for the country according to a poll taken in the main cities and the camp. Nevertheless, in rural areas the support is significantly less than in the urban areas. The poll also showed that 45% of Chileans believe the country is progressing while 39% said it was stagnant and 13% in decadence. Support for President Frei's administration reached 44%, but 33% rejected the present government policies. Most Chileans also believe the government has been "soft" on lobbies and pressure groups. A similar Mercosur poll taken in Argentina showed 56% of Argentine public opinion in favour of Chile's entry and only 19% considered it harmfull. Chile and Argentina For the first time since Chile and Argentina became independant we are going to have a frontier without disputes, mistaken interpretations or misconcepts", indicated Fern�ndez who added most of Chile's foreign investments so far have been in Argentina. Fern�ndez said Chile is also having talks with the Pacific basin countries and Canada to establish closer trade and investment links, and will become the natural gate to that area for the other Mercosur members. The Iran and Lybia Sanctions. Mercosur countries have rejected the Clinton's administration decision to sanction any oil and gas company dealing with Iran and Lybia. The Iran and Lybia Sanctions Act 1996, similar in spirit to the Helms-Burton which punishes companies trading with Cuba, has also become for Washington an area of confrontation with Europe. For Uruguay the bill if finally enacted could have very negative consequences since Iran has been for the last decade an important market for wool, rice and beef in exchange for oil. Uruguay also lost as a consequence of the UN Irak embargo during the Gulf War a 40.000 tons of mutton market in Bagdad. 7/8/96 Back WT01-B08-88IA062-000353-B003-169http://www.falkland-malvinas.com:80/sne211196.html 207.32.88.17 19970115204213 text/html 6397HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 20:35:00 GMTServer: Apache/1.0.3Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 6226Last-modified: Sun, 29 Dec 1996 07:28:19 GMT Noticias del Mercosur ( ) Significa Texto Completo Noticias del Mercosur Agencia Mercopress 21/11/96 Inversiones Brit�nicas En Argentina Llegar�n a Los 2.200 Millones De D�lares BUENOS AIRES. La Corte de Apelaciones chilena fall� favorablemente el recurso de amparo elevado por los ganaderos que en los hechos bloquea la importaci�n de carne de los pa�ses del Mercosur, principalemente desde Argentina. Los ganaderos chilenos argumentan se han opuesto abiertamente a la asociaci�n de su pa�s al Mercosur argumentando que la importaci�n de productos agr�colas de esos pa�ses los llevar� a la ruina. El fallo judicial, apenas un mes despu�s de la puesta en vigencia de la asociaci�n chilena a Mercosur, sacudi� a los exportadores argentinos quienes en lo que va del a�o ya colocaron carne por valor de 75 millones de d�lares, y r�pidamente comenzaban a adue�arse de ese mercado. Los ganaderos chilenos alegan que la carne argentina no cumple con las exigencias de tipificaci�n chilenas y es de inferior calidad. Argentina consider� el fallo judicial "inadmisible" en t�rminos comerciales y agreg� que los ganaderos chilenos se quejaban simplemente porque no pueden competir con la carne argentina, la cual afirman tiene menores costos y es de superior aceptaci�n entre los consumiodres. "Los consumidores y supermercados chilenos est�n encantados y nuestros productos se han quedado con el 30% superior del mercado", dijo Felipe Sol�, Secretario argentino de Agricultura. El recurso de amparo fue presentado contra el gobierno chileno por la Sociedad Nacional de Agricultura (SNA), la cual tiene un importante respaldo en la oposici�n conservadora en el Congreso. Si bien el gobierno del presidente Eduardo Frei puede apelar ante la Suprema Corte de Justicia, el fallo puede poner impedimentos durante semanas, al comercio de carnes complicando las relaciones con los socios del Mercosur. A pesar del hecho que el gobierno de Frei oportunamente se comprometiera a extender fondos compensatorios por 500 millones de d�lares durante los pr�ximos a�os para el sector rural, lo cual fue parte del acuerdo pol�tico con el Senado chileno para que votara el acuerdo de asociaci�n, la SNA consistentemente ha rechazado el Mercosur y se ha auto-excluido de las principales muestras agr�cola-ganaderas del pa�s andino. Seg�n altos representantes de la SNA las importaciones de carne del Mercosur han causado, en lo que va del a�o a los ganaderos p�rdidas superiores a los cien millones de d�lares como resultado de la ca�da en los valores de la hacienda y de los campos. POLEMICA RESPECTO A LA "EFICIENCIA" DEL MERCOSUR WASHINGTON.- Una pol�mica a nivel continental literalmente estall� cuando, en un informe realizado por uno de los principales economistas del Banco Mundial se describ�a al Mercosur como "un mundo artificial de crecimiento, donde industrias ineficientes prosperan al amparo de una muralla de barreras comerciales". El primer informe cr�tico fue seguido de un segundo, en el cual se ensalzaba el Mercosur diciendo que se trataba "de una iniciativa positiva e importante similar a los inicios del Mercado Com�n", asicomo de cartas de disculpas a las m�ximas autoridades del bloque 4 por 1. Pero los informes lejos de desacreditar al Mercosur revelaron una dura puja intestina en el Banco Mundial donde t�cnicos y economistas parecen divididos en torno a lo que se denominan bloques econ�micos. Por un lado est�n los fundamentalistas quienes predican una completa libertad de mercado y libre empresa, al igual que la eliminaci�n de los aranceles para todos los socios comerciales por igual, catalogando de ineficiencias todo lo que se oponga a ese planteo; en el otro bando est�n aquellos quienes piensan que las asociaciones en bloques econ�micos pueden resultar moderadamente ineficientes, pero m�s que compensan a medida que se consolidan los mercados, se gana en credibilidad y se reducen los riesgos para la inversi�n extranjera. Asimismo el primer informe fue filtrado justo cuando el Banco Mundial oficialmente comineza a recomendar el Mercosur "como una opci�n seria" para las inversiones y tambi�n revelaba que en los �ltimos cinco a�os la instituci�n multilateral de cr�dito ha otorgado cr�ditos por 32.000 millones de d�lares a Latinoam�rica. Para empeorar las cosas el Banco Mundial como parte de su programa de descentralizaci�n ha trasladado su Departamento de M�xico a la capital azteca y en una segunda etapa ha de hacer lo mismo con Brasil, uno de los principales clientes del banco. No obstante los fundamentalistas recibieron alguna ayuda del momento que el informe cr�tico del Mercosur result� simult�neo con un reclamo oficial de Estados Unidos y Jap�n ante la Organizaci�n Mundial del Comercio, por los reg�menes especiales para la industria automotriz que tienen Brasil y Argentina. La pol�mica sobre bloques econ�micos, que tom� circunstancialmente a Mercosur como ejercicio de prueba, se espera sea uno de los principales temas a discutir en la reuni�n de diciembre de la Organizaci�n Mundial de Comercio a celebrarse en Singapur. Mientras tanto para el Banco Mundial, "en el contexto de una creciente globalizaci�n de las econom�as regionales, el Mercosur promete mejorar su competitividad en el tiempo, y por tanto es considerado una iniciativa positiva e importante". LA BRASIL DEPENDENCIA FLORIANOPOLIS. La falta de una "pol�tica industrial activa" y los riesgos de la "Brasil dependencia", se han convertido en los principales temas de debate entre el gobierno argentino y ciertos sectores industriales quienes entienden que r�pidamente est�n perdiendo terreno ante un socio comercial m�s agresivo y pragm�tico. Los primeros disparos provinieron de uno de los industriales m�s fuertes de Argentina quien tiene importantes intereses sobretodo en la fabricaci�n de autom�viles. "Corremos el riesgo de convertirnos en una provincia brasile�a, no necesariamente porque ese sea el prop�sito de nuestros vecinos del norte pero por la falta de una pol�tica industrial activa", dijo Francisco Macri quien est� vinculado a la Fiat y Peugeot. El gobierno argentino no se hizo esperar e inmediatamente respondi� demostrando con cifras que las exportaciones industriales se han duplicado durante los �ltimos doce meses y mantienen el ritmo de crecimiento. Pero a pesar de la controversia es indudable que el comercio argentino-brasile�o en el marco del Mercosur, est� en pleno ascenso con colocaciones record de petr�leo y alimentos por parte de Argentina, mientras que los brasile�os efectivamente se est�n consolidando en varios sectores industriales. Analistas tambi�n agregan al an�lisis de la situaci�n, la vulnerabilidad de los momentos pol�ticos que atraviesan los socios principales del Mercosur: Argentina todav�a sufre los efectos de una severa recesi�n, desempleo y desfase fiscal, mientras que el gobierno brasile�o est� bajo fuerte presi�n de poderosos grupos industriales proteccionistas, en momentos que el presidente Henrique Cardoso negocia con el Congreso una reforma constitucional que le abrir�a las puertas a la reelecci�n, y asegurar�a la continuidad del actual modelo de desarrollo. MEXICO Y MERCOSUR PREPARAN UN ACUERDO DE ASOCIACI�N MEXICO. M�xico a mediano plazo comenzar� discusiones para alcanzar un acuerdo de asociaci�n con el bloque que sustituya los tratados bilaterales con los cuatro miembros plenos del Mercosur. El presidente mexicano hizo el anuncio durante una recepci�n oficial en honor del mandatario uruguayo Julio Mar�a Sanguinetti quien se encuentra de visita en el pa�s azteca al frente de una numerosa delegaci�n de empresarios. Por ahora el Mercosur est� integrado por cuatro pa�ses con un arancel externo b�sico com�n, Brasil, Argentina, Uruguay y Paraguay; una asociaci�n de 4 por 1 con Chile y en diciembre pr�ximo en Fortaleza, Brasil, durante la cumbre presidencial semestral se espera que los mandatarios de Bolivia y Venezuela firmen acuerdos de asociaci�n. El acelerado �xito del Mercosur ha sorprendido a la Uni�n Europea e igualmente el proceso de integraci�n latinoamericano "nos recuerda nuestra propia g�nesis" afirm� el presidente de la Comisi�n para Latinoam�rica del Parlamento del Viejo Continente. Argentina a insistencia de su empresariado ha protestado respecto al mercado petrolero y de combustibles brasile�o, el cual contrariamente a lo acontecido con Argentina donde ha sido enteramente derregulado, permanece restringido y dominado por Petrobras, mientras se aguarda que el Congreso de Brasilia apruebe el proyecto de "flexibilizacion". La otra area de disputa es el paquete de incentivos para promover exportaciones (casi mil millones de dolares en creditos blandos y devoluciones impositivas), que el gobierno federal recientemente aprobara en un intento por disminuir el deficit de la balanza comercial. Similarmente muchos estados brasile�os tienen sus propios incentivos fiscales como forma de atraer a inversiones extranjeras en las industrias del acero, petroquimica y papel, lo cual disminuye las esperanzas de las autoridades de Buenos Aires de conducirlas hacia la Argentina. La prensa brasile�a por su parte ha estado muy caustica en sus comentarios respecto a la situaci�n, afirmando que "Argentina pretende que Brasil le resuelva sus problemas economicos de propia factura. Nuestro end�mico d�ficit comercial con Argentina solo ayuda a financiar las compras argentinas en EE.UU.", resalto un importante industrial brasile�o en un art�culo de la principal publicaci�n econ�mica de Sao Paulo. ACUERDAN FORMACION DE TRIBUNAL ESPECIAL PARA EL MERCOSUR Miembros de las Supremas Cortes de Argentina, Uruguay, Chile y Paraguay acordaron la creaci�n de un tribunal supra nacional para derimir sobre cuestiones comunitarias referidas a disputas comerciales, aduaneras y diplom�ticas. La resoluci�n se aprob� a pesar de la oposici�n de la delegaci�n judicial del Brasil la cual argumento que la instalaci�n de un tribunal especial resultaria "costoso e innecesario". El Tribunal especial tendra su sede en Asunci�n, Paraguay, y se considera el primer paso hacia la unificaci�n jurisprudencial del derecho comunitario de la regi�n. "Todav�a es muy temprano para pensar en un tribunal supra nacional, por lo menos hasta que no hayamos redactado y aprobado una legislacion comunitaria eficiente y apropiada que beneficie a los paises miembros y asociados", indico Nelson Jobim, el Ministro brasileno de Justicia. Pero antes que el Tribunal especial sea realidad, las legislaturas de los cinco paises involucrados deberan debatir y aprobar el proyecto. Pero las cifras del censo realizado en abril de este a�o, tambien muestran desequilibrios entre la poblaci�n que vive en Port Stanley y el campo, al igual que significativos cambios sociales. Mientras que el n�mero de residentes en la capital ha crecido un 63% desde 1982, y ahora alcanza a 1.638, el campo en apenas diez a�os ha perdido 208 habitantes, quedando con apenas 445 personas. La caida en los precios de lana, la fortaleza de la industria de la pesca y del servicio civil, sumado a las perspectivas petroleras han atraido a muchos residentes del campo a Port Stanley en busca de puestos de trabajo mejor remunerados, ocasionando a la vez una escasez de viviendas. Desde que el Reino Unido estableciera una zona exclusiva de pesca de 200 millas en torno a las islas en 1985, la econom�a de las islas no ha cesado de crecer, y la escasez de mano de obra para mantenerse a tono con los contratos de desarrollo del gobierno se ha hecho mas evidente. El anterior record de poblaci�n data de 1931 con 2.392 personas, mientras que las estad�sticas m�s pobres corresponden a los �ltimos a�os de la decada del setenta y 1980 con el m�nimo hist�rico de 1.813 personas. Otro hecho interesante es que las islas han recibido en los ultimos a�os un influjo sostenido de inmigrantes revertiendo la tendencia previa a la guerra, cuando por ejemplo las jovenes isle�as se casaban con los Infantes de Marina desplegados en las islas para asi emigrar al Reino Unido. Esto tamb�en en su momento ocasion� un serio desequilibrio entre la poblaci�n masculina y femenina (2 a 1), en tanto ahora casi se ha nivelado (1 a 1 ). El censo de 1996 no incluye a la guarnicion militar britanica en Mount Pleasant, estimada en 2.000, pero si a los 253 originarios de la isla de Santa Helena, que generalmente hacen tareas de apoyo y mantenimiento en la base. POSICION ARGENTINA EN TEMA PESCA PREOCUPA A ISLE�OS El duro e inesperado discurso del Canciller argentino Guido Di Tella ante la Asamblea General de Naciones Unidas respecto a la pesca en el Atl�ntico sur, elevando dram�ticamente el nivel de las diferencias, ha originado preocupaci�n entre los habitantes de las Falklands/Malvinas y autoridades brit�nicas. La nueva posici�n argentina en cuanto a un acuerdo de pesca a largo plazo, insistiendo en que cualquier entendimiento debe cubrir ambas zonas ma�timas, "no solo las Falklands / Malvinas, sino tambien las Georgias", echo un balde de agua fria sobre cualquier esperanza de una soluci�n en un futuro pr�ximo. Los temas son "indivisibles" y "si no logramos un acuerdo sobre pesca en las Falklands/Malvinas y en las Georgias, entonces no hay acuerdo", resalt� el Canciller Di Tella. El Reino Unido que tambien mantiene un controvertido control sobre la pesca en las Georgias del Sur, no acepta conexi�n alguna entre ambos territorios insulares y rechaza de plano la nueva posici�n argentina. Del momento que la econom�a de las Falklands/Malvinas depende pr�cticamente de la pesca, sobre todo el calamar, el cual circula libremente en el Atlantico sur en aguas compartidas, la nueva politica argentina implica riesgos para los ingresos anuales que genera la venta de licencias de pesca. Ambos paises reconocen que es necesario un acuerdo a largo plazo para evitar la sobre explotaci�n de los recursos maritimos en la zona, pero un acuerdo ahora parece mas distante que nunca. Di Tella tambien ha adelantado que ha de plantear el tema de la pesca en torno a las Georgias en la pr�xima reunion de CAMELAR, Convencion para la Conservaci�n de Recursos Marinos Antarticos, prevista para este mes en Australia. Tanto Argentina como Chile han protestado la decisi�n britanica de extender permisos de pesca para operar en aguas de las Georgias del sur. MAPA DEL MERCOSUR INCLUYE A FALKLANDS/MALVINAS El primer mapa regional del Mercosur relevado e impreso por el Servicio Geografico Militar del Uruguay, (SGM), y que recientemente fuera hecho p�blico, incluye a las Falklands/Malvinas. Daniel de los Santos, Director del SGM. El mapa es parte de un proyecto cartogr�fico contratado por los pa�ses latinoamericanos el cual tamb�en incluye al Mercosur. ALERTA ROJO POR EL OZONO La parte m�s debilitada de la capa de ozono anticipo en un mes su llegada al Atlantico sur con peligrosas consecuencias para quienes se expongan a los quemantes rayos solares. Los registros en unidades Dobson, el indice para determinar los rayos ultra violeta, alcanzaron un m�nimo hist�rico en Punta Arenas, extremo sur de Chile y en las Falklands/Malvinas donde el gobierno de inmediato ordeno una alerta roja. Por alguna raz�n aun desconocida, los argentinos que hab�an anticipado el fen�meno desde la Base Marambio en la Antartida, como primera reacci�n retuvieron la informacion originando una protesta generalizada en las zonas mas afectadas por la erosi�n en la capa de ozono. Se entiende como un registro normal y sin consecuencias, 300 Dobson, pero cualquier �ndice menor a los 220 es considerado peligroso: la exposici�n al sol debe ser reducida al minimo, y se requiere protecci�n especial para la piel y ojos. Los registros en Punta Arenas a mediados de setiembre, el mes cr�tico este a�o, estuvieron un par de d�as por debajo de los 200 Dobson. En ese per�odo se celebran las muestras ganaderas y de industrias anexas, mas importantes de Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay y Uruguay, ofreciendo un panorama de las perspectivas y animo que reina en el sector. Este a�o la muestra de Palermo en Argentina no escap� del ambiente recesivo y de preocupaci�n que afecta a los agentes econ�micos argentinos, si bien el sector agr�cola por la firmeza del mercado internacional de los granos atraviesa un buen momento. La ganader�a en cambio se ha visto condicionada por las consecuencias negativas para el mercado internacional de la carne de la epidemia de la "vaca loca" y la depresi�n en los precios de la lana. Igualmente la inestabilidad del clima, con temperaturas extremas a destiempo de las estaciones ha ocasionado grandes perdidas en los cuatro pa�ses del Mercosur: las secas se van alternado con inundaciones y registros bajo cero afectando la capacidad de alimentaci�n de los campos naturales. En Paraguay anuncios oficiales de apoyo a la ganader�a neutralizaron esos efectos y en Brasil en la exposici�n de Esteio en Porto Alegre, y la mayor de ese pa�s con mas de 4.200 animales, a pesar de una promesa del gobierno de un paquete para fomentar las exportaciones se cosecharon mas quejas que aplausos. Tanto en Palermo, Esteio como Paraguay la venta de reproductores en esta edici�n fue menor a la del a�o pasado. Falta saber lo que acontecer� en la muestra rural del Prado en Uruguay, el pa�s que mas depende de los precios internacionales de los productos agr�colas pues exporta la mayor�a de su producci�n. Sin embargo en Uruguay el sector rural tambi�n se queja amargamente adem�s de la carga fiscal. Visite expoprado CHILE FUERTE INVERSOR EN MERCOSUR A pesar que reci�n el mes de octubre pr�ximo comienza a regir el acuerdo de Chile con Mercosur, las inversiones externas del pa�s andino durante los �ltimos a�os se han estado dirigiendo mayoritariamente hacia ese grupo de paises. Sobre un total de 8.634 millones de d�lares que Chile ha invertido en el exterior casi cinco mil millones o sea el 57% han sido colocados en el Mercosur desde 1990 seg�n cifras divulgadas por el Comit� de Inversiones Extranjeras del Ministerio de Econom�a chileno. De ese total un 90% se ha colocado en Argentina, 7% en Brasil y el resto en Paraguay y Uruguay. Si bien el grueso de las colocaciones chilenas hasta el momento se han dirigido hacia Argentina aprovechando la pol�tica de privatizaciones, es sabido que uno de los objetivos principales de la participaci�n de Chile en Mercosur es el mercado brasile�o. En Brasil Chile ha invertido 340 millones de d�lares pero participa en proyectos de negocios que superan los 1.300 millones de d�lares. . "UNO DE LOS FENOMENOS MAS INTERESANTES" El Mercosur es uno de los fen�menos m�s significativos del continente y es interesante comprobar que las decisiones para conformar ese mercado se est�n tomando fuera de la �rbita de Washington afirmo Henry Kissinger, ex Secretario de Estado de los EE.UU. del gobierno de Richard Nixon. Kissinger entrevistado sobre las actuales relaciones de EE. UU. con Latinoam�rica dijo que lamentablemente el presidente Clinton no muestra inter�s por el continente. "En cuatro a�os no ha visitado siquiera M�xico, pero lo mas preocupante para mi es que no se presta la debida atenci�n al fen�meno del Mercosur", resalto Kissinger. Por primera vez en la historia seg�n el consultor internacional existe un grupo de pa�ses aliados del cual esta excluido Estados Unidos. "Los presidentes de Brasil y Argentina son buenos amigos, pero las decisiones sobre el futuro de una regi�n tan importante en el hemisferio occidental est�n surgiendo en Buenos Aires mientras Washington permanece indiferente", explico Kissinger. De acuerdo al ex-profesor de Harvard es esencial para Estados Unidos recuperar la iniciativa continental e intentar la confluencia en un solo mercado com�n del NAFTA y Mercosur. BRASIL TRABA TEXTILES Brasil ha vuelto a trabar las importaciones de textiles al decidir unilateralmente bajar de 180 a 30 d�as el plazo para el pago de las compras en el exterior. Cuando se anuncio la medida por primera vez en mayo pasado, Uruguay y Paraguay protestaron en�rgicamente y luego Argentina. Un mes despu�s en el marco de la cumbre presidencial de los pa�ses del Mercosur celebrada en San Luis, Argentina, Brasil retorno al plazo de 180 d�as para sus socios. En esta ocasion aparentemente la resoluci�n del Banco Central incluye precios m�nimos de importaci�n que violan las normas de la Organizaci�n Mundial de Comercio. En Brasil medios pol�ticos han dicho que la medida obedece alas intenciones del gobierno de Cardoso de enfriar las importaciones para satisfacer a los industriales paulistas y contener el desbalance comercial. Comisiones especiales del Mercosur y del Grupo Andino han sido encomendadas para preparar los documentos a negociar si bien no se han puesto una fecha definitiva para la reuni�n. "No queremos precipitar las conversaciones y vamos a iniciar analizando mecanismos y criterios para la negociaci�n", dijo el Ministro de Comercio Exterior de Colombia Morris Harf. Un primer encuentro formal esta previsto se realice en Lima. El Grupo Andino esta conformado por Colombia, Ecuador, Per� y Venezuela. CHILE QUIERE RENEGOCIAR Cuando faltan apenas d�as para la puesta en vigencia del acuerdo Chile-Mercosur rubricado por los cinco presidentes pero que aun aguarda aprobaci�n del senado chileno, autoridades de Santiago de chile adelantaron que desean ampliar la lista de productos negociados para ingresar al Mercosur. [ ORDER | HOME | FEEDBACK ]WT01-B08-113IA069-000435-B025-20http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/garden.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174023 text/html 7152HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:40:31 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Fri, 12 Jul 1996 23:27:44 GMTETag: "403ac-1aff-31e6df70"Content-Length: 6911Accept-Ranges: bytes About Organics About Organic Gardening As more and more products labeled "natural-organic" become available today at local garden centers, many gardeners are asking the question, "What is organic gardening?" People often assume that organic gardening is some kind of fad or gimmick that is the result of the latest environmental concern. Organic gardening is in no way a new phenomenon, however. It is a return to the methods of cultivation practiced for centuries. Organic gardening is a conscious effort on the part of the gardener to reintroduce the cycles and inherent balances of nature back into their gardens. Organic gardening has several basic principles that provide the foundation for its success: Learn to live with nature, not in confrontation with it. Promote diversity within the garden. It is through this diversity that nature achieves stability. Grow plants in environments to which they are best suited. Feed the soil, not the plant. It is the health of the soil that ensures a plant's health. Return to the soil as much as you take out. Think of the garden as a total system. Organic gardeners think of the soil as the foundation of a healthy garden. The soil holds most of the vital nutrients a plant requires for growth. The soil also serves as the reservoir for the water plants require. By feeding our soil, making regular additions of organic matter, we create an environment that fosters the growth of healthy, vibrant, and nutritious plants. Plants are allowed to grow at their natural rate (not pushed along by synthetic fertilizers) and they therefore develop a higher resistance to attacks by insects and diseases. By creating diversity in our gardens, such as planting flowers in vegetable gardens, we learn to attract beneficial insects and other life into our garden to help us maintain an appropriate equilibrium. In time we learn to accept a few holes in the leaf, the occasional slug or snail, the presence of weeds, as signs that the garden is healthy, vital, and self-sustaining. As a result , we are able to vastly reduce the chemical dependency many gardens have unwittingly developed. Whitney Farms Organic Fertilizers and Soils provide the gardener with sources of the finest quality fertilizers and soils derived from entirely natural sources. We have made every effort to produce plant foods that feed and enrich the soil so that the gardener may enjoy the abundance a healthy garden can afford. About Organic Fertilizers Any discussion of fertilizers should begin with at least a brief overview of plant nutrition. It is commonly accepted that there are 16 elements required by plants for healthy growth. Of these, three-carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen-are supplied by air and water. The other 13 are normally absorbed from the soil by plant roots. This group of 13 is further divided into 3 subgroups: primary nutrients , secondary nutrients, and micro nutrients. All of these elements are essential, regardless of the amounts required. They include: Primary Nutrients: Nitrogen, Phosphorous,Potassium Secondary Nutrients: Calcium,Magnesium, Sulfur Micro nutrients: Zinc, iron, Manganese,Copper, Boron, Molybdenum, and Chlorine All of these nutrients work together in a delicate balance to promote plant growth. For example, an excess of one nutrient can reduce a plant's ability to absorb another. The role of any fertilizer is to improve the fertility of the soil. The soil supports plant life and is the vehicle that supplies the necessary nutrients to the plant. The more fertile a soil is (i.e. rich in organic matter) the more likely it is to yield a healthy and abundant garden. Fertilizers are commonly divided into two different categories: synthetic/chemical fertilizers and natural organic ones. Plants cannot tell the difference between an organic and a synthetic/chemical fertilizer. The difference between the two types of fertilizers is evident in their impact on the soil. Organic fertilizers feed the soil, not the plant. The soil will feed the plant. Organic fertilizers help maintain overall soil fertility by contributing vital organic matter and enhancing the soil structure in addition to supplying plant nutrients.They are most often derived from the by-products of once living organisms or from rock powders. Organic fertilizers are released gradually to the plant. They actually form a store house in the soil; the plant takes up the nutrients as it needs them. Soil fertility is maintained and enhanced for the long-term benefit of the garden. Synthetic/chemical fertilizers are formulated to be fast-acting. Most synthetic fertilizers are salt or acid-based. They typically have a higher nutrient grade than do natural organic fertilizers and they are often intended to be immediately available to the plant. In many cases the plant can only use 10% to 15% of the available nutrients in synthetic/ chemical fertilizers. The rest is essentially wasted -creating possible harmful side effects and suppressing many beneficial soil organisms. Soil fertility can be reduced with an excess of synthetic/chemical fertilizer use. Whitney Farms Organic Fertilizers are derived from entirely natural sources. Except for our rock powders, all of our organic fertilizers are by-products that have been "recycled" for the gardener's benefit. Our fertilizers fit into two categories: fertilizer blends and simple plant foods. All Whitney Farms Organic Fertilizers are derived from natural organic sources (as defined by organic certifying organizations). We produce plant foods that aid the gardener by feeding and enriching the soil. A rich soil will produce an abundant garden. Where is Whitney Farms? Whitney Farms is located next to the mighty Willamette river in Independence, Oregon. For quite some time we have been gathering a compost next to our compound, mainly consisting of exotic zoo animal excrement. Anyways, it is getting ripe and it should be ready sometime next year. Unfortunately, our most creative name for it is Zoo Doo. We would like to find a great name, and are soliciting your help. If you can think of that great name, send it to us and if it is chosen, you will win a fantastic prize. [ Enter to Win |Previous Entries |Prizes |Rules ] 30,000 pounds of manure. What a Lovely sight. An enormous pile of potential, that's what we see. Bags upon bags offertilizer. Beautiful things growing everywhere. Every week, it's more of the same. Another 30,000 pound package fromthe Zoo, another opportunity to grow. In exchange, we send the Zoofertilizer. We also send along a share of the proceeds, which the Zoouses to buy food for the animals (which make more manure). By the time the year's over, we've not only converted 1,560,000pounds of manure into 100% premium organic fertilizer, but we've savedthe Zoo about $50,000 in dumping fees. Meanwhile, we get to be a provider for the Zoo's lawn and gardencare. They were even kind enough to name their concert lawn after us.The Whitney Farms Concert Lawn. Ah, the sweet smell of manure. Unfortunately, this year's batch was lost in the flooding. But next season, the zoo fertilizer will be on themarket, and we still don't have a name for it! That's where you comein. Enter our contest by sending your suggestion for a name for theproduct. We'll post it along with earlier contributions, and give ita preliminary rating on the poo scale. All previous contributions areeligible for the contest. Raised beds in the vegetable Garden Raise your Beds Container Gardening Cool Veggies Beans & Bacteria = nitrogen for your garden The Origins of Corn The Three Sisters Fertilizers at the speed of light! I need some water! Help! Not just any water! Controlling Moss Still More on Planting Trees OLD DIRT (back issues) APRIL ISSUE What do roses Like? Myth of the Month Don't Pick on the Chicken Move Toward the Light Attracting Butterflies & Hummingbirds More on Trees Favorite Annuals Whitney Farms Seed Starting Mix is a Smash Hit So Long Sammy MARCH ISSUE Whitney Survives Flood but ZooPoo heads downstream Planting Trees & Shrubs Check Before you Dig Uncle Malcolm's Fun Facts A Note from the President I admit it. I enjoy mowing the lawn. In fact, I enjoy it so much that I even mow my neighbor's yard every week. It sounds strange as I write this but I seem to get lost when I am pushing the mower back and forth. It must go back to my Midwest roots and the long summers of lawn mowing.My first real business in high school was mowing lawns for all of our neighbors. In my old neighborhood there are no fences. It is just a collection of shared lawns with houses in the middle. It was not uncommon to start mowing in a straight line at one home and turn around four houses later.We rarely see lawns of this magnitude in the West. Like most of my neighbors, we've taken out most of the existing lawn and put in flower beds. Even as good as the flower beds look, without the lawn in the middle the yard would look incomplete. Grow your own! John D. [ ORDER | HOME | FEEDBACK ]WT01-B08-124IA069-000435-B026-60http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/compost.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174320 text/html 6197HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:43:24 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Tue, 04 Jun 1996 20:11:47 GMTETag: "d5b0d-1744-31b49883"Content-Length: 5956Accept-Ranges: bytes Composting Locating Your Compost Pile Building Your Compost Pile About Backyard Composting There are three critical elements to making compost: Balance of raw materials Air Water The art of making compost involves integrating these elements to allow decomposition to occur with the greatest efficiency. Composting is a modification of the natural process of decay, which maintains and enhances the nutrients in the system. Selecting Materials There are two types of organic matter that go into the building of a compost pile: Materials high in carbon - woody dry materials like sawdust, straw, dry grass clippings, and fallen leaves. (Hint: The older and more mature the material is, the higher the carbon content.) Materials high in nitrogen - green, wet materials like fresh grass clippings, kitchen wastes, fresh green weeds, and manure's. (Hint: The greener the material, the higher the nitrogen.) Material high in carbon is usually the ingredient most readily available for composting but it is also the limiting factor in a compost pile because it breaks down slowly. To ensure the proper balance of materials, it is crucial to match the carbon content with the nitrogen content. Locating Your Compost Pile To achieve the optimum temperature, adequate mass is required. The ideal minimum size for a compost pile is a cubic yard (3 ft. by 3 ft. by 3 ft.). Position the compost pile where it will be protected from drying winds in the winter, and hot, drying sunlight in the summer. In general, the more exposed the location for the pile, the more extra watering will be required to ensure a good moisture content. Building Your Compost Pile By layering the ingredients in a compost pile, we simplify the process of balancing carbon and nitrogen. Put layers of matter high in carbon (6-8 inches thick) next to layers of matter high in nitrogen (3-4 inches thick); layers of dry ingredients next to layers of wet ingredients. In general, a number of thin layers will allow for more efficient decomposition than a few thick layers. Raw Materials Begin by loosening the soil in the area where you wish to build your compost pile. Make a base of coarse material like corn or sunflower stalks. This will allow for good aeration at the bottom of the pile and will help to hasten the decay of these materials. Water. On top of the base layer, place a 6"-8" layer of organic wastes, such as grass, leaves, and plant trimmings. (Hint: Any Material that could nut and putrefy should be mixed with other drier materials like straw or sawdust, and kept in thin layers no more than 1 "-2 " thick.) Water. Next layer: Use green materials high in nitrogen or use a nitrogen source like Whitney Farms Compost Maker. (Use 2 cups for every 6"-8" layer.) On top of the nitrogen source, it is useful to add a half-inch of soil to inoculate the pile with the appropriate microorganisms. This soil layer will also help reduce the leaching of mineral nutrients like potassium, and help to trap escaping nitrogen gas. Add water. Continue to repeat the layers adding organic wastes, a nitrogen source, and soil until the pile is completed. (Be sure to water each layer, except for those layers composed of wet materials like kitchen scraps.) The pile should be at least 3 feet high when finished. It is important to cap a finished pile with 2"-3" of soil. This final layer of soil will help to trap many escaping gases, like ammonia, and retain those nutrients in the finished compost. A thick layer of straw in winter will help to protect the pile from rain and provide insulation so that the desirable temperature for decomposition can be maintained. Air The most efficient green high decomposition requires an with the adequate supply of oxygen.Oxygen can be provided in two ways: The first technique is to construct your compost pile in layer cake fashion to provide adequate ventilation. The second technique is to turn the compost pile periodically - once or twice a month. By thoroughly turning the pile inside out, a sufficient supply of oxygen can be guaranteed and the process is accelerated. In a well built and well aerated compost pile, the process of decay generates a lots of heat - up to 150'F (66'C). This high heat is crucial for killing any weed seeds and pathogens (disease producing organisms), and for accelerating the decaying process. Monitor the temperature of the compost pile with a compost thermometer. Turn the pile after the temperature has peaked and begun to cool down. Water Water is also vital to a compost pile, because the microorganisms in the pile dependupon it for their metabolism. A compost pile that is too dry will not break down efficiently; compost pile that is too wet will interfere with oxygen availability and become anaerobic. Asyou construct the compost pile, water each layer until the material glistens; as a rule of thumb, the compost should have the feel of a damp sponge. (Some materials, like wet leaves or kitchen scraps, may be wet initially, and do not need additional watering.) Seabird Guano is used extensively on fruits, citrus, and grapes in South America, and is suitable for use throughout the garden on all types of plants. Bat Guano is an excellent source of readily available nitrogen and other nutrients, and was very popular with farmers and gardeners prior to the advent of chemical fertilizers.
