[ ORDER | HOME | FEEDBACK ]WT01-B08-133IA069-000435-B026-336http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/lawn.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174508 text/html 3829HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:45:16 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Tue, 04 Jun 1996 20:12:12 GMTETag: "d5b0e-e05-31b4989c"Content-Length: 3589Accept-Ranges: bytes The Lawn Organic Lawn Food Whitney Farms Organic Lawn Food is a premium blend of slow-release, non-burning, 100% natural organic ingredients. It is formulated to meet the year-round fertility requirements of all types of turf grasses. It will gently feed the lawn and enhance the vitality of the soil to provide the foundation for a healthy turf. Whitney Farms Organic Lawn Food should ,be used as a complete annual program to achieve optimum results. For those lawns converting from a "chemical dependency" on synthetic fertilizers, the first year is critical to the process of rebuilding a healthy soil ecosystem. In order to restore vitality to the soil, it is necessary to initially use our lawn food at higher rates than in subsequent years. Indeed, the longer you use it, the better your turf response. Ingredients: Blood Meal, Dried Poultry Waste, Feather Meal, and Bone Meal. Tips for Preparing New Lawns Whether using seed or sod, always begin by thoroughly preparing the soil. For best results, incorporate 2-3 inches of compost or other organic matter into the soil. Till to a depth of 6-8 inches. Level area with rake or roller. Under any new lawn it is important to establish a basis of soil fertility. To give the turf a gentle start, add Whitney Farms Organic Lawn Food at a rate of 25 lbs. per 1000 feet. Rake in lightly to a depth of 1-2 inches. Keep the new lawn area moist throughout its first 3 weeks. For newly seeded lawns, keep it moist until the grass is at least 2 inches tall. For newly sodded lawns, ... keep turf area moist for at least 3 weeks.Apply Whitney Farms Organic Lawn Food again 4-6 weeks after lawn is established. Why Use Whitney FarmsOrganic Lawn Food? The results are longer lasting. The longer you use our fertilizer, the less frequently you will need to apply it. It gently fertilizes turf grass and relies on soil microorganisms to release their nutrients at the same rate plant rootscan absorb them. Our lawn food is easy to use. It is a dust-free, homogenous blend, granulated for easy spreading. It is an ideal lawn food for the low water or drought growing conditions in the West. Available in 25 lb. bags. Tips for a Healthy Lawn Aerate lawn in spring and fall to help reduce thatch problems. Add a 1/4 to 1/2 inch of finely screened organic matter annually to enhance soil life under turf. Mow regularly. To recycle nutrients (particularly nitrogen), leave lawn clippings whenever possible. When you water, water deeply. Most lawns require about an inch of water per week. Avoid watering daily to prevent shallow root development. In the spring, mow the lawn short to help stimulate the grass. In the summer andfall, allow your grass to grow higher. This will help, shade the lawn and crowd out potential weeds. In the late fall, lower the height again. [ ORDER | HOME | FEEDBACK ] WT01-B08-134IA069-000435-B026-372http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/soil.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174521 text/html 3027HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:45:26 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Tue, 04 Jun 1996 20:12:51 GMTETag: "d5b0b-ae3-31b498c3"Content-Length: 2787Accept-Ranges: bytes About Soil Amendments About Soil Amendments Organic matter is the very heart and soul of organic gardening. Organic matter is the waste residues and remains of living organisms. As it undergoes the natural process of decay in the soil, it is converted gradually to a very stable form called humus. Ultimately humus and the process by which it is formed can have a dramatic impact on your garden. An adequate supply of humus in a garden will: Improve aeration in the soil and enhance its ability to absorb and retain water readily Improve the soil's ability to retain and release nutrients Provide a source of nutrients to plants Serve as a food source for soil microbes, thereby improving the soil's biological activity There are few things as important in garden preparation as adding organic matter to the soil. Yet, many gardeners have gotten away from adding organic matter to the soil and instead have relied on synthetic fertilizers. While synthetic fertilizers can provide the raw elements necessary for plant growth, they can not replace organic matter lost through the mismanagement of soils. In time, more fertilizer is needed to compensate for degeneration of organic matter in the soil. At Whitney Farms we have worked hard to develop a line of soil amendments that provides a quality compost for the home gardener. All of our manures and amendments are composted for a minimum of one year. They aren't just stacked in a big pile and left to sit; they are turned regularly with compostturning machinery to ensure proper breakdown. Throughout the process we maintain temperatures close to 160 degrees Fahrenheit for optimum breakdown. By composting, we ensure that the finished product is a material rich humus that will contribute to a garden's success. Our amendments and composts won't rob nutrients like an unfinished compost or wood byproducts will. Whitney Farms amendments add life to a garden. It is important that compost or other organic matter be added to a garden every year to keep the soil alive. We suggest that 2 inches be added and tilled in to a minimum of 6 inches before spring planting. For stubborn soils, add organic matter again in the fall as a mulch for the first few years of a garden. WT01-B08-136IA069-000435-B027-29http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/water.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174550 text/html 10624HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:45:55 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Tue, 04 Jun 1996 20:13:05 GMTETag: "403a8-288e-31b498d1"Content-Length: 10382Accept-Ranges: bytes Water Wise Gardening Water Wise Gardening Soil Plants Fertilizers Watering All too often gardeners in the west face frequent concerns about water shortages and mandatory rationing. Periods of extremely low rainfall, coupled with rapidly growing populations and limited reservoir capacity in some areas has prompted municipalities to institute measures to reduce outside water use. Should gardeners he concerned? Does this mean loosing that prized collection of lilies? While water use restrictions may mean an inconvenience for some, they do not signal an end to gardening. During the eighties, many areas, such as the central coast of California, endured extended periods of drought. Gardeners simply adapted and learned how to conserve water while their gardens continued to thrive. Conservation begins with wise water use. The first step should be to check existing sprinkler systems and outdoor faucets for leaks; even a slow drip can add up to hundreds of gallons of lost water in a very short time. Repair leaks, and replace worn washers with new ones. At the same time, check the a pattern of your sprinklers to ensure that your water is going where you want it, on your garden - not your neighbor's driveway or the sidewalk where it will be lost to evaporation. This is also a good time to repair that leaky hose that has dribbled water down your arm for years when you watered your hanging flower baskets. A new hose end costs very little, a new washer even less, and you can save a substantial amount of water with these simple repairs. Saving water may also require a change in your watering schedule. Many gardeners make the mistake of watering in the heat of midday when water is lost to evaporation. Instead, water during cooler periods of the day, early morning and late evening. To avoid diseases like powdery mildew, early watering schedules are best, because the water has time to evaporate from the leaf surfaces while the day warms up. Automatic timers can make early watering easier: They can be set to go on at dawn and to shut off the water after running for a specific time. Soil Learning to determine how much water to use is another important component of wise water use. Different plants will require different amounts of water, and different soils will have different water needs. Begin by establishing what type of soil you have. Generally, there are three different kinds ofsoils: sand, loam, and clay. Sandy soils will have a gritty feel if rubbed in the palm of your hand. The bigger particles in sandy soil create large air spaces between particles that allow for good drainage and fast water infiltration. Unfortunately sandy soils are often so well drained that they do not retain water well. Clay soils are the other extreme: Composed of fine particles that will fell smooth and slippery when rubbed in the palm of your hand, clay soils have very small spaces between particles. This causes them to absorb water more slowly making them prone to runoff. On the positive side however, soils of this type can hold significantly more water than sandy soils. Loamy soils lie somewhere in the middle of these two extremes, and often share the properties of easy infiltration balanced with good moisture retention. Regardless of soil type there is one factor that can substantially improve the ability of all soils to retain moisture: Compost. The spongelike quality of compost allows it to hold substantial amounts of water in a form available to plants. Incorporate compost when planting, or add it to existing beds by carefully working it into the soil around plants. Because of the absorbent nature of compost, you may have to use more water initially to thoroughly wet your soil, but you should be able to go longer between waterings, saving in the long run. Compost can also be used as a mulch, which will help conserve moisture by reducing the loss of water from the soil due to evaporation. At the same time, it acts like an absorbent covering for the soil which aids in the infiltration of water into the soil and reduces runoff. In general, compost is one of the most cost effective improvements you can make to drought-proof your garden. All of our Whitney Farms composts and soil amendments provide you with an outstanding source of high quality organic matter to help you enhance and maintain the natural reservoir in your soil. Learn to judge when to water by the color and feel of your soil. Dig down 8-12 inches and grab a handful of soil. Most soil with adequate moisture will look relatively dark, feet moist to the touch, and will form a ball under light pressure. If your soil won't form a ball and looks dry, it is time to water. It will take a while to become expert at this, but a good, sense of moisture comes with practice. Plants The kind of plants you are growing will also influence your watering methods. Different plants have different watering needs. Deeply rooted shrubs, for instance, will not have the same requirements as shallow rooting annuals. It is important when planning your garden that you take into account these differences so that plants can be grouped by water requirements and thus be maintained more easily without wasting water. Remember that the way you water will also determine the rooting depths of the plants in your garden. If you water frequently with small amounts of water, you will encourage your garden to develop shallow roots close to the surface that require almost daily applications of water. For healthy root systems that grow deep into the soil for moisture, water deeply as infrequently as possible. Even lawn grasses, usually thought of as shallow rooted, can be encouraged to root as deeply as 10 to 24 inches, which allows them to tap reserves of moisture lower in the soil, but only if the gardener waters deeply and infrequently. If you have questions about the watering requirements of plants in your garden or the kind of root systems that you can expect to develop, consult the staff at your local nursery for further information. Fertilizers An important consideration is the kind of fertilizers you use. Because most inexpensive synthetic fertilizers are salts, they can compete for moisture with plants during time of drought. At the same time, extremely soluble forms of nitrogen can encourage tender succulent growth which increases the demand for water in the plant. Avoid these problems by using Whitney Farms fertilizers. Our natural organic products are not salt based, and add valuable organic matter to your soil when you fertilize. Because they are slow release, they also allow the plants to grow at a more gradual natural rate and make more efficient use of the water available to them. Watering The kind of sprinkler you use will also have an influence on your ability to conserve water. Sprinklers come in a wide variety of styles and sizes. Ideally a sprinkler should apply water like a light spring rain with fine gentle droplets. This allows the water to soak into the soil gradually and helps to limit compaction of the soil, Additionally, some sprinklers have motions that allow the water time to soak in between cycles. This will also aid in reducing compaction and the loss of water to runoff. It is better to have a number of small sprinklers that do an excellent job of covering different areas of your garden than to try to adapt one sprinkler to a variety of different uses. Perhaps the most important tools for reducing water use in the garden are soaker hoses and drip systems. Both soaker hoses and drip systems apply water at such low rates that local authorities will often exempt them from many of the water restrictions. And because they do not spray water directly onto the foliage, these systems will also allow you to irrigate at night when there is the lowest chance of evaporation. Soaker hoses are the easiest and least expensive to use; they hook up to your spigot and the water leaches out from tiny holes along the entire length of the hose. They are best suited to intensively planted areas like vegetable gardens or ground covers where they is little concern if the area between plants is watered as well.Drip systems are similar to soaker hoses and have the added advantage of allowing the gardener to apply precise amounts of water to specific areas. They are made up of a variety of little "drippers" (which are small outlets that meter the flow of water) and the tubing and connectors necessary to supply them. It is clear that gardeners have tools available that can help their gardens flourish through periods when water is in short supply. In fact, it is the experience of many gardeners in California that their gardens grew better when they were on watering restrictions. Why? Many gardeners discovered they were simply over watering, while others discovered that they were wasting water with short shallow sprinklings that quickly evaporated and left their gardens thirsty. Some gardeners even found ways to save water in the home to ensure that they would have an adequate supply for their plants. While the possibility of watering restrictions may be in our future, they will not mean an end to gardening. Rather it will encourage more efficient water use through careful planning and the many water saving technologies available to gardeners today. At Whitney Farms we are dedicated to helping you have a rich, healthy soil that will allow your garden to make optimum use of the water available to it. [ Enter to Win |Previous Entries |Prizes |Rules ]WT01-B08-143IA069-000435-B028-203http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/maydirt.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174939 text/html 13207HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:49:44 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:25:22 GMTETag: "e0bb7-32a5-31ae2052"Content-Length: 12965Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Back Issue (April) Veg food hits a grand slam Whitney Farms Vegetable Food is the best team player in the organic vegetable garden. This fertilizer, known to its fans as Veg, shares many traits with those baseball heroes who get the job done without calling attention to themselves. Like Cal Ripken, Veg is well-rounded and always there when needed. Veg has blood meal to promote green growth in the cool days of spring, and dried poultry waste to sustain plants throughout the season. Bone meal and sunflower hull ash round out Veg with phosphorus and potash so plants produce strong roots and abundant fruit. Unlike its tired competitors, the chemical fertilizers, Veg will never have a rain delay because its ingredients will not wash away under heavy rains or irrigation. Veg, with its kelp meal, will also help plants take any curve that nature can throw at it. The potash and micronutrients in kelp meal help plants resist pests and diseases and enhance their overall vigor and hardiness. Veg is also a great motivator of its teammates. Its organic matter stimulates soil organisms, like earthworms, which greatly contribute to a garden's fertility and productivity. Other players may boast bigger numbers, but Veg gives all its has and will never burn out, wash out or fade in the stretch. Those gardeners who have Veg on their team wouldn't trade it for all those over-promised hotshots in the league. Get out of line! Raised Beds in the Vegetable Garden In 19th century Paris, growing vegetables reached a zenith unparalleled even to this day. Small market gardens using intensive methods supplied the city with an incomparable variety of fresh produce throughout the year. The famed English gardener, William Robinson remarked in his book, Parks and Gardens of Paris that, "The culture of salads for the Paris market is not merely good it is perfection." Using techniques dating back to the 1600s it was not unheard of for these gardens to produce asparagus in December; radishes, lettuces, and mushrooms in January; cauliflower in March; strawberries in early April; peas in May; and melons in June. Similar methods were employed for centuries by the gardeners and farmers of China. Unlike the use of row planting in "modern" vegetable gardens, which wastes an incredible amount of space, the gardeners of 19th century Paris maximized the production of their market gardens by using their limited space as efficiently as possible. A hallmark of these methods was the use of intensively planted, heavily amended raised beds. Somewhat forgotten with the advent of the "Green Revolution," raised beds found their way into American gardens through the work of Allan Chadwick at the Garden Project at the University of California at Santa Cruz. On a steep hillside above what was then the main entrance to the campus, Chadwick carved a veritable Eden out of heavy clay soils covered with native shrubs and poison oak. In early 1967 when he began his work at the Garden Project the soil was as hard as rock and no one could imagine the transformation it would undergo. Using techniques Chadwick described as "The Bio-dynamic French Intensive Method", techniques adapted from the French market gardeners of a century earlier, he and a core group of students began a remarkable process. Today, a visit to the Garden Project reveals amazingly productive soils that are easily worked with a garden fork. Every year, the garden produces an unbelievable abundance of vegetable crops and cut flowers. Like the market gardens of 19th century Paris, the key to the productivity of the Garden Project in Santa Cruz is the use of intensively planted raised beds. For many gardeners the mere mention of raised beds implies a massive construction project and a small fortune in wood, which steers many away from raised-bed gardening. In reality, that image could not be further from the truth. The French Intensive method does not require a vast investment in timber; the soil is raised simply through cultivation and the introduction of air into the soil. The French Intensive method only requires the gardener to shift from planting in rows (moved about from season to season) to planting in permanent beds. The beds become the focus of all soil-building efforts. In turn, the paths are made permanent and all the traffic in the garden is restricted to those paths. This allows the soil in the beds to undergo a remarkable transformation. Raise Your Beds Raised beds provide the gardener with a number of important benefits. By employing a method of deep cultivation, they mimic nature�s own soil dynamics of aeration and drainage. Raised beds drain readily, allowing earlier planting in the spring. At the same time they warm up faster, which encourages faster rooting and earlier growth and leads to earlier harvests. The soil is kept loose and well-aerated in raised beds so that the plants are able to establish more vigorous root systems and take advantage of a larger portion of the nutrients in the soil. Because the beds are never walked on, there is minimal compaction of the soil in the growing area, which results in better retention of soil structure.Studies show that the yield, when using this method, is four times the yield of traditional row planting because of the more efficient use of space in the garden. In his book, The Self Sufficient Gardener, John Seymour wrote of his own skepticism about the vast difference between the two methods: "I had read these figures but did not fully believe them. I went to California to see for myself...Seeing is believing and in this case I am completely convinced of the superiority of this method." Constructing raised beds is relatively simple. Traditionally they are constructed using a technique called "double digging."(see diagram) To begin, lay out a bed four to five feet wide�a good rule of thumb is to make the bed twice as wide as you can reach. The bed can be made as long as needed or as space allows. One important consideration when deciding on the length of the bed, however, is the time it will take you to walk around it; once established you should never walk on it. A convenient length for most people is 20 to 25 feet. Raised beds are often oriented to the south so that the plants in the bed get an even exposure to light as the sun moves from east to west. You can lay your beds out side by side with paths in between. Be sure your paths are wide enough to allow you to move comfortably around the beds. After marking out the area, lay a covering of manure or compost on top of the bed. (For vegetable gardens you could use Whitney Farms Barnyard Manure. If establishing beds for perennials or other plants, use our Uncle Malcolm's Planting Mix.) If needed you can also add lime or other fertilizers like Whitney Farms Vegetable Food to the bed at this time. To begin digging, simply dig a trench to a spade's depth and width. Set the soil from the trench aside in a wheelbarrow. Dig your spade or fork into the bottom of the trench and loosen the soil as deeply as you can; leave the large clods in the bottom of the trench to promote drainage. Some gardeners add more compost to the trench at this time to aid in loosening the deeper layers of soil. Working backwards down the length of the bed, dig out a second trench next to the first one and "slide" the soil and manure into the first trench. Do not invert the soil layers if possible�keep the topsoil on the surface and the subsoil below it. Work the bottom of the second trench as you did the first. From here move the third spade's width of soil into the second trench. Continue in this fashion until you reach the end of the bed. After loosening the soil in the bottom of the last trench fill it with the soil from the first trench. Looking down the length of your newly tilled bed, you will see that the soil has formed a rough mound. In fact, you may be surprised to find the soil much more raised than you imagined possible. To complete the process, use a digging fork to work the surface of the new bed, breaking up clods as you go. Use the fork in a lifting motion to bring clods to the surface�like sifting flour. A gentle side-to-side motion with the fork breaks the clods up into a finer texture. Don�t pound down onto the bed to break up the clods of soil, that only serves to compact the soil again. Rake any soil that falls onto the paths back up into the bed. These Paths Are Made For Walking From this point onward, NEVER WALK ON THE BED nor let anyone else walk on it. Always tend and work the bed from the paths. The only time you should walk on the bed again is if you are deep digging for another season. It is not necessary to double dig to form raised beds. You can also rototill the beds, leaving the paths untouched and raking any excess soil back up into the bed. Top-dress the bed with manure or compost as you would for double digging. Typically, however, tilling does not result in as loose or deeply prepared a bed as does hand digging and can leave a layer of compacted soil at the lower limits of the tiller depth. Rototilling can also lead to a pulverized soil texture if overdone. This in turn can lead to problems with drainage and aeration. Depending on the quality of your soil, one initial digging is often all that is required. To maintain the beds, simply dress them annually with compost, fertilizer, and lime as needed, and till them with your digging fork. Gardeners with heavy clay soils may need to double dig the beds for a couple of years to ensure that their improvements are permanent. Planting Raised Beds Perhaps the single biggest advantage of raised beds is the dense planting pattern they allow as compared to row plantings. Don't plant in traditional rows; instead work in a triangular pattern with your crops spaced in "clumps." The objective is to space the plants so that the leaves just touch when they are mature. The overall effect is to create diagonal rows of closely spaced plants that waste no soil in the bed. Because the soil is so deeply prepared and traffic is limited to the paths, plants grown using raised beds typically develop much more vigorous root systems, which allows for denser planting. There are several other benefits that result from using a dense planting pattern. Because the leaves of the plants just touch when mature, they create a micro-climate within the bed. Weeds are suppressed by the shading of the crop plants, and because the soil is so loose, any that grow in the bed are easily removed. You will also find that the garden will use less water than a traditional "row garden" because of the shading of the soil surface. When seeding raised beds: Sow them heavily and thin the seedlings after germination to allow for the mature plants to just touch as outlined above. Direct sowing plants like carrots or radishes in a raised bed will result in significantly higher yields in a very small area as compared to sowing seeds in rows. Unlimited Applications Raised beds are easily adapted for use throughout the garden. The same methods can be extended to preparing areas for planting annual flowers, bulbs, perennials, roses, and other shrubs. Even trees can be planted using this technique. In all cases your garden and the plants growing in it will benefit from the richly prepared soil. The time and energy required to transform your garden will be paid back immeasurably by the increased yields and the ease of maintaining raised beds. [BACK] | [FORWARD] WT01-B08-144IA069-000435-B028-245http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/maydirt2.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174951 text/html 5939HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:49:57 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:25:26 GMTETag: "e0bb8-1642-31ae2056"Content-Length: 5698Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Container Gardening Many gardeners today are hard pressed to find the time and space for a full-blown vegetable garden. However, these limits need not constrain the resourceful gardener. Raising vegetables in containers, whether they are old buckets or fine pottery, is the answer to the apartment dweller or small-lot suburbanite who yearns for fresh homegrown veggies. Container gardening saves time in soil preparation and weeding; containers can be placed virtually anywhere and can be moved easily to take advantage of available light and heat. Gardeners with soil-borne disease problems will find containers indispensible. Theoretically, any vegetable can be grown in a container, given proper care. As a practical matter some vegetables are more rewarding when raised in the confines of a container. Moreover, some are more attractive and have neater growth habits, making them more suitable for visible locations on a deck or patio. Generally, those that have compact growth habits and yield abundant veggies that are far superior in flavor to store-bought kinds bring the most satisfying results. A rich, water-retentive potting soil like Whitney Farms Premium Potting Soil or Whitney Farms Uncle Malcolm's Potting Soil is best because most vegetables need a steady supply of water and nutrients. Light but frequent fertilizing with Ellie's Ultimate Plant Food (Fish and Kelp) or a tea made from composted manure or Whitney Farms Fruit and Flower Booster will ensure adequate nutrients for the entire growing season. The all-natural ingredients are released slowly and will not leach out with the frequent watering that containers need in the summer. An all-organic mix like Whitney Farms' Uncle Malcolm's Potting Soil will work great for the following suggested vegetables: Tomatoes- Several dwarf and compact types will stay small yet produce big crops in a small container. "Patio" is an old standby for small containers. You can try your favorite larger varieties in appropriately sized containers. A whiskey barrel works well for beefsteak types. Eggplant- Be sure to place these in a hot location for best results. Try the flavorful Japanese varieties in cool summer areas. Peppers- These attractive plants double as ornamentals even before peppers ripen. Leaf lettuce- Be sure to keep evenly moist; use blood meal for rapid growth in cool soil. Scallions- Easy to grow; great value when compared to what supermarkets charge for them. Garlic- Plant cloves the previous autumn for earliest harvest. Bush beans- Go easy on the nitrogen for this and other legumes. Bush cucumbers- Try training one up a trellis for further space savings and increased production. As a rule, select a container at least 12 inches across and 18 inches deep. Smaller containers will suffice for shallow rooted veggies like lettuce, scallions and small peppers. Cool Veggies Are you bored with beets and beans, tired of plain tomatoes, sick of zucchini? Well, the editors of The Dirt have compiled a list of cool vegetables certain to stimulate the most jaded vegetable gardener.Now, we don't mean just those vegetables that do best during the cool months of spring and autumn. We're talking about vegetables with attitude, that break the rules, and will have your neighbors wondering what you're up to. As with people, cool in vegetables is hard to pin down, but you know it when you see it. The following list is based upon the vegetable's distinctive flavor, and not least of all, its appearance. Kohlrabi-These otherworldly cabbage relatives look like they could be alien beings from a B movie. They also bear a startling resemblance to the first satellite launched into space, Sputnik. Kohlrabi have a flavor similar to water chestnuts but of course are far fresher and sweeter than what you get at the store. Kohlrabi are easy to grow because the edible portion, a bulbous stem, grows above the ground, beyond the reach of soil-borne insects and diseases. They even come in an extra-cool purple variety. Heirloom tomatoes- Upscale nurseries and catalogs have featured "old" tomato varieties for several years now, which makes them more than a fad. And for good reason. These varieties are unsurpassed for flavor and texture, even if they can�t match modern hybrids for productivity and shelf-life. An example: "Brandywine," the classic Amish variety, has the cachet of their devotion to the old ways, which include, incidentally, an unwavering adherence to organic farming principles and techniques. Popcorn-You can grow your own popcorn to eat while you watch a movie starring Kohlrabi. Kids will get a kick out of stomping the dry kernels off the cobs� a fast, fun way of processing large quantities! Colorful potatoes and peppers-Better garden centers will now offer yellow and blue varieties of potatoes as well as the more familiar red ones. You can grow bell peppers that ripen to purple, yellow, orange and red. The purple peppers will turn green when cooked, however. [BACK] | [FORWARD]WT01-B08-145IA069-000435-B028-273http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/maydirt3.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175000 text/html 5296HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:50:08 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:25:30 GMTETag: "e0bb9-13bf-31ae205a"Content-Length: 5055Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Beans + bacteria=nitrogen for your garden Beans and others members of the legume family are nature's subtle way of supplying nitrogen to the vegetable garden. Working with specialized bacteria known as rhizobia, legumes convert pure nitrogen in the atmosphere to an ammonia form that is immediately available in the soil. With sufficient rhizobia, legumes will produce a reserve of nitrogen that will be available for a succeeding crop. Each kind of legume� vegetables such as beans and peas, and cover crops such as clover and vetch�respond best to different species of rhizobia. You can ask at your local garden center for rhizobia innoculant for each specific crop, or use a general purpose innoculant. Another option, which the editors of the Dirt shamelessly promote, is to add copious amounts of high-quality compost, which is naturally full of rhizobia and other beneficial microbes, as well as the phosphorus necessary for good root growth and flower production. The origins of Corn Corn has been raised in North America for over 800 years. Bred from wild grasses, it was developed by Mesoamerican farmers around 7000 years ago, probably in Mexico. As aboriginal farmers spread north and south, new strains of Zea mays or maize (as corn is known) were selected to adapt to different soils, pests, moisture levels and growing seasons. Today, modern high-yield hybrids have replaced the traditional varieties. Corn is totally dependent upon humans for its continued existence. If humans were to stop planting and harvesting corn, it would disappear. As one scientist reports in a recent article in Smithsonian (November 1995), "Corn's seeds, the kernels, grow embedded in cobs. The stay pressed together when the cob falls to the ground, inhibiting one another's growth. �Over time, reproduction stops. The only reason we have corn today is that for thousands of years humans have selected seeds and planted them." We are as dependent on the ancient varieties of corn today as our forebears were hundreds of years ago. Why? We depend on the genetic diversity of the maize plants of the ancients to provide stability to the modern agricultural corn field. In fact, in 1970 an outbreak of Southern corn leaf blight killed 15 percent of the U.S. corn crop, reminding us of how fragile are the monocultures upon which we depend for our food. The Three Sisters Ancient farmers in the Americas practiced a unique form of intercropping known as the "Three Sisters." For example, in upstate New York, the Iroquois used a variation of this system to produce crops for over 400 years. The ancient farmers would girdle the trees in a field. After the trees had died, they would burn the field using the ash as a fertilizer. A few kernels of corn would be planted in a hole. After the corn sprouted, the area would be weeded and the soil mounded up around the young corn stalks. Two weeks or so after they planted the corn, the Iroquois farmers would then plant two or three bean seeds. Between the corn and bean "mounds" they would also plant pumpkins or other squash. As the plants grew, these Three Sisters worked together. The broad leaves of the squash plants shaded the soil and suppressed weeds. Bacteria living in the roots of the beans converted atmospheric nitrogen into a form that the plants could use. The corn provided the beans with a framework to grow on.At harvest, the Iroquois farmers would leave the debris in the fields to enrich the soil. As the bean plants rotted, the soil was enriched with nitrogen. The following season, the mounds were replanted using the same system. As the fields became worn with time, the planting area was moved and the old ground allowed to regenerate. When measured in bushels of corn produced the native practices were not as productive as modern agricultural techniques: 25-40 bushels per acre compared to modern yields of over 100 bushels to the acre. But the Iroquois did not raise corn alone. When the combined output of the corn, beans, and squash are measured by comparing the overall caloric production, the traditional system produces over 4.02 million calories per acre as compared to the modern cornfield's production of only 3.44 million calories per acre. That modern number is further reduced when one factors in the caloric content of the fuels, fertilizers, and pesticides required to produce a bushel of corn in the modern world. [BACK] | [FORWARD]WT01-B08-146IA069-000435-B028-303http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/maydirt4.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175008 text/html 6183HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:50:16 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:25:34 GMTETag: "e0bba-1736-31ae205e"Content-Length: 5942Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Fertilizer at the speed of light! Only nature can deliver fertilizer with more style than Whitney Farms. In fact, nature brings it to the garden in a flash� of lightning, that is. Lightning forces nitrogen in the atmosphere to combine with oxygen to form nitrogen oxides. When rain washes nitrogen oxide out of the air, it eventually produces nitrogen in the soil that plants can use for leafy growth. However, Whitney Farms is far more predictable than thunderstorms, even if wecan'tmatch nature's dramatic display. Mucky Myth of the Month In our continuing quest to debunk gardening myths, the editors of the Dirt now turn their attention to the persistent belief that sand is a beneficial and desirable soil amendment. Like many myths, this one contains an element of truth that is the genesis of the mistaken belief. First, in a man-made potting soil or in small localized areas, sand is a perfectly acceptable ingredient for promoting adequate drainage. However, in a garden that has clay soil, sand is the last thing to add to improve drainage over a large area. Sand is a binding agent. If you add sand to most clay soils, you will end up creating a low-grade concrete. For an acre of clay garden soil you would have to add more than a million pounds of sand to beneficially change the soil structure in the top six inches! A far better solution to poorly drained clay soils is to add ample amounts of good compost. We suggest Whitney Farms Planting Mix or Mushroom Compost come to mind. In addition to improving soil structure by making the clay become granular in texture, the compost will stimulate soil organisms and add essential plant nutrients. Fruit or Vegetable? The quandry continues It is prominent among life's great questions. Experts in the fields of law, science, and business have wracked their brains over it for centuries. It is the subject of heated debate at the dinner table, across backyard fences and in neighborhood bars. It has even reached the United States Supreme Court.The question is this: Is a tomato a fruit or vegetable or what? The editors of the Dirt have found the definitive answer to this weighty matter to be as elusive as a blight-resistant tomato. As the Supreme Court decided decades ago, the tomato is generally accepted and understood, according to its common usage, to be a vegetable, and therefore should be classified and taxed as such.On the other hand, many gardeners will insist that because it grows on a vine it must be a fruit, like grapes or kiwi. They also rightly point out that the part of a flowering plant that holds seeds is technically a fruit. Webster's Dictionary takes the middle road, defining the tomato as "a widely cultivated solanaceous plant, native to South America, bearing a slightly acid, pulpy fruit, commonly red, sometimes yellow, used as a vegetable; the fruit itself." Botanists go further still, and classify the fruit of the tomato plant as a berry. That�s right, a berry, because of its fleshy pulp and numerous small seeds. So there you have it. A tomato is different things to different people. What almost everyone can agree on is that they are versatile, delicious, and easy to grow. Now what are we to make of rhubarb, an ornamental vegetable with poisonous leaves and roots with edible stems that are used as a fruit in pies? Now to address a practical question: Where do you find a blight-resistant tomato? The insidious and rampant fungal disease known as blight is a persistent problem of tomato growing. The form known as late blight is particularly devastating, striking with little warning just as harvest begins. An airborne fungus, late blight often hits after a prolonged warm, humid spell in mid-summer.An organic fungicide, such as copper or sulfur spray, applied before the fungus spores land on the plant, can prevent the disease from taking hold. However, once the plant is infected, the disease spreads rapidly, spoiling the entire crop. Some growers find that a row cover can prevent infection, while others advocate pruning to open up the plant and improve air circulation. The editors of the Dirt are anxious to know if some tomato varieties are more blight- resistant than others. Readers are encouraged to share their experience either throughe-mail or by letter. A note from the President Fresh vegetables. I was speaking with a grouch the other morning about gardening. He claimed that he had never planted a vegetable garden because the economics didn't make sense. "Why garden when I can go down to the grocery story and buy ten ears of corn for a dollar?" he said. "I can't grow corn that cheap." He misses the point. For most of us, gardening is not about dollars and cents. It's about that series of small successes we all look forward to. For the vegetable gardener, it's also about taste. There is little more satisfying than a plate of fresh vegetables from your own back yard in the late summer. The difference in taste between store-bought and home-grown is dramatic. Grow your own! John D. Graham [BACK] | [FORWARD]WT01-B08-147IA069-000435-B028-336http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/jundirt.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175019 text/html 16594HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:50:24 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Fri, 26 Jul 1996 22:13:44 GMTETag: "bf918-3fe0-31f94318"Content-Length: 16352Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt June July Issue June/July Issue Moles:Rebels with claws It's been said that organic gardening is 10 percent technical and 90 percent psychological. That observation is especially accurate when it comes to the concept of beneficial organisms. Sometimes all a gardener needs to do is change their perception of a supposed pest to turn it into an ally. Take moles, for instance. Many gardeners see them only as destructive critters that leave unsightly mounds of soil in their otherwise perfect lawns. In addition, moles can uproot young plants, possibly killing them if not replanted promptly. However, moles have an important role in maintaining soil health. Their tunneling helps improve soil structure and drainage. Inspect the soil in a mole mound sometime. A rototiller couldn't do a better job of aerating heavy wet soil. Also, moles are primarily insect eaters. Only rarely do they nibble on plant roots. While they do eat the gardeners favorite soil dweller, earthworms, moles also eat grubs that cause serious damage to grass roots.So rather than declare war on moles with traps, poison gas and other weapons, consider enlisting them as biological subsoil's. The money and time spent on killing them could be just as well applied to replanting their mounds. Or on controlling slugs, a slimy, voracious creature with no known redeeming qualities, unless you're a French raccoon. Natural Lawn Care:The way to grow In the United States lawns occupy more land than any single crop including wheat, corn or tobacco. Homeowners use ten times more chemical pesticides per acre than farmers do, much of it on lawns. The average American homeowner will spend 40 hours a year behind a lawn mower. By practicing a more natural approach gardeners have found that they can have a great looking lawn with less work and vastly reduced inputs! Here are some of our ideas on how to have an easy-to-care-for and beautiful lawn. While most of the information applies to cool season grasses (Ryes, Bluegrass, Fescue, etc.) much of it can apply to warm season grasses as well. Make The Cut A healthy, easy-care lawn begins with the right mowing height. Proper mowing height is critical to the health of your lawn. Only about 5% of turf grass nutrition is derived from the soil; the other 95% is taken in through the blades as carbon, hydrogen, oxygen. Grass blades exist to convert energy from sunlight into sugars, starches and plant fibers that the grass plant then uses for growth. The food manufactured in the blades of the grass is used for both the top growth and the root growth.When you mow you reduce the ability of the grass plant to manufacture food, and thereby to form strong roots. The shorter you mow, the less the roots will grow. Deep roots are the key to a healthy, drought resistant lawn. Mow lightly and frequently. Mow the lawn when the grass is dry, and only remove 1/3 of the blade length at any given time. If you remove more than 40% of the grass blade the roots stop growing. The grass should always look green even after you cut it. Generally, if the lawn is yellow or brown after mowing, you are cutting too short. The shorter you cut the longer it will take the roots to begin growing again. At worst, if you cut too close, the grass roots may never grow again. Clippings 1/2 inch or smaller can be left on the lawn, and will help to reduce thatch buildup and help to provide your lawn with valuable nutrients. Many homeowners worry that longer blades will mean a less attractive lawn. In reality, the look of a lawn is determined by how even the grass is mown, not how long the blades are. In fact, according to Stuart Franklin in his book "Building a Healthy Lawn,"a taller lawn will actually require less mowing than a lawn kept shorter. In addition, the taller turf grass will shade out many sun loving weeds. Lawns that are mown too short will require more work and result in a sickly hard-to-manage lawn.Mowing heights for most cool season grasses (Perennial Rye, Bluegrass, Fescue, etc.) will vary with the season as the grass grows at different rates throughout the year. Start mowing when the grass begins to grow in the spring. As a general guideline, cut the lawn shorter in spring (the actual height will vary with the kind of grass you are growing). This removes dead grass and increases the penetration of sunlight to newly forming blades. A short cutting in early spring also helps to invigorate the grass and will aid in warming the soil sooner. After this initial cutting, set the mower at around two inches for the next few mowings until the lawn begins to grow vigorously. By mowing higher you encourage the grass to thicken and grow new tillers, stolons, or rhizomes. Allow lawns of cool season grasses to grow longer in the summer months�in the range of 3 to 4 inches. A higher mowing height helps to improve the growth of the lawn and to shade the soil which aids in reducing water use and helps to suppress weeds. Keep the mower set high into the fall. This allows the grass to replenish its store of nutrients in the roots. In late fall, after the leaves drop from deciduous trees, gradually reduce the mowing height again to 1-1/2 inches. Remember, never remove more than 1/3 of the blade length. Regardless of the time of year, the lawn should always still be green after mowing. There is some evidence to show that by varying mowing heights through the year you may actually improve the drought resistance of your lawn.Leave the clippings. One of the great myths of lawn care is that clippings cause thatch. Research has definitively shown this to be untrue (see sidebar). In fact, by leaving short clippings on the lawn (1/2 inch or finer) up to 40% of the lawns annual fertilizer needs can be met. In one study at the University of Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, researchers observed that, "You didn't need any fancy instruments to see the difference. Where the clippings were left, the plots were much greener." The research shows that clippings begin to break down within a week, and by the end of two weeks the nitrogen from the clippings is available to the growing grass. Grass-cycling can contribute significantly to the annual fertilizer needs of the lawn and helps to improve the soil and retain moisture. The only exceptions would be for lawns suffering from some diseases like red thread or rust, for lawns with heavy infestations of weeds with mature seed heads, and during times of the year when clippings may be too wet or excessively long. Finally, remember to keep the blades of your mower sharp to reduce incidences of disease. Mowing lawns when they are dry will also help to reduce the spread of some diseases, limit the compaction of the soil, and aid in a cleaner cut and more even spread of the clippings. Pick the Right Fertilizer A second component of easy-care lawn practices is the use of slow release, natural organic lawn foods with an approximate nutrient ratio of 3-1-2 like our Whitney Farms Natural Organic Lawn Food (8-2-4) or Lawn Food Plus Iron (6-2-4). Remember, your lawn is only as good as the soil it grows in. Good nutrition improves turf performance and disease resistance. Slow release natural organic fertilizers are less likely to contribute to thatch buildup, and do not acidify the soil or cause a decline in the population of earthworms and other microbes in the soil. Unlike many forms of synthetic nitrogen, natural sources do not cause the lawn to grow too quickly. In addition, the iron sulfate in our Lawn Food Plus Iron contributes to the growth and color of your lawn while it also helps to increase the drought and disease resistance of your lawn and discourages moss. By comparison, chemical or synthetic fertilizers can release their nutrients too quickly contributing to thatch buildup and causing over vigorous growth that means more mowing. Also, because these types of fertilizers can contain extremely soluble forms of nutrients they tend to leach away during periods of heavy rainfall or irrigation particularly on sandy soils. Research at Alabama Polytechnic University showed that up to half of the soluble nitrogen applied to the soil will be leached out and unavailable to plants. This can contribute to the contamination of groundwater and waterways. At the same time, because synthetic fertilizers are by definition salt based, you are much more likely to burn the lawn if they are accidentally over�applied or you are not able to water soon after application. Furthermore, because of their reliance on sulfate of ammonia many chemical lawn foods are actually extremely acidifying leading to the need for applications of lime to counteract the lower soil pH caused by the repeated use of acid forming fertilizers. Additionally, there is some evidence that repeated use of salt based synthetic fertilizers can result in the destruction of soil microbes which in turn contributes to the loss of soil structure and thatch build up. As Elliot Roberts, director of the Lawn Institute, has said, "We've found that the grass plant is a very efficient user of nitrogen" The more chemicals you use, the more you disturb the natural biological processes that convert organic matter into nutrients to keep the lawn growing since you get heavily involved with chemical fertilizers, you�re increasing the growth rate of the plant and growing it to death." Grass grown with chemical fertilizers can often grow so quickly and require such frequent mowing that the plant is unable to store carbohydrates which ultimately leads to a reduction in the root growth of the plant. Ultimately this weakens the lawn making it more susceptible to drought stress during hot weather, diseases, and weed invasions. Through the use of natural organic sources of nutrients and through the practice of grass-cycling, or leaving the clippings, it is likely that you will be able to significantly reduce the amount of fertilizer needed to keep your lawn looking its best. Most lawns require between 2-4 pounds of nitrogen per thousand square feet per year, with as much as 4-6 pounds required for lawns on very poor soils, to look their best. Clippings alone can contribute almost 2 pounds of nitrogen per thousand square feet per year. With this in mind, it is evident that is not necessary to feed as often as many companies would have you use their products in order for your lawn to look its best. In fact, research at Oregon State University has shown that over time using organic fertilizers for feeding your lawn will actually result in nutrients building up in the soil, something that the research has not shown with synthetic fertilizers. Feed Your Lawn in the Fall Proper timing is essential to feeding the lawn for the best results. Feed your lawn every fall sometime from late September through mid-October in areas with milder climates. The fall feeding is the most important feeding for cool season grasses. During the fall, the grass plant is storing nutrients that will support the growth in the spring. By feeding late in the season, but while the soil is still warm, you will stimulate the root growth and food production in your grass. The other ideal time to feed again is in the spring about the time the initial growth spurt is beginning to slow down. Your lawn has now used up all of the reserves stored the previous fall and is feeding itself. Fertilizing at this time helps to support that process. If you intend to keep your lawn watered and green through the heat of summer another feeding, if needed, in late May will help the lawn to thrive through the hot summer months. This application should be made at least 30 days prior to the onset of hot weather. Do not feed the lawn in the summer. The growth of cool season grasses slows down in the heat of summer, and all you end up feeding are the weeds which thrive in summer heat and will often out compete the grass for nutrients during hot weather. Dress Your Lawn Once a year, top dress with compost. Add a thin layer of up to 3/8 of an inch of a finely screened, unsterilized compost, like Whitney Farms Peat Humus or Mushroom Compost, to your lawn to help control thatch and improve the soil, as well as to discourage diseases. Dr. Eric B. Nelson reported as early as 1990 in the trade publication "Lawn Care Industry" that, "Research at Cornell University with the use of compost and organic fertilizers has indicated the potential to suppress diseases such as brown patch, dollar sport, typhula blight, pythium blight and root rot, and red thread by topdressing with some of these materials." The fall is probably the best time of year to top dress your lawn, but top dressing is also recommended anytime after aerating or thatching your lawn. Deep Water, Deep Roots Another critical component of natural lawn care is proper watering. Water your lawn deeply and infrequently. Many gardeners make the mistake of watering the lawn with short, shallow waterings for a few minutes every day. There is ample evidence to show that lawns are more tolerant of drought and have deeper root systems when watered deeply, less often. A simple test to see if your lawn needs water is to simply walk on it. If your footprints spring back, the lawn has adequate moisture. If your footprints stay depressed, it is time to water. Apply enough water to wet your soil to a depth of eight or more inches once or twice a week as needed. Check the pH of your lawn periodically and add lime when needed. A slightly acid pH (around 6.5) ensures the optimum availability of most nutrients and good microbial activity which results in better nutrient availability and reduced thatch buildup. Fall is ideal for lime applications, but spring is acceptable as well. Depending on your local climate it may be necessary to lime as often as every year or so. From time to time your lawn will require some additional maintenance. Some older lawns may require thatching (see accompanying sidebar). Thatch is a build up of roots and stems that inhibits moisture penetration, encourages diseases, and interferes with fertilizer availability. Thatch is typically caused by fast acting, soluble nitrogen which encourages excessive growth and kills soil microbes; mowing at too short a height which keeps the roots near surface, as does watering too often and too shallow. Pesticides and fungicides can also kill off soil life like earthworms slowing the decomposition of roots, stems, and clippings and contributing to a build up of thatch. Using the practices outlined above can often completely eliminate the need for dethatching. Through normal wear and tear your lawn will become compacted and require aeration from time to time. Aeration helps to improve the exchange of air between the soil and the atmosphere vital for healthy plant growth. It will also enhance the breakdown of thatch and will help to reduce water runoff and puddling. Aeration helps to improve rooting and fertilizer and water uptake, and while it also enhances heat and drought tolerance. Ideally, aeration should be followed with a top dressing of compost and a fertilizer. Most problems lawns face, from moss to problems with insects and diseases, can be dramatically reduced through the use of more natural methods to maintain your lawn. Consequently you can avoid using harsh and toxic chemicals to achieve a beautiful and sustainable lawn that will be the envy of the neighborhood. [BACK] | [FORWARD] WT01-B08-148IA069-000435-B029-35http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/jundirt2.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175037 text/html 6408HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:50:44 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Fri, 26 Jul 1996 22:13:49 GMTETag: "bf919-1817-31f9431d"Content-Length: 6167Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt June July Issue June/July Issue Free fertilizer through grass-cycling Everyone enjoys a well-kept lawn for recreation and good looks. In time, however, the monoculture of grass known as a lawn can become boring. As we all know, variety is the spice of life, and that old saying applies to landscape design as much as anything else. Variety in the landscape has benefits beyond the aesthetic. Mixed plantings attract birds and beneficial insects that prey on pests. Diverse landscapes, which are based on a healthy soil full of organic compost that stimulates earthworms and other helpful little critters, will also function as ecosystems that are less vulnerable to diseases and more self-regulating than a mono- culture. In a stable ecosystem, natural controls prevent problems from getting out of hand, fertilizer needs are reduced and herbicides are unnecessary. A gardener can promote diversity within a lawn by using a seed mix that includes flowers such as lawn daisies, Roman chamomile, yarrow and clover. Several years of research at Oregon State University have led to the development of such "Eco-Lawns," mixes that stand up to foot traffic, need minimal maintenance and are pleasing to look at. A gardener could also consider replacing some lawn area with beds along the edge, or with "islands" of desirable flowers, shrubs or trees. Of course, a well-planned and maintained water garden will also attract birds and possibly frogs and toads. A visit to a quality garden center can reveal the unlimited possibilities for enriching the environment with thoughtful garden design. Grass substitutes for problem areas Sometimes, despite a gardener's best efforts to improve the soil and care for the grass, their lawn fails to thrive. Insufficient light is often the cause of the problem. Other times the location is too hot or steep to keep well-watered and fertilized. On such sites a gardener is well-advised to consider low-maintenance alternatives to turfgrass. The following plants are excellent choices for difficult locations. For shade: Vinca minor-Best choice for dry soil, has periwinkle blue flowers. Pachysandra-Spreads quickly through underground runners but is not invasive;thrives in acid soil. Creeping Oregon grape-Yellow flowers and blue berries against holly-like leaves make this Oregon state flower attractive year-round. Sword fern-A tough fern that tolerates some sun and looks good through winter. Sweet woodruff-A pleasant aroma and profuse white flowers add to this rapid grower's charm. Hostas-Lush yet elegant appearance, dozens of varieties and easy care make hostas a popular choice for shade. Lily Turf-Ideal for use around ponds and the edge of streams, best with well-drained soil and light feeding. Wintergreen-Large scarlet berries really light up dark areas, needs woodland soil conditions. Sarccococca humilis-Also known as Himalayan box, it is fragrant in bloom and always a polished dark green. For Sun: Kinnickinnick-Thrives on steep slopes and meager but well-drained soil. Very cold hardy. Willowleaf cotoneaster-The most graceful of the cotoneasters, and as tough as any. Blue rug juniper-Flattest juniper, intense blue-green color. Must have well-drained soil and full sun. Roman Chamomile-Delightful apple-like fragrance, profuse daisy-like flowers; can be mowed to make a sweet-smelling pathway. Mother of Thyme-Spicy fragrance, pink flowers, excellent between stepping stones. Creeping rosemary-Good over walls and on slopes. Tolerates heat, but not cold. Hardy to about 18 degrees F. Rockrose-Attractive grey-green foliage and long bloom period. A fire-resistant favorite in California, rockrose tolerates salt spray, ocean winds and desert heat. Free fertilizer through grass-cycling Grass clippings are the largest source of landscape waste in most yards. Yet leaving the clippings on the lawn, or grass-cycling, is healthier for the lawn than removing them. Grass-cycling recycles nutrients and reduces fertilizer needs often contributing almost half of the lawns annual nitrogen needs. Grass cycling also adds organic matter which rejuvenates the soil and helps to conserve moisture, and it saves the time and expense of bags and collection fees. Many mowers are now designed to chop clippings into tiny pieces and blow them down into the turf. Inexpensive mulching blades and conversion kits for older mowers are also available to convert older rotary mowers for mulching . Most real-type and push mowers cut clippings small enough so that they can be left on the lawn. Grass-cycling with any mower requires more frequent, light mowing, but each mowing takes less time without bagging and disposing of clippings. The key to successful grass-cycling is to mow often and leave fine clippings on the lawn. CLIPPINGSRETURNED More earthworms Softer Turf Higher Soil Moisture & Improved Drought Resistance Greener During Winter Months Less Moss in Turf More Poa annua (26%) CLIPPINGSREMOVED Fewer earthworms Harder Turf Very poor moisture; lawns dry out quickly Browns During Winter months More Moss in Turf Less Poa annua (6%) [BACK] | [FORWARD] WT01-B08-149IA069-000435-B029-66http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/jundirt3.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175050 text/html 7030HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:50:57 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Fri, 26 Jul 1996 22:13:54 GMTETag: "bf91a-1a85-31f94322"Content-Length: 6789Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt June July Issue June/July Issue Myth of the Month Many gardeners mistakenly believe that leaving clippings on the lawn will cause a problem with thatch. This could not be further from the truth. Here is June's Myth of the Month. What is Thatch? Thatch is a naturally occurring layer of partially decomposed dead stems and roots that builds up beneath some grasses. High in lignin, these parts of the grass plant are slow to decompose. Some thatch is normal; up to 1/2 inch of thatch is typical for many species of grass and acts almost like a mulch for the lawn. A layer of thatch thicker than 1/2 inch, on the other hand, can mean problems for the lawn. In severe situations thatch can inhibit the ability of water and nutrients to reach the soil below, and can actually slow the growth of your lawn. It also provides a breeding ground for insects and can harbor diseases harmful to your lawn. In cases where the thatch layer becomes really thick it can also result in the lawn actually growing in the thatch layer on top of the soil. This in turn can make the lawn much more susceptible to dehydration, frost damage, insect attack, and damage from traffic over the lawn. Most experts have come to agree that the surest way to create a thatch problem in your lawn is to over-fertilize with quick release nitrogen like sulfate of ammonia, a common ingredient of many synthetic lawn foods. Grass clippings do not except under very unusual circumstances contribute to the buildup of thatch. Thatch is caused by the excessive use of soluble fertilizers which cause grass to grow too vigorously, resulting in a buildup of roots and stems that can�t decompose fast enough. These types of fertilizers can also have a detrimental effect on soil life and can inhibit the very species that would normally help to break down the thatch before it could become a problem. Other factors that contribute to the formation of thatch include: mowing too short, which keeps the roots close to the surface; frequent light watering which keep only the top of the soil moist and the roots close to the surface; overuse of pesticides and fungicides which suppress soil life like earthworms�an important contributor to the natural control of thatch. To tell if your lawn has a thatch problem, take a close look at your lawn. As you walk out onto it does it feel spongy and springy? This could be a sign of a thatch problem. Next, stick your finger down into the turf. If you feel soil right away, you have no thatch layer. If instead you feel a spongy layer, take a closer look. Dig a small hole in your lawn (you can replace the sod, just like repairing a divot at the golf course) and take a look at the cross section of the grass. Bring along a ruler. It should be easy to see the soil layer and the grass growing above it. If you see a brown or tan underlying layer of straw-like material between the soil and the grass, measure it. This is the thatch layer. If it is more than half an inch thick, it is time to take action. To rid your lawn of thatch, follow a few simple guidelines. First, while getting the thatch under control, catch your clippings. (Otherwise, in most cases you should leave fine clippings of less that 1/2 inch to help feed your lawn with valuable nutrients.) Aerate your lawn with a core aerator. After aerating, top dress your lawn with up to 1/4 inch of finely screened compost, like Whitney Farms Peat Humus or Mushroom Compost. This will help to revitalize your lawn with microorganisms and contribute to the decay of the thatch. Also, using natural fertilizers like Whitney Farms Lawn Food can help to add beneficial organisms to your lawn. Change your mowing practices and your watering habits (see the accompanying article).In severe cases, it may be necessary to de-thatch your lawn using a thatch rake or a power rake or vertical mower. This is best done in the fall before mid-October and may require over-seeding to help the lawn fill back in. Help! I need some water! For many lawns, particular those grown with cool season varieties of turf grass, the hot days of summer can be particularly stressful. A number of steps can be taken to ensure that your lawn is ready to withstand the heat and to prepare it for the fall. Here are some steps recommended by the Turf Resource Center in Rolling Meadows, IL: Thirty days before the anticipated arrival of hot weather, reduce or eliminate fertilizer. Fertilizers encourage lush growth that does not withstand the high summer temperatures very well and can increase the amount of water the lawn requires. Weed killing herbicides can also place the grass under stress that reduces its rate of growth. Infrequent, deep watering encourages deeper root growth. Most lawns will need around an inch of water per week, though exactly how much will vary with your soil texture. Sandy soils will require more frequent watering but will not need as much water each time to ensure a deep watering, while clay soils will require water less often but more water at each application to penetrate more deeply into the soil.In early fall, a number of steps can be taken to improve the health of your lawn for the winter and next summer. Aerating and thatching followed by an application of a slow release fertilizer (like our Whitney Farms Lawn Food) a couple of weeks later will greatly enhance the performance of your lawn in the coming months. If you find yourself in an area where severe watering restrictions are enacted during the summer months it does not necessarily mean an end to your lawn. If you have taken the steps outlined above, allowing your lawn to go dormant (the natural response to extremes of temperature) and turn golden brown is an acceptable solution. As the heat subsides and the water restrictions are eased, start watering deeply again. Once the lawn re-establishes its health, you can begin to reduce mowing heights again, and if needed weed control measures can be taken. If you would like more information from the Turf Resource Center you can contact them at 800-405-TURF. [BACK] | [FORWARD] WT01-B08-150IA069-000435-B029-87http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/jundirt4.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175057 text/html 4788HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:51:06 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Fri, 26 Jul 1996 22:13:57 GMTETag: "bf91b-11c3-31f94325"Content-Length: 4547Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt June July Issue June/July Issue Controlling Moss For many of our customers who live in more humid regions, like the Pacific Northwest, moss can be a particular problem in the lawn. Controlling moss is relatively simple, but may require some changes in the garden. Generally moss is favored by thin lawns (see our hints on lawn care), poor drainage, shade, and acid soil conditions. To get existing moss problems under control you can use existing commercial formulations or use Whitney Farms Iron Sulfate. Broadcast it over the mossy areas according to the rates on the label, or dissolve three ounces of Iron Sulfate in five gallons of water to treat 1000 sq. ft. The treated moss will turn black and can be raked out of the lawn. Overseed thin areas if needed. Unless steps are taken to correct the conditions that favored the moss you will soon have moss again. If necessary, prune or trim trees and shrubs to increase light and air flow to the area. Aerate the lawn to correct compaction; improve the soil drainage if needed. Use shade tolerate varieties of turf grass in shady areas. Reduce frequency of irrigation. Avoid over-fertilization with soluble forms of nitrogen. Increase mowing height to around three inches and mow as frequently as is required to remove less that 1/3 of the blade length at each cutting. Still More on Planting Trees... or a reader stakes his reputation on correcting one of our oversights We recently received a letter from a reader in Illinois reminding us of an omission in our tree planting instructions in our premier issue. Mr. Tom Vorbeck wrote to remind us that there are instances when stakes are absolutely indispensable�planting fruit trees on dwarfing rootstocks, particularly apples on M7, M7A, and EMLA-7 rootstocks. Mr. Vorbeck has a great deal of experience with these trees and reminds us that they require staking to withstand windstorms particularly when they are young and soils are wet. Along with the M7 rootstock and it's relatives, apples planted on M26, M9, Mark and EMLA 27 must be staked at planting as well. Mr. Vorbeck included in his letter an article he had just written for an apple grower's newsletter in which he makes the following recommendations, "You can plant a2" x 2" x 8' pole with the tree at planting time." He warns that whatever you use should be a minimum of 2" x 2" and should be of a material that will last up to three years in the soil. "Lesser quality stakes," he continues, "will keep the tree from getting loose in the ground. But lesser quality stakes will increase the risk of catastrophe in years four and five in which the winds snap off the stakes and the tree at its bud union." He notes that a number of varieties in his orchard have "been nearly immune" to getting loose on M7. Specifically he notes Jonagold, Mutsu, and Spigold. He warns that all of his Blushing Goldens on M7 got loose. He also observes that trees planted in soil that had been tilled for crops the previous season stayed better anchored than trees planted into sod. The good news is that trees planted with a stake "grow taller and bear younger." The editors of The Dirt encourage readers to stake loosely to allow some movement so that the trunk and root systems are encouraged to develop through the natural swaying motion of the tree.In most cases trees on M7 and its relatives will only require staking for the first three to five years. Trees on M26 and Mark will require staking the first 5 to 8 years. Trees planted on M27 and M9 rootstocks will require staking for their entire lives and are ideally suited for use as espaliers or in a cordon systems because of this. It had been our intention to include a caution in the original article. Due to the pressures of our first deadlines it was unfortunately omitted. We are grateful to Mr. Vorbeck for bringing our omission to our attention. [BACK] | [FORWARD] WT01-B08-151IA069-000435-B029-113http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/dirt/issue2.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175107 text/html 12600HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:51:15 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:24:13 GMTETag: "e1cac-3046-31ae200d"Content-Length: 12358Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Back Issue (March) WHAT DO ROSES LIKE? Many would have you believe that growing roses is the biggest challenge and most mysterious process that gardeners face. Secret formulas for fertilizers and other concoctions abound. Every ardent rose grower has his or her own theory on just the right method to grow roses. Indeed, it seems that few groups of plant enthusiasts are as headstrong as are rosarians. In reality, growing roses is much easier than many might suspect. Before you select a spot to plant a rose, it is important to have a general sense of what roses like. Few things can have as great an impact on successful rose growing as finding the best location for the rose bush. Roses need and thrive in sunlight. Ideally they should be planted in an area that receives a minimum of six hours of sunlight a day. David Austin in his book "Old Roses and English Roses" goes so far as to say, "They do not like shade, even partial shade" Perhaps the best suggestion comes from Graham Stuart Thomas in his classic work "The Rose Book." He suggests that the best results particularly in very hot areas will come from planting roses where "their roots are shaded and their flowers are in full sun."The second most important consideration for growing beautiful roses is the soil they are planted in. Roses prefer and thrive in a rich, slightly acid soil that is well drained. If you have a poorly drained PREPARING THE SOIL More than many other plants, roses will benefit from careful preparation of the soil before planting. All too often, planting instructions focus on the planting hole. We take a slightly different approach and encourage gardeners to think instead of the area you will be planting your rosebush in. Rather than preparing a rich hole to plant your rose in, we suggest that you amend the area and then dig the hole for planting. Most roses will grow in an area roughly three foot by three foot, or four by four. Begin by spreading one to three inches of a good quality compost, like our Uncle Malcolm's Planting Mix or Mushroom Compost over the area. David Austin considers the addition of compost or humus "crucial in growing good roses." If you live in an area with very acid soils, you could add lime at this point, or if you are in an area with alkaline soils, soil sulfur or peat moss could be used to help acidify the soil. Spread Whitney Farms Rose and Flower Food over the area at the same time. Unlike many synthetic blends, there is no danger of burning tender roots with our fertilizers. They can be used safely at the time of planting.Thoroughly work all of this into the soil. Graham Stuart Thomas recommends digging as deeply as possible "up to 18 inches" as long as "undesirable subsoil is not brought to the surface." Indeed, he suggests that the poorer the soil, the more extensive and thorough the preparation should be. At the very least a spade's digging depth is recommended. By preparing the soil for planting in this way we have accomplished two very important things. First, we have loosened the soil around the hole so the roots can grow quickly into the surrounding soil. Second, we have already amended the soil that will go back into the hole. One word of caution: Do not work the soil when it is wet. (See our first issue for an explanation of how to tell if your soil is safe to work.) Meanwhile, soak your bare-root roses in water for an hour or two. This is particularly important if the roots may have dried in shipping or storage at the nursery. Next dig the hole. Be sure it is wide enough to easily take in the roots of the plant. Eighteen inches is usually sufficient for most plants. Save the soil from the hole. Mix a handful of compost with some more Rose & Flower Food, or a handful of Bone Meal, into the soil in the bottom of the hole. If you are planting a bare root rose, form a cone of soil in the hole and gently spread the roots over the cone. Be sure to keep the plants' bud union (the knob from which the canes grow) just above the soil surface. A small stick or board can be helpful to check the level of the bud union. In colder climates you can plant the rose with the bud union just below the surface. At this point, return the soil to the hole. When the hole is half full, give the bush a light shake to help settle the soil around the roots and then carefully firm the soil around the plant with your feet. Be careful not to tread too heavily. The soil should be firm enough to hold the plant, but not compacted. (Remember all the digging we did to loosen the soil for the roots to grow in!) Finish filling the hole with the remainder of the soil and then firm the soil again. The last step is to water the rose into the soil. This helps to ensure contact between the soil and the roots and to flush air out from around the roots.
