If you are planting a rose from a container, the steps are essentially the same, except that rather than forming a mound, refill the hole with enough soil that the bud union is jut above the soil surface. flatten the soil in the hole and position the rose in the center. Backfill as outlined above. CARING FOR YOUR NEW ROSES Everyone has a personal theory on the care and feeding of roses. here at the Dirt, we are no different. Because he is long famous for the cultivation of roses, we turn to the suggestions of the English expert David Austin. He claimed that the most important aspect of good rose care is probably mulching. Roses like a cool, rich, moist soil. Mulching helps to provide the right soil conditions for your roses, and makes continuous flowering possible. It helps to conserve moisture in the soil, as well as to suppress weeds. Mulching provides nutrients as well, reduces the susceptibility to some fungal diseases like black spot, and will help to keep the soil loose and friable. In fact, if you are growing roses in hot climates, one trick is to mulch early in the season before the soil warms. up. This helps to keep the soil cooler longer, encouraging your roses to thrive. Look for our Garden Mulch or Mushroom Compost at your favorite garden center. Mushroom compost is particularly well suited for use around roses as it is rich in potash, which roses like in abundance. However, if you live in areas with alkaline soils, we would discourage the use of mushroom compost. Because roses are heavy feeders, good nutrition is important too. We admit an obvious bias, but with good reason. Recently, a number of experts, (officers of regional rose societies) have been critical of organic fertilizers for a variety of reasons, including what they perceive as low nutrient content or high price. Often this only serves to illustrate how little most people know about soil fertility and how little they understand about organic fertilizers. Keep in mind that high analysis fertilizers like 16-16-16 are often made from very soluble nutrient sources. This means that they will be subject to leaching from the soil during periods of heavy irrigation or rainfall. In fact, many soil scientists estimate that as little as 10 to 20 percent of the synthetic nitrogen fed to plants actually ends up in the plant. Suddenly that super rich triple 16 becomes a 1.6% or at best a 3.2% fertilizer, and that much less of a bargain. By comparison, natural organic fertilizers like our Rose & Flower Food (4-6-2) are derived from nutrient sources that by definition are not water soluble and release their nutrients slowly over a long period of time. Unlike synthetic nitrogen sources, repeated use of organic sources can actually result in a reserve of nutrients building up over time, and can be used less often. In our mind, this offers the gardener a much better value. What is important is that your roses get a good feeding in early spring as they begin to show signs of new growth, again after the first blossoms fade, and finally one more feeding in midsummer. By using organic fertilizers and mulching, we are confident that your roses will be as beautiful as any in the neighborhood, with less work! How do we know? That is what our manysatisfied customers have been telling us for years! Alfalfa Meal is great for roses and is an ingredient in our rose food. the January 1993 issue of the American Rose Society Magazine recommended alfalfa meal for stronger stems and greener leaves. Rich in natural growth stimulants, use it according to directions�more is not better, and can actually suppress growth. Similarly, kelp meal, another ingredient of our fertilizer, can help increase disease resistance and provides a source of trace minerals. One rose grower had outstanding results when we added Greensand to his rose beds last spring. Chris Pruitt of Weeks Roses told us that he was amazed by the results he had when he used Greensand last year. For those of you who prefer foliar feedings, look for our Ellie's Ultimate Plant Food, a unique blend of hydrolized liquid fish and kelp meal. One reader of the American Rose Society Magazine also reported great results mulching roses with our Chicken Manure, but keep in mind that chicken manure is loaded with readily available nitrogen and could burn if over-applied. Generally, we would only recommend it for use around established roses and not for use when planting new roses. [BACK] | [FORWARD]WT01-B08-152IA069-000435-B029-143http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/dirt/dirt2.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175118 text/html 4868HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:51:26 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:23:49 GMTETag: "e1ca6-1213-31ae1ff5"Content-Length: 4627Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt APRIL'S MYTH OF THE MONTH The editors of the Dirt are on a mission to dispel gardening myths. This month we want to point out a fallacy perpetuated by those city slickers at the big Madison Avenue advertising agencies.No doubt, dear reader, you have seen those TV ads featuring someone standing in a field of wildflowers, sneezing their heads off and complaining of itchy, watery eyes. The impression is that big beautiful flowers are the culprits behind the allergy attacks. This simply is not the case.The serious offenders are plants with inconspicuous flowers which depend largely on wind to spread their pollen. (the actual allergen) This group includes many common trees and grasses. The wind spreads the pollen everywhere, including your house, your car, your office and finally up your nose and in your eyes.Showy flowers depend on bees and other insects to spread their pollen. Botanists theorize that flowering plants have evolved attractive colors precisely to increase their prospects for pollination and thus reproduction.So go ahead and smell the flowers. It's something else that's making you sneeze. Don't pick on the Chicken Chicken manure has gotten a bad rap. Many gardeners believe that it is likely to burn plants.Truth is, any fresh manure contains salts that can dehydrate plants, causing them to appear burnt.Well-rotted, composted manure, like all of our Whitney Farms products, applied judiciously (i.e., don't plant anything directly into large amounts of it) is non-burning and an excellent, even essential, ingredient to gardening success. Manure improves soil texture and makes it easier to work, it stimulates beneficial soil organisms, which makes the nutrients more available to the plants. It is important to remember that manure has what is called a high mineralization rate (which is how fast the nutrients it contains become available to plants). For example, only about half the nutrients in steer manure become available the first year. By comparison, 90% of the nutrients in chicken manure are available to plants in the first year. So, it is important to use chicken manure judiciously.The main advantage of chicken manure is that it is rich in nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium in a readily available form. Like all of our manure, Whitney Farms Chicken Manure has been composted and has a nutrient analysis of 3-2-2, which makes it specially suited to the nutritional needs of annuals and vegetables. Use it sparingly, spreading 1/4-1 inch of manure over the garden area and tilling it in to a depth of 4-8 inches. As a nutrient-rich top dressing, spread up to 1/2 inch of manure around the drip line of well established plants. Remember, the nutrients chicken manure contains become available quickly, so if in doubt, use a little less.Some of our competitors have been critical of our use of dried poultry waste (DPW) in our fertilizers; they call it a cheap filler.* We could not disagree more strongly. The low moisture DPW we use can last up to two years in the soil according to Ross Penhallegon from the Lane County, Oregon, Extension Office. In addition our DPW contains 4% nitrogen, 3% phosphorous, and 2% potash as well as trace minerals. We feel that it is a quality product that keeps our products affordable, while helping poultry producers deal with a substantial waste problem. In short, it is a well-balanced source of long lasting plant nutrients that produces excellent results at a moderate cost. *Ross H. Penhallegon, Values of Organic Fertilizers, Lane County Extension Office Commercial Horticulture, January 1993. [BACK] | [FORWARD]WT01-B08-153IA069-000435-B029-166http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/dirt/dirt3.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175126 text/html 4833HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:51:34 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:23:53 GMTETag: "e1ca7-11f0-31ae1ff9"Content-Length: 4592Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Move toward the light! Did you know that sunflowers face the sun because of a growth regulator called auxin? Unequal light on each side of the stem causes auxin to build up on the shaded side. The auxin buildup increases growth on that side of the stem, causing the stem to bend toward the light. This habit, which allows plants to make the best use of available light, is known as phototropism.Sunflowers are among the most popular flowers, and for good reason. They are charming, cheerful, and fun to grow. The heads, of course, are a source of food for people and animals. Sunflowers now range in color from red to yellow, from farm-size giants to a fuzzy double-flowered variety called "Teddy Bear." Garden centers now have entire seed racks devoted to sunflowers.Sunflowers are perhaps the best choice for children because their rapid growth and impressive flowers provide a sense of accomplishment. The following sunflowers, which produce flowers on many branches, are especially good for cutting: Teddy Bear Luna Primrose Stella Sungold Tithonia Autumn Beauty Q: When is a flower not a flower? A: When it is an inflorescence. What most people think of as flowers in the composite family of plants are really numerous tiny flowers arranged in a compact head. The petals of a daisy, for instance, are known botanically as ray florets. Sunflowers are another familiar example. Attracting butterflies and hummingbirds Happily, many flowers that attract butterflies and hummingbirds to the garden are easy to grow as well as colorful. In general, butterflies favor large flowers with abundant nectar, while hummingbirds are drawn to brightly colored tubular flowers such as fuschias. Consult your local nursery for specific advice on growing these flowers. Common perennials for attracting butterflies: (Common Name) (Scientific Name) Autuman Joy Sedum Sedum spectabile Bee Balm Monarda didyma Black-eyed Susan Rudbeckia spp. Buddlea Buddlea alternifolia Buttlerfly Bush Buddlea Davidii Chrysanthemum Chrysanthemum Common Rue Ruta graveolens Coreopsis Coreopsis spp. Daylilies Hemerocallis spp. Frikarti aster Aster frikatti Germander Teucrium spp. Globe Thistle Echinops ritro Heliotrope Heliotropium arborescens Honeysuckle Lonicera spp. Indian Blanket Gaillardia Lavender Lavendula spp. Mint Mentha spp. New Jersey Tea Ceanothus americanus Parsley Petraselinum crispum Pincushion Flower Scabiosa caucasica Purple Coneflower Echinacea purpurea Queen Anne�s Lace Daucus carota Rosemary Rosmarinus officinalis Spike Garfeathers Liatris spicata Summer Phlox Phlox paniculata Sunflowers Helianthus spp. Sweet Pea Lathyrus Thyme Thymus spp. Tiger Lily Lilium speciosum Violet Viola spp. Yarrow Achillea spp. Easy-to-Grow flowers for hummingbirds Columbine Achillea spp. Foxglove Digitalis spp. Lupine Lupinus Veronica Veronica Bee Balm Monarda didyma Lobelia Lobelia Clarkia Clarkia Did you know? Hummingbirds eat half their weight in food everyday. Hummingbirds are the only birds that can fly backward. They can also fly upside down and hover in their search for nectar and insects. however, you'll never see a hummingbird walk. They will fly even to move an inch. Some hummers beat their wings 70 times each second! [BACK] | [FORWARD]WT01-B08-154IA069-000435-B029-193http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/dirt/dirt4.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175137 text/html 10390HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:51:43 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:23:59 GMTETag: "e1ca8-27a4-31ae1fff"Content-Length: 10148Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Last month's feature was on trees. Due to space limitations, some content had to be left out. This month, however, we've expanded, and thus present: MORE ON TREES! To stake or not to stake? Contrary to popular opinion, it is generally better not to stake a tree. A recent study at Michigan State University showed that staking trees often results in long and leggy growth with thin and weak stems. Unstaked trees develop better root systems and more dense and compact growth. In areas where wind may be a problem, or if the tree starts to lean, the trunk should be attached loosely to the stake. An old nylon stocking makes a great flexible tie. If possible, use a flexible stake. Some movement is necessary for the tree to build a strong trunk and sturdy root system. After one year, the stake and ties should be removed, to prevent damage to the tree from the tie. Studies have also clearly shown that the old recommendation to prune the shoots to match the roots is also misguided. The old theory: Reduce the leaf surface to lessen transpiration and accommodate the reduced root system, and the plant would better survive transplanting. New theory: Research has shown that the shoots and leaves provide the plants with the photosynthetic surface to produce the nutrients required for good root growth. Finally, be sure to keep your new tree well watered during dry spells. In most areas, an inch of water per week is all that is required. Ideally, water the whole planting area�not just the area near the trunk�so as to encourage the growth of a vigorous root system. Just as you read about our favorite roses, here we present our picks on annuals. Peter Hershey: Choosing my favorite annual flower-Poached Egg Flower- was easy because I only grow a few. My family's garden consists mostly of perennials, small trees, flowering shrubs plus a vegetable garden. Poached Egg Flower,also known as Meadowfoam, bears the scientific name Limnanthes douglasii. It can be found at nurseries with good selections of native plants or specialty seed suppliers.Poached Egg Flower is an apt name. The profuse flowers have a bright yellow center surrounded by pure white. The foliage is a bright green, about the color and texture of parsley. The plant looks good enough to have for Sunday brunch. However, this is one tough plant that will thrive despite heavy soil, overwatering and light frost. Meadowfoam reseeds readily, yet will not become an pest. In a natural garden setting it is a welcome and underused treasure. Sylvia Carlton-Cordaro: Impatiens or Petunias? Impatiens grow in shade, they're bold, easy and reliable, and cheer up woodsy places. But petunias come in rainbows of colors and will grow anywhere in full sun, spilling out of baskets, mounding out of borders. Let's see, petunias or impatiens'? Kevin Loomis: Of the many annuals to choose from it is very difficult to choose a favorite! There are so many that have such specific uses. Some for heat tolerance, some for shade, some as dramatic specimen plants and others as wonderful companions mixed in containers. There is one, however, that I have always liked and used a great deal, which has earned a new special place in my garden. That annual is trailing Lobelia. Last year, trailing Lobelia seeds (apparently from containers in my gardens the previous year) self-sowed at random throughout my garden. Because of the light, almost airy growth habit of trailing Lobelia the effect was better than anything I could have planned. Beautiful light blues, lavenders and whites wove gently through and around perennials, roses, or whatever they happened to encounter. This year I will try to achieve similar results by scattering trailing Lobelia seeds throughout my gardens. Chris Totten: Agrostemma, or Coneflower; This beautiful wispy plant grows sturdily to a height of about three feet. the purple flowers unfurl as they bloom. It makes a great cut flower never failing to add character to a mixed bouquet. Brenda Sage: Sweet pea is my favorite annual flower because it provides plenty of fragrant bouquets all summer long. From time to time, The Dirt will print a roundup of various employees' favorite plants relevant to the appropriate season. Chris Totten: Madame Alfred Curriere. This amazing climber has a beautiful white bloom with a faint peach blush as at opens. The fragrance is unbelievable. It is very vigorous, and blooms profusely in the spring and fall. In Portland, it will continue blooming well into the fall, finally giving up with the onset of freezing weather. Brenda Sage: Graham Thomas, a David Austin English rose, is my favorite because it is vigorous, with true yellow flowers. It is fragrant and very disease-resistant. Sylvia Carlton-Cordaro: Although it�s a lanky rose, Gertrude Jekyll has pretty pink flowers that allure me. Then I can't keep my nose out of the blossoms the rest of the day. Norm Ross: American Beauty, because it was a Grateful Dead album cover; Bob Hope because of the memories; and Blazer, because I went to every one of the Portland Trailblazers' 1977 playoff games. (Norm likes basketball -Ed.) Kevin Loomis: My favorite rose is a budded shrub variety Floribunda named Bonica. Bonica displays masses of clear pink, ruffled and heavily petaled 2-3 flowers all summer, above glossy medium green foliage. It has a light, sweet fragrance and I have found it to be highly disease and insect resistant. Bonica's fragrance and contrast in flower and foliage color make it especially nice for a prominent position near a favorite evening sitting area. Peter Hershey: After the severe winter the Pacific Northwest gardeners just endured, my choice for favorite rose is clear. Of the disease resistant varieties we grow one stands out for hardiness and vigor -Rosa rugosa. It is the only one of 10 rose bushes that survived the February freeze unscathed. The others survived, but with extensive dieback because they had already come out of dormancy after the mild temperatures beforehand. Rosa rugosa is available in several color and form varieties. They all have attractive crinkly foliage and produce large orange-red fruit, called hips, that are a good source of vitamin C, and sometimes used in preserves. We know what our favorites are. Let us know about your faves! Write or e-mail us Whitney Farms Seed Starting Mix is a smash hit! The mix, a finely screened ensemble of peat moss, vermiculite, perlite and pumice, features excellent drainage and water retention. The strong supporting cast consists of natural fertilizers and pH buffers that bring life to the mix and ensure many happy endings. Whitney Farms Seed Starting Mix may be light in texture but it's a heavy hitter at the box office. Sales of seed starting mix through February this year exceed the total for all of 1995.It has opened the 1996 gardening season to rave reviews that are pouring in like spring sunshine.Here�s what reviewers from all over the Western U.S. are saying about Whitney Farms Seed Starting Mix:Two Green Thumbs Up! The good news is, his brothers Severo and David are still with us working in our warehouse. [BACK] | [FORWARD]WT01-B08-155IA069-000435-B027-149http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/dirt/issue1.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174653 text/html 11113HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:46:58 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Thu, 30 May 1996 22:24:05 GMTETag: "e1ca0-2a77-31ae2005"Content-Length: 10871Accept-Ranges: bytes The Dirt Issue 1 Issue 1 Whitney survives flood, butZoo Poo heads downstream Thanks to the hard work of county crews, trucks carrying Whitney Farms products were rolling just days after floodwaters tore up the road to the Garden Grow Company. In one day crews dumped 200 truckloads of gravel to fill 12 major washouts and several minor ones.Polk County's prompt response will minimize disruption of production and distribution.Company production workers will work double shifts seven days a week to make up for the week of lost time and $500,000 in lost inventory. High Water: The Willamette encroached, but did not flood out the buildings. The water came within six inches of the company warehouse, sparing the fertilizers and indoor sods. The main office also escaped damage. However, 700 pallets of bagged outdoor soil products and a pile of zoo animal manure were lost to the high water.In response, Garden Grow will ask our suppliers at Washington Park Zoo to increase their output so that the project can continue. The product, a compost that has yet to be named, is on hold for a year.The Willamette River normally flows peaceably along a high bank bordering the 67-acre property, which is located near the farming community of Independence Oregon.On Thursday Feb. 8 the river crested at 36 feet, covering the access road with four feet of water and swamping the composting yard. Employees had evacuated the premises when the water level reached 24 feet. The call to evacuate, according to company president and founder John Graham came when the rising waters lifted and started to push a fully loaded semi truck. Employees were not able to return to work until Tuesday Feb. 13, and then it was on foot. By the next day the road was back in service. Graham noted that insurance will cover the losses. "Normally we brag about our beautiful river front property. This week we're bragging about our flood insurance," said Graham. Planting Trees& Shrubs In recent years, many problems associated with trees in urban and suburban areas have been traced to poor planting techniques. Essentially, planting trees in the old-fashioned hole in dense compacted soils like those often found around new construction sites and filling the holes with amendments such as peat moss or compost can cause the roots to grow in tangled circles in the rich soil. Any outward growth stops when the roots reach the denser original soil. It is important to select either the right tree for the location, or if your heart is set on a particular tree, to ensure that it is planted in a suit-able spot. Once the proper site is found, loosen the soil by digging or tilling to a depth of 12 inches over an area as much as five times the diameter of the root ball. Ideally the planting area should be about 30 sq. ft. in size, with the minimum area no smaller than 4'X4'. Quality organic amendments, like Whitney Farms Planting Mix, can be added to the soil at this time. Use it uniformly throughout the area and mix it thoroughly into the soil. If required, blend fertilizers and lime into the planting area at the same time. Use our All Purpose Plant Food for planting trees and shrubs. For planting roses, we recommend our Rose & Flower Food. Some debate surrounds the use of organic matter when planting new trees. A number of studies have shown that the closer the soil in the planting area is to the native soil, the more success and better long-term health of the tree. There are exceptions to the rule, however. To decide if you need to use compost consider the following factors: 1) Assess the size of the tree when mature. Contrary to popular belief, a tree's roots are not a neat mirror image of its shoots. Root systems can extend three and four times the diameter of the drip line. Obviously, for large specimen trees like oaks or standard fruit trees, it would be all but impossible to amend the entire root system of the tree. By comparison many smaller trees and shrubs, including roses and fruit trees on dwarfing root stocks, have extremely compact root systems at maturity that are confined to a small area. With these plants it is quite practical and affordable to thoroughly amend the planting area. The plants will grow better as a result. 2) Assess the condition of the native soil. Adding compost or organic matter to the planting area can contribute significantly to the success of the planting if the soil has poor structure, drains poorly, or is excessively sandy or heavy. A simple rule of thumb is, the heavier the soil the less amendment should be used. If you are blessed with rich fertile soil it is likely that few or no amendments would be required for planting trees. Once the area has been tilled, dig a shallow hole no deeper than the root ball in the center. To prevent the tree from settling, do not loosen the soil beneath the root ball. However, if desired, the bottom of the planting area around the root ball could be loosened where practical. The tree can be set in the hole with the upper surface of the root halt or the old soil mark on the trunk at the same level as the existing soil. At this point, if you are planting a balled and burlapped plant, you should carefully cut and remove the rope or wires holding the burlap in place. Some nurserymen recommend that th burlap be removed as well, though care should be taken handling the rootball or it could be damaged. Roots circling the root ball should be spread out or even cut as needed. If you are planting bare root plants, gently spread the roots out in the hole. Cut off any damaged roots. Fill in around the root ball with the soil from the hole, and Gently pack it down to prevent air pockets. DO NOT compact the soil around the root ball with your feet. A good watering will help to settle the soil and ensure contact between the earth and the roots. Rake the soil around the area, and cover it with two to four inches of mulch like leaf mold, compost, or Whitney Farms Garden Mulch. Be careful to keep the mulch away from direct contact with the trunk. In some areas with low rainfall, gardeners are often encouraged to form a berm around the plant to conserve water. It may, however, also cause the roots to concentrate in the area within the berm close to the tree, as well as contributing to problems with crown rot in areas of high rainfall. A good mulch provides the same water saving benefit without contributing any problems. Check before you dig! Or how to be sure you get the most out of your dirt...All the hard work you have put into building your soil can disappear in one misguided morning of overzealous digging or tilling. Working a soil that is too wet or too dry can destroy the structure of the soil. Clay sods in particular are easily damaged by digging when they are too wet or dry. Take a moment to check your soil by following these simple steps. 1. Pick up a handful of your soil and squeeze it gently in your palm to form afirm ball. 2. If the soil balls up easily without oozing through your fingers or disappearing into the palm of your hand as gooey mess, it, may be ready to work. The final check is to see if the ball crumbles, easily. If you can make a firm ball of soil that still crumbles readily, your soil is just right for digging or tilling. 3. If the soil is too dry, you will not be able to form a ball. In this case, give your garden a thorough soaking, let it drain for a day or two, and repeat the above test. 4. Some soils , like sandy soils are more forgiving and can be worked more easily than clay soils. For more information on how to determine the kind of soil you have, keep your eye on future editions of The Dirt, or browse the Soil Ammendments section of our web site. Uncle Malcolm's Fun Facts © The Dinosaur Tree The Ginkgo tree is the sole surviving member of an ancient family. During the Mesozoic Era dinosaurs roamed the earth in forests full of these primitive trees.The Ginkgo is a deciduous broadleaf tree, but is unique because it is related closely to conifers.Scientists once believed the Ginkgo survived only because of its cultivation as a sacred tree in China temple gardens. However, wild Ginkgos have recently been found growing in remote valleys of western China. The Ginkgo's fan-shaped leaves turn bright yellow in the fall, then drop all at once, making a loud "swoosh" sound. This curious habit endears to anyone who wants to keep leaf raking to a minimum. TheGinkgo, as you might expect, is also highly adaptable. It withstands Pollution, low sunlight, meager soil, and extreme temperatures. It is virtually immune to disease and pests. With all those traits, the Ginkgo should be around for another 200 million years. Does Peanut ButterGrow on Trees? The Harlequin Glorybower, a small garden tree that has pretty white flowers in late summer, is also known as the peanut butter tree. The next time you're in a nursery, crush one of its leaves between your finger and sniff it. Many people think that the scent is similar to peanut butter. Unfortunately, the leaves make a lousy sandwich, even with jelly. Take me Back WT01-B08-159IA069-000435-B029-217http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/malcolm/past.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208175149 text/html 823HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:51:53 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Fri, 08 Nov 1996 20:27:11 GMTETag: "141002-247-3283979f"Content-Length: 583Accept-Ranges: bytes I Love Martha Past Adventures Take me BACK.WT01-B08-160IA069-000435-B027-339http://www.whitneyfarm.com:80/ask/questorg.htm 206.163.112.59 19970208174757 text/html 20165HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 17:48:02 GMTServer: Apache/1.2b6Connection: closeContent-Type: text/htmlLast-Modified: Tue, 11 Jun 1996 18:17:29 GMTETag: "11b4a4-4dd2-31bdb839"Content-Length: 19922Accept-Ranges: bytes Organic Gardening Questions and Answers Organic Gardening Brooksville, Florida Dear Whitney Farms-- Can you explain adding minerals and nutrients to soil? What value does this have? Plants feed themselves by converting the energy contained in sunlight toforms that can be utilized by life on this planet. This is a processknown as photosynthesis. As part of that process plants require certainnutrients some of which come from the air, some from water, and somefrom the soil. By supplying nutrients to the soil, we are ensuring thatthe plants have the elements they require to perform the valuable servicethey provide the rest of us who depend on them for food. A good example is magnesium. It is at the heart of the chlorophyllmolecule--putting the 'green' in plants--and acts much like thehemoglobin in our own blood. Only 20% of the magnesium in plants ispart of chlorophyll, it also is necessary to every operation in a plantinvolving phosphorus; it influences the metabolism of nitrogen and isimportant to the assimilation of carbon dioxide during photosynthesis.Obviously, it is vital to the well being of plants. Plants getmagnesium from the soil. At the same time, it is important to understand that every time weharvest a vegetable, cut a flower, or feed plants to livestock we aretransferring minerals and nutrients from the soil where the plants grewto a new location--our bodies, the cows, our dining room table, or eventhe garbage. If we don't replace those nutrients either by compostingor through supplements from fertilizers we could eventually deplete thenatural reserves of available nutrients in the soil, and we would nolonger be able to grow plants. It is also true that in many soils some nutrients are deficient or in aform that is not available to plants. This is particularly true ofnitrogen. Nitrogen is very soluble in water and is often deficient inmost soils. It is also absolutely essential for plant growth. It candramatically limit our abilities to grow plants. By adding it to oursoils, we ensure that our plants have what they need to grow and thrive. Ultimately, the value of adding nutrients and minerals to the soil isthat we ensure that our plants grow, that the organisms in the soilvital to the health and growth of our plants are able to grow andthrive, and most importantly we ensure that the food we eat is rich andwell balanced and contains the minerals and vitamins we need to live. It is my belief that without soil and the plants that grow in it, lifeas we know it would not exist on this planet. All the food we eat, allthe gasoline we burn, all the natural gas we cook with is a by-productof the process of photosynthesis. Without it, we would cease to exist.By taking care of our soils and providing them with the nutrients theyrequire to support the plants and the rest of the life on the planet, weensure that we continue to live on this planet. Without fertile soilsyou have deserts where nothing grows and only the toughest species oforganisms can survive--we humans are not that tough!! Hope I could answer your question...It is not one that lends itself to ashort or simple response...If you still need clarification, please emailagain. What does organic mean? There are a variety of definitions on what constitutes "organic." At Whitney Farms our guiding definition of "organic" is any naturally occurring animal and plant by-products approved for use by the major certification organizations like Oregon Tilth and California Certified Organic Farmers. We only use products that will improve the soil and encourage a healthy population of soil organisms, while meeting the nutritional requirements of your plants. Does a plant know the difference between a synthetic/chemical fertilizer and an organic fertilizer? All nutrients, whether synthetic or organic must be converted to a form which can be utilized by the plant. The plant does not recognize a difference between synthetic/ chemical or organic nutrient sources, but the soil does. Organic fertilizers and amendments are meant to develop a healthy and vital population of the organisms that make nutrients available to plants. Therein lies the age old organic gardening motto, "Feed the soil, not the plant." A plant's growth is dependent on the ability of the soil to retain and release nutrients. It is therefore critical that the soil be nurtured and fed. A healthy soil will result in a garden full of healthy plants. Our intent is to help the gardener build a fertile soil with a large reserve of nutrients. The plant will draw the nutrients it needs from this storehouse in the soil. What impact does soil temperature have on organic fertilizers? Because organic fertilizers work in unison with the microbial life in the soil, most organic fertilizers work more effectively when the ground temperature is above 55 degrees Fahrenheit, which allows those organisms to be active. Below that ground temperature, the biological processes in the soil may be sluggish and the nutrients are, in a sense, "dormant" in the soil. Why are organic fertilizers more expensive than synthetic/chemical fertilizers and yet still considered a better value? Organic fertilizers are more expensive than synthetic/chemical fertilizers because the raw materials cost considerably more. In most cases, however, organic fertilizers are a better value because they don't have to be used as often, and will have the long term benefit of improving the soil. Organic fertilizers may be more expensive, but they will improve the ability of the soil to retain and release nutrients that will reduce a garden's overall fertilizer needs. How often should organics be applied? How frequently you apply fertilizers will depend largely on the inherent fertility of the garden soil. A very poor soil may require regular applications of nutrients and soil amendments as it is being built-up. Rich, healthy soil only requires applications of nutrients to replace those that are removed by the plants or lost by natural processes of decay. Because organic matter is naturally consumed by soil organisms it is advisable to apply compost or other amendments and organic fertilizers at least once a year. Don't organics work slower than synthetic/chemical fertilizers? Organic fertilizers work gradually, and that is what contributes to their effectiveness. Because the nutrients are released slowly, the plants are able to use them as they need them, and to grow at a natural rate. This slow release enhances the inherent ability of plants to resist attacks. from insects and disease, and to survive dramatic extremes of climate, such as drought and unseasonable freezes. How important is amending the soil in organic gardening? Amending the soil is the foundation of organic gardening. The whole philosophy is to encourage the growth of those organisms within the soil that govern the availability of nutrients. By carefully amending the soil through the use of regular applications of organic matter, the physical structure of the soil can be vastly improved. This will contribute significantly to better moisture retention, nutrient retention, aeration, and drainage. Dear Whitney Farms -- Can you recommend a source of Organic fertilizerthat will giver the desired results as per 1000square feet? First let me tell you how to determine how much nitrogen is in a givenfertilizer. You will find three numbers on every label of fertilizer. Thefirst is nitrogen (N)--green growth in plants; the second is phosphorous(P)--flowering, fruiting, and rooting; the third number is potash(K)--overall health and vigor (these are simple "rules of thumb" butgenerally accurate.) These numbers are a percentage of the weight of thebag. So, for example if we had a 100 lb. bag of a 10-10-10 fertilizer, 10%of 100 lbs. would be the total nitrogen content of the product--10 lbs..The math is not as neat for P and K, there is a small conversion for theactual content. (Hopefully, I didn't just bore you with information youalready knew!) So, to answer your question, I would suggest blood meal for your nitrogensource. Why? Oregon State University has been looking at organic nitrogensources for the last couple of years, and the Professor doing the researchhas come to believe that blood meal is the single finest nitrogen source hehas ever seen, bar none--synthetic or organic. It will release itsnutrients in cold, wet soils or warm, dry soils. It releases its nutrientsquickly, and yet OSU has seen it continue to feed for up to 8 months ormore. It is good stuff. How much to apply? Given the information above, there are about 2.6 poundsof N in a 20 lbs. bag of Blood Meal (13% of 20 lbs.). So that ought toprovide you with what you are looking for. Be sure to add compost at the same time you till in the fertilizer, if youare not in the habit of doing so already. Dear Whitney Farms -- About how large an area will 1 yard of mulch cover if it is about 2 inches deep. We estimate that it takes about nine cubic feet to cover a hundredsquare feet (10 X 10) with one inch of compost. Given that there are 27cubic feet in a cubic yard, you should be able to cover about 150 sq.ft. with a yard of material spread two inches deep. Dear Whitney Farms -- what's the last spring frost date in st.paul,mn? Is this a trick question? Being from Oregon, and central Californiabefore that, I can't honestly say that I know the last frost date forSt. Paul. Were I to seek out the answer, I would call the agriculturalextension service for the State of Minnesota. I know that in Montanathe growing season is relatively short--in the 75- to 150-day range, andthat it is possible to have a frost almost any time of the year in someof the more mountainous areas. The last frost can be as late as earlyJune. Presumably, conditions are similar in Minnesota. Sorry we could not be of more help, but the question is a little out ofour range--give those extension folks a call though! We pay taxes sothat we can get information like that from folks like them! Oceanside(San Diego) CA Dear Whitney Farms -- Which of your fertilizers would be best for an outdoor cactus garden? I would recommend our All-Purpose Plant Food for use in cactus gardens.It is an excellent general purpose fertilizer that has long lastingingredients to gently feed your cactus throughout the year. One or twoapplications per year should be sufficient for the needs of most cactusplants. Dear Whitney Farms -- What are the major drawbacks to using chemical fertilizers in our garden. I am especially concerned about any health related problems orsoil contamination. I can not tell you honestly that in and of themselves chemical orsynthetic fertilizers are harmful or inherently evil. If usedjudiciously and intelligently they can make a significant contributionto the overall health and productivity of our soils. Unfortunately thatis not how they are use. Instead, they are viewed as all that is needed to grow plants. Vitaminsare important to our health, but it would be impossible for us to liveon vitamins alone. I see synthetic fertilizers in much the same light.They are only one part of a very complex picture. Here are the primarydrawbacks I see to there use: Destruction of soil structure. Soil is alive and depends on organicmatter to keep it healthy. Just as we require carbon to live so to dothe organisms in the soil. Excessive use of synthetic or chemicalfertilizers has several detrimental effects on the soil. One soilmicrobiologist I know has documented the destruction of soil life due tosalt based, synthetic fertilizers. She says it is a pretty simpleprocess--you have a salt, with a very low moisture pressure (thefertilizer) next to bacteria and other organisms critical to the healthand productivity of the soil. These organisms are basically cellsfilled with water. Water moves from areas of high pressure (thebacteria) to areas of low pressure (the fertilizer). The result? Awhole bunch of dead soil microbes. This particular biologist hasdocumented a depletion of soil life on American farmlands from a naturalhigh of anywhere from 200-2000 species to a low of fewer than 20species--all due, she believes, to the overapplication of salt basedfertilizers. (chemical fertilizers are by definition salt based)Furthermore, many of the less expensive forms of these products utilizesources or raw materials that are very high in chloride, also toxic tomicrobial life. So what's the big deal? Dead bacteria who cares? Most people do notrealize that all the nutrients plants need are cycled at one time oranother by the biology in the soil. In fact, most forms of syntheticnitrogen are made available by microbes in the soil. Without themicrobes the soil is dead and unproductive. Furthermore, the microbial life in the soil makes a significantcontribution to the structure of the soil which determines how easy itis to work, to the prevention and destruction of pests and diseases (Infact, penicillin is a derived from soil microbes!), to the overall growthof plants in the soil. At the same time, due to the excessive use of synthetic nitrogen, soilsystems can be affected in several other ways. For example, if there isalways an overabundance of soluble nitrogen, many of the microbialsystems slow down--why work if we don't need to. Then when the plantsneed the nitrogen to be converted to a more available form thebiological system that makes that happen is not working at optimumefficiency. At the same time, because there is a balance of carbon andnitrogen in the soil, a lot of soluble nitrogen floating around can leadto the destruction of soil organic matter which ultimately leads to lossof soil structure and productivity. This can lead to catastrophicevents like the dust bowl in the early part of this century, or erosionat levels far beyond what the soil can naturally replace. Many chemical fertilizers are acidifying which can cause problems inareas where soils are already acid. Many nutrients are made lessavailable due to high acidity (low pH), which results in plants notbeing able to use them and suffering from nutrient deficiencies. Soluble forms of nitrogen are also readily leached out of the soil oftencausing ground water contamination due to excessive nitrateconcentrations. Nitrates are toxic to mammals and extremely harmful tobabies etc. I have seen some work indicating a relationship betweenmiscarriage and high nitrate levels in farm well water. At the sametime, in places like the Everglades extremely high levels of phosphorousdue to the excessive use of phosphate fertilizers has caused severeenvironmental damage. Furthermore, many lakes and streams in thiscountry are clogged with algal blooms directly related to the misuse andover dependence on synthetic nitrogen on agricultural lands. There is a good body of evidence to show that the salts can build up inthe soil also leading to a loss of productivity. The deserts of Iragand Iran are known to anthropologists and historians as the FertileCrescent and may be the first example of highly centralized, irrigatedagriculture. Many scientists believe that these practices lead directlyto the desertification of the region and the current state of the landthere. More? Ironically, many soil scientists estimate that only a very smallpercentage of the chemical fertilizers applied actually find there wayinto the plants. Some estimates are as low as 10-20%. The rest is tiedup in the organic matter of the soil, where it is released to plants insubsequent seasons, or it is leached out into the water supply, or lostto the atmosphere as a gas. Gardeners become dependent on the fertilizers and fail to understandwhat is happening in the soil. They stop adding organic matter orcompost, and the soil becomes less and less productive. So they addmore and more fertilizer and the soil becomes less and less productive.Soil is alive and you have to feed that life to keep it productive.Inert salts do not feed the soil. In fact, in reality they do not even feed the plants. Sunlight and thephotosynthetic process feeds plants (and the rest of us too!), thenutrients in the soil, air and water are only the building blocks thatmake that process possible. Feed the soil, not the plants! What else? It is very easy to make a severe mistake with highlyconcentrated salt based, synthetic fertilizers. An obvious example issalt burn. Too much fertilizer salts and the plants burn. Otherproblems can be more subtle. It does not take a lot of some of thetrace minerals to cause some very severe nutritional deficiencies in theplants. Often synthetic blends have these trace mineral packages inthem that are supposed to be just dandy--but no one knows how much ofthese substances you already have present in your soil. People justapply them because the box told them too, and yet they could be buildingup a toxic level of a trace mineral without even realizing it. Synthetic fertilizers contribute to our dependency on foreign oil. Ittakes energy to make them and some are even made using by products ofoil. Synthetic fertilizers can also cause over abundant growth in plants.This can make plants weak, subject to falling over when exposed to theleast wind or the most gentle spring rain. That overly lush growth canalso be attractive to insect pests and subject to diseases. It is alsotypically very water intensive--all that growth makes a plant a lot lessdrought resistant. There is some evidence that produce grown with soluble salt basedfertilizers is also less nutritious than that grown using naturalorganic methods. There is a fairly large body of research comparing thedry weight of produce--the crops grown using chemical fertilizers arefull of water, and have a lower mineral content than that using organicmethods. These are a few of the concerns that I have with the long term use ofchemical fertilizers. I hope I answered some of your questions. OurWeb page (as you probably already know) has some more info which mayalso answer some of your concerns. I would also invite you to visit a"friend's" web page. Check out www.cfarms.com (if that doesn't work trycfarm.com without the ess). They have a great, albeit long, piece aboutwhy organic covering many of these topics and more. And we haven't even begun to discuss pesticides... (frost?) I couldn't tell where you lived in New York state, upstate?, NYC?I would bet that you are getting closed to the planting date for tomatosin your area. In the milder parts of NY state, I believe mid to lateMay is just the right time, and in some of the colder areas late in themonth should be fine. You still might want to be prepare to protectthem in the event of a late frost. For more exact information, contact the New York State AgriculturalExtension Service. We all pay tax dollars to have these folks availableto answer questions just like the one you have! They can usually provideyou with planting dates for all the major vegetables in your area. Dear Whitney Farms -- I just read your topic on watering and am considering running a networkof soaker hoses throughout my various vegetable beds.Question: Would it work if I were to bury the hoses slightly under the soilnext to the plants? Yes!! It works really well. People have even started to use the new"weeping" style soaker hoses under lawns for irrigating turf grass. Thekey is to be certain that you have "weeping" soakers (most majormanufacturers make a version of them) not the old style "soaker" hosesthat spray streams of water or the really old forerunners of today'shoses--canvas soakers. Burying the hose would not work with thesetypes. The second key is not piercing the hose with garden forks, weeders,spades, shovels, etc. when you are out working in the garden (havingonce done it, I can tell you that I now have a very clear visual senseof how sink holes are formed...). A great way to set your system up is to go ahead and plant as younormally would and lay the hose out to fit the needs of your currentgarden. I would counsel flexibility--don't lock yourself into a set upthat won't allow for annual changes in the layout of the vegetable patchfor crop rotations, etc. Then, after the soil warms up, mulch over thehose. Simple as that. . . I have used the hoses extensively and know commercial growers who haveemployed them in intensively managed systems anc can vouch for theireffectiveness. One other note: You will need to account for your soil type when layingout the hose. On sandy soils, the water is going to go virtuallystraight down (think carrot shape) whereas on clay soils the water isgoing to move more laterally as well as vertically (think onion). Besure that the spacing between the hoses accounts for the way water movesin your soil. Dear Whitney Farms-- HI... I ALREADY HAVE A WELL ESTABLISHED GARDEN, IN 12" POT APPROX. 40 OR SO AND A VEGGIE BED THAT IS APPRX. 4' X 4'. I LIVE IN A CONDO SO I HAVEHAD TO IMPROVISE. I KNOW FROM MY COURSE IN BIOLOGY 122 THIS SEMESTER THAT PLANTS ESSENTIALLY NEED 9 BASIC NUTRIENTS IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN ITS RICHNESS. I HAVE READ THE LABEL ON "MIRACLE GROW" AND CAN NOT DECIDEIF MY VEGETABLES ARE STILL GOING TO BE ORGANIC.. I AM USINGABSOLUTELY NO OTHER FERTILIZER OR BUG AND WEED KILLER. IF IT DOES TAKE THE "ORGNIC OUT OF MY VEGETABLE GARDEN, CAN I CORRECT THE PROBLEM BYCHANGING THE SOIL OR CAN I JUST USE YOUR PRODUCT FROM NOW ON AS I GRADUATE MY PLANTS INTO LARGER POTS AND EXTEND MY VEGETABLE BED. PLEASE ADVISE AND SEND ME INFORMATION IF YOU HAVE AN ORGANIC NEWSLETTER OF ANY SORT. PERSONALLY, I MAKE CLOTHING OUT OF RECYCLED PLASTIC SODA BOTTLES AND/OR RECYCLED COTTON...WE ARE TRYING TO MAKE MORE ROOM FOR FIELDS AND LESS ROOM FOR LAND FILLS! ECOLOGICALLY YOURS... To answer your question, plants need more than just the 16 essentialnutrients you learned about in class. In fact one of the bigdifferences between organic and what I call convential vegetables is theactuall mineral content in the plant tissue. The elements you learnedabout have been identified as essential to the growth of plants, butthere is much more happening here particularly in terms of the manydifferent organisms who call the soil home and are beneficial to thegrowth of your plants... To answer your specific question...Miracle Gro is not now and never willbe organic...It has taken the organic completely out of yourgarden...and it is just about the most expensive way to fertilize--butthat is a whole other conversation. Don't worry...while it is not "organic" by the market definition, it isalso not in and of itself "toxic." This is a fertilizer after all, andnot a pesticide or an herbicide. Don't get obsessed with labels. Some of the trace minerals required arein such small concentrations that annual applications of compost, orusing compost based potting soils like Whitney Farms potting soils, willusually supply most if not all of the various trace minerals required.I would heartily encourage you to take a look at our vegetable food foryour fertilizer needs. Just mix it in the next time you water or if youare potting up to a larger size. Otherwise, liquid fish or liquid fishand kelp products work wonders for quick, natural organic supplementalfeedings. We have a great product out there in nurseries called Ellie'sUltimate Plant Food--it's a fish and kelp combo--the kelp helps providetrace minerals. Also, organic gardeners/farmers will supplement withproducts like greensand or raw rock phosphate or even ground rock dustas a supplement for trace minerals. So, don't go to the trouble of replacing the soil, just make the switchand you will be back on track and gardening organically... Alabama--- Dear Whitney Farms -- I am trying to start an organic vegetable garden. What steps can I take to prevent pests in the garden. I have heard that planting various flowering plants with the vegetables will help ward off unwanted bugs. Any suggestions? One of the underlying principles of organic gardening is diversity. Without it, weare sorely limited in what we can do as gardeners. Your question touches on anumber of different topics: trap plantings, companion planting, and attractingbeneficial insects to the garden. A couple of basic principles in organic gardening (and gardening in general):1) Focus your energies on improving the soil! Organic gardening is as much aboutfeeding the soil as it is about reducing the chemical inputs to our garden. Thetheory goes, and the experience teaches, that the healthier and more rich the soil,the healthier the plants that grow in it. Essentially, much like humans have theability to resist the various diseases that affect us, most plants have a naturalresistance to insects and diseases. By allowing the plants to grow at a morenatural rate and ensuring that the soil is full of the vital nutrients needed bythe plants to grow, we can help the garden better withstand the various pests thatmight afflict it. 2) Plant the right plants in the right place. Be sure that the plant you aregrowing is suited to the environment you are asking it to grow in. More problemsare caused by poor choices--putting shade loving plants in a hot sunny location,for example. 3) Avoid monocultures like the plague. Plant a variety of vegetables and flowersa few at a time, as opposed to one big massive planting that goes in all on thesame day. With diversity comes stability. 4) Accept a little damage from time to time as the cost of gardening in a naturalworld. I am not suggesting that you surrender to the pests, but realize that notall insects are pests. Entomologists estimate that at best only 2% and at worst10% of insects would qualify as pests. All too often, we get the arsenal out tokill a couple of aphids that could be washed off with a sharp stream of water andend up killing all the good guys that were feeding on the aphids. Balance is thekey. If you are going to attract beneficial insects to the garden, they need tohave someone to eat, or they will just move on to the next garden with a readymeal. So, to get to the specifics of your question. There are a number of strategiesthat can be utilized to reduce the problems you might have. One is companionplanting. Basically this just means mixing it up. Planting a variety of plantsthat use different parts of the soil for example. Some plants are shallow rootedand others deeply rooted. Some plants like to vine and climb, while others like totumble out across the garden. A classic example of companion planting are the'three sisters' of native American agriculture--corn, beans and squash. All arestaples of the traditional diet--the corn gives the beans something to climb on,the beans fix nitrogen which feeds the corn and the squash, the squash fills thearea between the plants, helping to shade it and keep it cool--conserving moistureand cutting down on competition from weeds. More nebulous are the interactions between the plants themselves. This is not aswell documented, but there seems to be a fair amount of anecdotal evidence to showthat some plants do well when planted together. Tomatoes and basil, beans andcorn, the cabbage family and onions, etc. This is all subject to a great deal ofopinion, but there are books out there with lists that can give you some guidance.Check out Rodales' Encyclopedia of Organic Gardening, or Robert Kouriks' book aboutedible landscaping titled "Designing and Maintaining Your Edible LandscapeNaturally"(this one is a great source of a number of different lists of plantsthat attract insects, repel insects, etc.)--to name just a couple. A number of plants are also attractive to beneficial insects, like Angelica. Arobust perennial member of the umbell or parsley family, it produces huge flowerheads that are attractive to a number of beneficial insects. By planting plantslike this in and around the garden, you can actually help to attract the bugs thateat the bugs that eat your plants. Quite a few fairly common plants make the list,like candytuft and yarrow to name just a couple. This goes back to my commentsabout avoiding monoculture--no where in nature do you see whole stands of just oneplant all the same age. So don't be afraid to mix the flowers in with thevegetables. Even if you just have the occasional stand of flowers at the end ofthe beds, or you edge your beds with marigolds, they will help to attract the goodguys to your garden. Some research has been done using some plants as trap crops to entice the pestsaway from the crop you want to harvest and into a plant that you are willing tosacrifice. Birds are good predators. Many an aphid outbreak has been cured in my yard by theneighborhood birds long before I could get the Safers Soap out to do the aphids in.Plant shrubs around the outside of the garden that will attract birds and give thema place to hide between forays into your garden. There are also any number of cultural controls you can resort to. Like using verylight reemay fabrics to float over your plants as they grow preventing pests fromgetting into the plants where they could lay eggs and do harm. Water is aneffective control for pests like aphids and mites--a good sharp stream will knockthem from your plants down to the soil from where they will never find there wayback to your plants. Learn about your local pests, when they are active, whattheir lifecycle is and time your plantings, controls, etc. accordingly. This lastpoint is probably the most important. If you know a little bit about the pest, youcan go a long way toward controlling it. Most important, don't get discouraged. If you loose the occasional battle, make afew notes, learn a little about what went wrong, and avoid the same mistakes nextyear. One of the things I appreciate most about gardening organically is that itencourages us to understand a little more of what goes on in our gardens, asopposed to viewing them as some industrial process which can be managed with theintroduction of chemical A or B. If this is your first year gardening organically,it does take time to reintroduce nature into your garden. But don't believe thehorror stories you may hear about loosing all of your crops to pests they simplyaren't true. A great fallacy of modern agriculture is this notion that we haveeradicated pests--we use more chemicals than ever in wider variety than we've everimagined yet according to a report I recently heard, we loose about the samepercentage of crops to pests as we did before the introduction of all thechemicals! HMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM!!!!!!!!!!! Dear Whitney Farms -- My vegetable garden is situated under the branches of my neighbors oaktree. it is not shaded, but it does drop a great deal of aphids into myyard the infestation usually begin just about the time my tomatoes andpeppers are ready to set fruit, and is disastrous. what can I do toprevent this from happening again. I am an organic gardener, but lastyear I had to resort to other methods to save my crop any suggestionswould be helpful. This is not an easy one. Anytime the pest problem crosses neighborhoodboundaries it makes solving the problem a bit more difficult. Here are my ideas:1) The obvious answer--move the garden. I realize that forconsiderations of light, etc. that might not be an option. 2) Talk to your neighbor and explain the problem. I would offer tocontrol it myself--as opposed to making it your neighbors problem. Youcould spray the tree with a good sharp stream of water and blast theaphids off--unless they are in the winged stage or actually land on yourplants, it is unlikely that they will find there way by foot into yourgarden as they are not very mobile. You could also hit the tree with aSafer's Soap Solution (an organic control) or use a solution of SunsprayHorticultural Oil (approved for use by most of the Organic CertifyingGroups), or use a product containing Neem--also organic--though I am notsure it has vegetable registration yet. This would at least help toreduce the population in the tree above your garden, and give yourplants a head start. The soap is an excellent control to use in thevegetable garden too. (A lot of people are convinced it doesn't work,but if you understand how it works--on contact--and use it early in theday so it can stay wet on the pests as long as possible it is veryeffective and very safe.) Aphids are very easy to control organically,so I am surprised that you "had to resort to other methods." 3) You could also try some releases of beneficial insects in the areaas well. You can order green lacewings by mail and release them intothe garden near the oak tree. Provided your neighbor doesn't spray thetree (and I don't get the impression he does) these voracious littlecreatures will make a feast of the aphids. I have friends who areorganic farmers and very successfully control aphids with thesepredators. I have also spoken to a person who manages the pest controlof a state university grounds and uses the lacewings very successfullyto control aphids in trees on the grounds. Ladybugs will eat aphids,but often are not as effective as the lacewings--so most expertsrecommend the latter. Dear Whitney Farms -- My zucchini squash plants have white spots on the leaves that look likemildew. What is it? Can I get rid of it using household products? To answer your question, it does indeed sound like powdery mildew. Are thetops of the leaves covered in a white powdery growth? Do areas of theleaves turn brown and dry? Does it affect older leaves first then theyounger leaves? Do leaves become cupped and show silvery undersides? Doesthe powdery growth attack the fruit? Answered yes to some or most of these?Yes, you do have mildew on your squash. How to control it?In general the best approach is to select varieties that are resistant topowdery mildew. At the very least, if you find one variety to beparticularly susceptible, I would suggest you avoid planting it and try anew variety of zucchini. There are a number of cultural practices you can use to limit the incidenceof the fungus. 1) Plant in unshaded areas as much as possible. 2)Provide enough water and avoid excess fertilizer. (Here comes a plug fororganics--unlike most synthetic fertilizers which are typically comprised ofvery soluble forms of nitrogen--they are readily available, organicfertilizers tend to be slow release, which means more natural growth. Mostplants have a natural ability to resist disease and insect attacks.Synthetic fertilizers often 'push' the plant causing them to grow too fastand become susceptible to attack. Using organic fertilizers allows theplant to grow at a more natural rate, and often results in better resistanceto disease. You will find the plants to be just a productive.) 3) Sincespores are often killed or suppressed in the presence of free moistureplantings with overhead sprinklers or with frequent water sprays may have areduced incidence of powdery mildew. 4) Rotate your plantings from year toyear. 5) Clean up and destroy any infested plant material. Do not use itin your compost. 6) Use lots of compost-it often helps to enhance thepresence of naturally occurring antibiotics, etc. in your garden. From time to time it may be necessary to use fungicides. Organically, youcould try Safer's Garden Fungicide--a formulation containing sulfur (checkthe label to be sure that squash are listed.) Timing is everything. Do notuse sulfur sprays on days when the temperature is expected to exceed 90degrees. My sources caution that some varieties of squash may be sulfursensitive so you may want to try it on part of a plant rather that the wholething. Remember, sulfur works to prevent the disease, not to cure it. Besure to apply it before you see and outbreak of powdery mildew. In the last couple of years, there has been a lot of work done looking atusing a baking soda solution to control mildew and black spot on roses. Theformula for roses is 3 tsps. baking soda and 1 TBS. HorticulturalOil--Sunspray seems to be the best--in a gallon of water. Spray to preventthe disease. Please remember--this is not an official recommendation!!Technically, we are not allowed by law in the industry to makerecommendations that do no appear on the product label. But you wanted toknow about household products... The non organic control would be to use a product containing a fungicidecalled chlorothalonil. Spray according to the directions on the label at 7day intervals. (You will find this as Orthos' Daconil Multi-PurposeFungicide.)
